PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 12.30 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996 (No. 2).

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (WORK FOR THE DOLE) BILL 1997

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had disagreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Work for the Dole) Bill 1997 and requesting the reconsideration of the bill in respect of the said amendments.
Ordered that consideration of the message in committee of the whole proceed forthwith.
Motion (by Senator Newman) proposed:
That the committee does not insist upon its amendments disagreed to by the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak against that motion. I believe that the Senate should insist on this amendment. I moved this amendment to hold the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to his word. He announced that this would be a trial program for 10,000 young unemployed Australians. The bill that we were presented with allows the principle of work for the dole to be extended to all or most unemployed Australians at a time of any future government's choice. I do not believe that is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I extended the sunset clause time frame because the minister argued that 18 months was not enough time for them to do a proper evaluation. A proper evaluation is important, but I do not mean a departmental evaluation where ministers choose to tell us what they think assists their case; I mean a parliamentary evaluation. We are now denied that opportunity because the Labor Party is prepared to allow this government, for reasons which it now has on the public record, firstly, to implement the scheme as is and, secondly, to deny the parliament further scrutiny of this—and it is in some respects, in its design, a little controversial—system of requiring, of compelling, young unemployed Australians to work for the dole.

The least we can do is insist on this amendment. Are you going to tell me that this government, with its appalling record on job creation, is going to go to a double dissolution on the wider issue of whether there should be a two‐year evaluation time frame for this scheme? Of course, they are not. It is silly for Labor to back down on this one important amendment which actually reflects the Prime Minister's words. It holds the government to a trial which would be evaluated and requires the government to come back to the parliament before they can extend the principle of work for the dole indefinitely at a time when it suits them electorally.

That is what we are doing. That is what we are being asked to do in the chamber today—to give them the blank cheque as usual. It is not good enough. This is not a costly amendment and it is not an amendment that would hamper the government. It is an amendment that requires appropriate scrutiny.

While Labor might like to argue about labour market programs and their amendments related to those, the fact is that this is an amendment that they should be willing to insist upon as well because they, too, professed concerns—and serious concerns—about the capacity of this legislation to be misapplied in the future. It is very disappointing that Labor will not join other senators in this place in insisting on this important amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pretty pass we have come to in this place! Last week, there was a defiant expostulation by Labor, the Democrats, the Greens and the Independents on the need for a review of this draconian piece of legislation, which vindictively picks out young people in this country who cannot get a job, not because they are unable to work or do not want to but because as a society and, in particular, due to government policy, there are no jobs for them to take. So 10,000 people are going to be picked out of the 810,000 unemployed in this country and told, `If you don't take this job, you're going to have any sustenance, your right to unemployment benefits, taken away from you.'

SPEECH.PARA: The young people are going to be selected in areas of high unemployment—regional areas of Australia. It is not going to be for the North Shore; it is not going to be for Kooyong. This is going to be for people in the western suburbs. People in regional Australia are going to be picked out at the combined whim of the government and, a little further down the line—mark you my words—private employment agencies, which are there for profit and which are going to want to get long‐term unemployed people off their books. They will flick them into a compulsory work for the dole scheme and, if they default, they will lose all income. As a result, at the end of the day, there will be a twofold disbenefit coming out of this, if you leave aside the feelings of those people caught in this trap.

Firstly, we are going to have people without income in this country. We are going to have young, active, energetic and disillusioned young people feeling the fair go has passed them by. In fact, by law they have been cut out of it in a lottery system that is beyond their control, because for other people next door who are also long-term unemployed this does not affect them. These people are selected by processes unknown to them to participate in a forced work program which gives them no skilling and no long-term prospects of a job, but which picks on them in a vindictive way for a little bit of gratuitous punishment to feed the feelings of disgruntled people paying taxes.

There are a few wowsers and mingy people in our society who feel they have to punish somebody because they do not like paying taxes, even in a country with high unemploy ment. They pick on some young people who have little ability to fight back and make them work in very often nonproductive and certainly not fulfilling jobs for a period of time as an example to the rest of society.

If those young people fall out of the welfare net, they are going take to the streets. We are going to see more locks on doors. We are going to see more people begging in the streets. We are going to see an increase in panhandling, as the Americans call it. We are going to see people unable to enjoy the security that Australia has valued in the past, because we are going to see increasing crime as a result of forced work of this variety being imposed on young people who are not at fault. The fault lies with our society and with governments, but we have not got the nous and the wherewithal to bring in programs which are going to ensure a better spread of work and a better opportunity for all Australians to work.

As Senator Harradine said yesterday or the day before, people have a right to access unemployment benefits when society cannot provide the jobs to go round. But instead of a right here, we have a punishment. It is ethically wrong. It is morally wrong. It is bankrupt. It is vindictive. It is nasty. It stands against this nation's ethos of a fair go.

Secondly, it is going to displace people out of proper full pay jobs with proper conditions. That is the overseas experience. Let me reiterate that in New York there are some 36,000 people on forced work schemes like this and it is estimated that they have replaced over 20,000 full-time jobs. The people who worked in parks, street cleaning and secretarial jobs on full pay and proper benefits have been replaced by people on forced work schemes who are living on a minimal wage—the dole wage it will be in Australia.

The opinion polls might at first reaction have shown that a majority of Australians favour this scheme, but there has been precious little public debate about it. I have seen nothing from those people who are going to be targeted. I have seen no case put by them. They do not even know who they are yet and they are certainly not going to have an opportunity to speak up in their defence as this vindictive scheme—now backed by Labor and the Democrats—comes into being.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is misleading.

—Senator Kernot says that that is misleading, but let me say this. Last week, the rot set in here when the Democrats voted against Labor amendments which would have enabled work skilling to be put into this program, which would have insisted that there be a skilling component in these forced work schemes.

SPEECH.PARA: In a tit for tat, the Labor big boys got together on the weekend and yesterday morning and decided here was their out. The Democrats blocked provisions to ensure that skilling be brought into this program so at least these forced labourers would have some chance of getting a job afterwards. Labor said, `We will drop our opposition to compulsion. We will support these young people being made to work in this vindictive fashion.' While the two parties of social justice bickered with each other, the government got the rails run on this and got through.

TALK.START.PARA: —We didn't even talk to each other.
—Senator Kernot says, `We didn't talk to each other.' Do you know why?
—That's right.
—Order! Senator Kernot!
—She is getting upset about this—
—Because you are lying. You are lying!
—Order! Senator Kernot!
—You know why she is doing it—
—On a point of order, Madam Chairman: as you know, what Senator Kernot has just said is unparliamentary. I ask that she withdraw it.
—Senator Kernot, would you please withdraw.
—On the point of order, Madam Chairman: I will withdraw after I make this statement.
—Unconditional withdrawal, thank you, Senator Kernot.
—I unconditionally withdraw. May I continue?
—No, you were asked to unconditionally withdraw.
—May I make a statement at the end, because I have already spoken on this debate?
—You may speak later.

—Senator Kernot can get upset about this, but she is not half as upset as I am. There are people out there who do not have a voice, who deserve to have Senator Kernot and the Labor Party sticking up for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I moved in the committee stage that we report progress while these two parties got together and solved this problem on behalf of the unemployed people who were going to be targeted. As you will remember, Senator Margetts and I went alone to the other side of the chamber and were voted down by Labor, by the Democrats and by the conservative parties voting in unison to bring in this work for the dole scheme. That is where we are at.

It is the Greens versus the rest on this score whereas we all stood on this side last week to amend this legislation so that there would be a skilling program that was not compulsory—something that was constructive for unemployed people in this country; something that meant this money was going to be put to a productive purpose with young people being fulfilled as a result of it. They had the option to go into this scheme and to get some skilling while they were at it, small as it might be—a little step towards constructive assistance for those people who have drawn the short straw in this country and who cannot get a job, simply because successive government policies have led to an unemployment rate of over eight per cent.

It is a pretty low day for the other opposition parties that we have come to this. But what about the great Labor Party, the party of social justice, which went belly‐up yesterday, caved in to the government and was prepared to use the young people unemployed in this country, who cannot stand up for themselves, as fodder in their backdown because they were concerned about the political outcome? What a low day! What a depth for the Labor Party to come to—this party of social justice, which should be standing for these very people who cannot stand up for themselves. Did they hit rock bottom? Did the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, and his party hit the bottom of the barrel yesterday?

Are they going to repeat that today when they cave in even further on a simple amendment from the Democrats, which we backed and which says, `At least have a sunset clause in this. Let us have a review of where it goes further down the line.' But, belly‐up, the Labor Party says, `No, we can't even stand up for the disadvantaged in this country to the point where we would think about having a review two years down the line.' What a disgrace the Labor Party has become! What hollowness there is to those words of social justice which this once‐great Labor Party is supposed to stand for. It strikes me that it is more persistent and has far greater vigour in this place when standing for the multinational corporations on issues like the $800 million handout in diesel fuel rebates to the mining corporations than it has for those people who are living on the poverty line in this country.

It is a disgraceful backdown. It is shocking. You—through you, Madam Chair—should be ashamed of yourselves. The Labor Party has hit a new low. It does not deserve to be the opposition, and it has abandoned the very people it should be standing up for in this matter. There is not a political argument that can justify this contempt for the very people you would have us believe that you stand for—the very people that you have abandoned and the very people that you have welshed on. You have sold out in this infamous little exercise in political retreat, double backflip and abandonment of principle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the Senate that, as the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, indicated in the House of Representatives last night, the opposition will not be opposing the bill in the form that it has been returned from the House of Representatives. Hence we will be supporting the government's motion before the chair.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the opposition is concerned, we are going to end once and for all the charade that this government has been running for a long time to divert attention from its complete failure to tackle unemployment in Australia. When the government's bill was introduced in the House of Representatives, the Labor Party vigorously pursued a number of amendments, and the government now has to answer for its own rhetoric. We tried to transform this ill‐considered proposal into a comprehensive quality training and skill based labour market program but, of course, those amendments were defeated by the government's numbers.

Soon after the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced the scheme, which I think was in February, we also acted to refer the bill to a Senate committee for detailed examination and community consultation. Several public hearings of the committee were held, and a substantial minority report was published by opposition senators on the committee, which has clearly put on record our concerns about the flaws in this bill. When the bill reached the Senate, the Labor Party again moved amendments to turn the bill into a proper labour market program with firm guarantees that it would not lead to the displacement of existing paid workers. However, unfortunately, the Australian Democrats and Senator Colston voted with the government to defeat those crucial amendments.

When I foreshadowed last week that the Labor Party would move in the Senate to amend the government's work for the dole scheme, that was in the context of submitting our decent training and skills programs, which were also compulsory but, unlike the government scheme, offered real choice and opportunities. We will not let the government divert attention from its failure to create real jobs by running a nasty and divisive campaign to blame the victims of unemployment, and that has been our intention all along.

Jobs will be the issue in the next election—not manipulating community prejudices against those who cannot get jobs, nor the side issue of whether some individuals should or should not be compelled into work. The fact is that the 10,000 places in the government's work for the dole scheme, with no training, do not even match the number of real jobs lost under this government in just one week in May this year. We on the Labor side made it clear early in this debate that we would be presenting a clear and better alternative to the work for the dole scheme. We also made it clear that, if the government did not accept this alternative, it would have to wear the consequences of its flawed scheme.

We presented our alternative, but the most essential features of that have been rejected. So, as Mr Beazley said last night, it is the government that has to wear the consequences of its mickey mouse scheme. There cannot be any more smokescreens. We are acting to make sure that the focus, starting from today and running right up until the next election, stays fairly and squarely on the government and on the job crisis that the government has created in this country and that is mounting by the month.It will soon become apparent that the criticisms that we have clearly put on the record, our criticisms of the work for the dole scheme, are valid. We will be rigorously monitoring the operation of this scheme as part of our efforts to expose the government's lack of real solutions to unemployment.

The Australian people will now be able to see even more clearly that the government does not care about solving unemployment and that the work for the dole scheme is doing nothing to help. This will enable people to vote for an alternative, to vote for the party which will do most to tackle unemployment. Our policy initiatives in the months ahead will make it even clearer that it is Labor, not the Howard government, which is regarded as the most competent party to tackle unemployment in this country.

As I have indicated, Labor senators will not be opposing the motion before the chair because we want to ensure that the focus of the unemployment debate from now on is on the government's failure to deliver on job security for all Australians, and in order for us to open up the debate on real solutions to unemployment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I could rehash all the arguments that were presented in this chamber over the last few days, but I am not going to do that because what is before us is a specific proposition. Suffice to say that I do not want to wax eloquent about those matters because I feel rather sick in the stomach about what happened here yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now in a situation whereby we are being asked by the government not to insist upon the amendment that was adopted by the Senate. That amendment provides for a two‐year sunset clause. Why did we amend the legislation thus? Because we were dealing with a trial. Surely, in anybody's language, a trial must have a sunset. It must come to an end; otherwise it is not a trial. It must be evaluated; otherwise it is not a trial. In my view, we should reject the government's proposition that we not insist upon our amendment. I think it is reasonable that we should insist upon the amendment. If we do that, then it puts the government on notice that it has got to come back with a very thorough report on the efficacy or otherwise of the trial. I will be voting against the motion which is before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have seen in the last couple of days has been cynical, sleazy politics. The structural unemployment from which Australia is suffering is at what is called an economic up‐point; we are still at the point of growth. If we should find, for instance, that stock markets crash or that other potential international events occur, then instead of the rate of unemployment being at around nine per cent, it could go to 15 per cent or worse. It is at a high at nine per cent. But here we are, blaming unemployed people.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party said the government must answer for its own rhetoric. No—it is the victims of structural unemployment who will suffer. This unemployment has been created by political and economic decision making. Structural unemployment is not choice unemployment; it is structural unemployment. Commentators would all agree that what we are suffering from is structural unemployment, not unemployment by choice. There is always a small percentage of choice, but that is not what Australia is suffering from at the moment.

We know, because we have figures and we have reports, that the people who are already finding it most difficult to cope are those people who are most likely to be hived off into these schemes. They are not for everybody. It will be decided. It is not across the board. It will be, and is, discriminatory.

Yesterday Senator Brown offered to remove the excuse between Labor and the Democrats. Senator Kernot said today that they have not met and talked about it. That is not good enough for this issue. Yesterday the excuse was removed and we said, `Take the time and talk about this issue.' If it was simply a ploy by the Labor Party, this is the time to remove that excuse. However—

TALK.START.PARA: —They were going to change their mind, weren't they!

—If Senator Kernot is saying they were not going to change their minds, at least that would have revealed the fact that they had no intention of sorting through this issue. Instead of allowing that excuse to be removed from Labor, we have a situation where the ability to talk that very important issue through did not take place.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a tiff going by. It might not be a tiff behind closed doors, but perhaps we could call it a tiff in the gallery. Perhaps we could call this the `spin tiff', which is going to fall over and affect thousands of people in Australia—not necessarily those people who say, `Yes, I would like the government to provide me with meaningful work. I don't want to be sitting around twiddling my thumbs and feeling my life is worthless.' What is the government actually going to provide for those people who really want to do something worth while with their life? What kind of funding does the government provide for those people?

If any government were so sure about their own program being sound, so sure that it is not going to target the wrong people, so sure that it will lead to positive outcomes, then how could they refuse to review the program in two years time? No, they do not want to do it, and now the rest of the chamber, it seems, will not have the numbers to even look at this program two years down.

Perhaps it is going to have to be another public debate, provided that the populist debate has not gone even further to a point where the only growth industry in our society is that of private prisons to lock up the people that we will have made enemies of by that time—mostly our young people, especially Aboriginal young people. Growth industry—private prisons: that is where we are going to in this country. And I am indicating that I will be insisting on this amendment. I am just dreadfully sorry that the Senate did not have the guts to stand up on other issues in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to go back to the fact that I was asked to withdraw my interjection. I think it is the first time I have had to do that. I want to put on the record that I am pretty sick and tired of the moral high ground lectures from Senator Brown, from the man who in March 1996 conducted one of the most unethical and dishonest election campaigns ever—
—Senator Kernot, I think you might have to withdraw that.
—Which part?
—`Unethical and dishonest'.
—I do not think that `dishonest' is unparliamentary, is it, Mr Chairman?
—`Unethical and dishonest' in that connotation has to be withdrawn.
—Sorry? Do I have to withdraw both? May I use `dishonest'?
—No, not in respect of the senator.
—It's not; it's conduct. Anyway, I sought advice before I made that statement. I acknowledge that nobody knew exactly what I was saying, but I sought advice. Okay, I with—

SPEECH.PARA: May I have a ruling?

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, Senator Kernot, you cannot use either of those terms in relation to a particular senator.
—Okay, I will say, `an unethical election campaign'.
—Will you withdraw?

—Sorry, I thought I did. But may I rephrase it as `an unethical election campaign'? I withdraw it against the senator and apply it to the election campaign—an unethical and dishonest election campaign. I think I am allowed to say that.
—On a point of order: I am finding this quite offensive.
—You would!
—Excuse me? I ask that Senator Kernot be asked to withdraw her offensive behaviour.
—I think it is quite clear to the assembled senators, Senator Kernot, that you are referring in your rephrased form to a particular senator. That being the case, I ask you to withdraw.

—Okay, I will withdraw. While I am speaking on the second point, I will try to think of a way to rephrase the first, because I think the point is a valid one. However, I said I was sick and tired of the moral high ground lectures, and I believe that the third reading recorded vote of the Senate on this matter was also deliberately misrepresented to the press gallery at the conclusion of this debate yesterday. I challenge the capacity of Senator Brown to reflect with any veracity on any interpretation of Democrat actions. That is the point I want to get on the record now. Having said that, I would like to ask the minister: when the Prime Minister and the minister have said that this is a trial scheme—they have said that publicly many times—why is it wrong for the Senate to insist on an amendment which actually reflects the Prime Minister's and the minister's words? Why should you not be held to a trial scheme? Why should you have the capacity to apply this scheme without any further parliamentary scrutiny to extend the principle, as you call it? Why should you have that right, when you are the ones who said that this is simply a trial? Why, Minister, should you not be required to come back here and demonstrate the merits, the flaws, in the design of this system before you seek to extend the principle to others? You are the ones who said it was a trial. Why should the Senate not insist on that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is repeating the debate we had previously. These issues were raised in the debate when the matter was before the chamber earlier this week. I made it perfectly clear then that the principle of the work for the dole scheme is appropriate to be in this legislation, come what may.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that we are implementing a pilot program does not say, `Yea, we will go on to further programs afterwards' or `Nay, we will not.' The pilot program stands on its own. The implementation of the principle in the legislation also stands on its own. It is perfectly appropriate for the government to want to amend the social security legislation to allow for that principle to be enshrined in the legislation.

We put a lot of requirements on people who are asking for social security income support in various ways throughout the legislation. There has been no requirement about compulsorily working for the dole, but there have been lots of other requirements which have also been compulsory. We are moving now, in a way which is consistent with countries around the world, to require flexible activity testing and a variety of ways that we can activity test people who ask for assistance from the taxpayer.

I do not want to prolong this debate any longer. Anybody who is interested in this issue is going to be able to read the whole Hansard of days of debate. Let it be quite clear, however, for those who do not know, that the question of evaluation has also been thoroughly examined in this place. There will be substantial evaluation by the department in time for the next budget and then in the second phase late next year. That has all been explained to the Senate; I do not want to go into more detail now. It simply only adds to the time delay.

However, in addition, as I think I pointed out to you, Senator Kernot—it might have been to one of the other opposition parties—it is very clear that at any time the Senate chooses, they are able to evaluate any program of the federal government. Whether it is in this portfolio or in any other, the numbers in the Senate make it perfectly possible for the Senate to choose at any time to evaluate any program. So I think the grandstanding you have just been going on with does not become you. You have been told all that already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Me thinketh the honourable senator protesteth too much. I am not going to respond to Senator Kernot, because the issue that is so important here is the plight of the young people who are going to be targeted by this compulsory scheme which has no training component, which does nothing to get them back into the work force, which simply sees them as a punishment vehicle for a pretty debased, vindictive streak that there is amongst a minority of people who think that people out of work should be punished, not given the opportunity to enjoy the advantages, including the fulfilment of life, that come out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: Honestly! The Labor Party are saying that they are going to support the government on this, because the government is going to stand indicted further down the line and they are going to go to the next election tackling the government over a measure which they are now supporting. What sort of twisted logic is that? What sort of hopeless attempt is that to excuse the inexcusable? The Labor Party is now supporting the work for the dole scheme and is ensuring that the government even gets its way on the Democrats' amendment to ensure that there is a review further down the line. Labor apparently does not even want a review on this iniquitous little piece of legislation which is going to have such appalling—

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had any kids who were unemployed, you'd understand it.

—Here we have got Senator Herron defending the Labor position. That is where we have got to. It is going to be interesting to see the final vote in this place. What we do know from what has happened this morning is that the Labor Party has given up its right to be called the party of social justice. That has become a much more confined thing in this parliament. I suppose it is one of those key points, one of those watersheds, one of those telling moments in the direction of our society, which is now so broadly affected by economic fundamentalism, which has no room for finer feelings, for ethics that Senator Kernot is concerned about, or for concern for others. Rather, we are prosecuting quarrels amongst ourselves. We ought to be able to do better than that in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, the whole problem arose because the two bigger opposition parties on this side could not get together and come to a mutual agreement to support each other's amendments in this place. Instead of that they fell apart and allowed the government through with a rails run, which is going to trample over the rights and even the aspirations to long-term work of young people, who are simply going to be seen as an expedient whipping group for the more venal and small‐minded and vindictive aspirations of a few people in our society who, unfortunately, tend to be concentrated in the support base of the parties opposite.

Senator KERNOT (Queensland—Leader of the Australian Democrats) (1.11 p.m.) I think there are a couple of disingenuous statements being made. It is disingenuous of Senator Brown to suggest that, when the Labor Party have made up their mind to bail out of an action, representation by the Democrats can change it, can change their mind when they have taken this particular decision, and I think in some respects it has been a damaging decision. When they have made up their mind, no entreaty from me or any other Democrat, I can assure you, Senator Brown, is going to persuade them.

We know why this decision was made. We are all capable of understanding that. It is disingenuous for you to reflect that the Demo crats could have gone to the Labor Party and saved this bill. Once Labor made up its mind, that was the end of it and we know that.

I ask the minister: is it not disingenuous of you, Minister, to argue that a trial is a trial, even if it is unlimited? How can you argue that? You are asking the parliament to give you the unlimited right to do this. What is the point of a trial, except for you to get your own evaluation? How can you argue that it is a trial? Why do you not just say, `We are enshrining the principle and that is that. And on the way we are going to conduct our own evaluation.'? But it is not a trial any more. It is the permanent right to compel all unemployed Australians to work for their unemployment benefits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —The contributions that we received from the Democrats and the Greens are simply a repeat of their contributions in the debate over recent days, enlivened for the rest of us, I guess, by the spat that they have had between themselves.
—Did you enjoy it?
—Well, did you?
—I wouldn't have said I enjoyed it.

—I did not either. I just said `enlivened'. Labor has now made a pathetic attempt to justify its somersault. By any other name, it is a somersault. No‐one is fooled, Senator Faulkner, by your explanations. You are clearly a poll driven, directionless rabble. No-one forgets that it was you who handed over an economy in a mess and with thousands and thousands and thousands of Australians out of work.

SPEECH.PARA: The work for the dole scheme is a very sensible initiative which has the specific purpose of lifting the self-esteem of young unemployed Australians. That is how it is understood from around Australia. The country understands. The regions understand. People who work with young people understand how desperately some of our long-term unemployed young people need a confidence boost, how they need the satisfaction that comes from having achieved something.

BREAK.PARA: The government is pleased to deliver a sensible initiative which will enable young unemployed Australians to participate in worthwhile programs, designed by their communities, that will lift their self-esteem, will give them confidence and satisfaction in what they have achieved and will give them some hope for their future. There has been a great deal of populism from those opposite during this debate and Australia deserves better. I commend this important measure to the chamber.
Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid the catcalling from down the far end of the chamber is just that.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Newman's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had agreed to amendment No. 9 made by the Senate and disagreed to the remaining amendments made by the Senate to the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 and requesting the reconsideration of the bill in respect of the said amendments.
Motion (by Senator Minchin) proposed:
That the message be considered in committee of the whole forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking against the motion. I assume this is a motion that the matter be dealt with immediately.
—Correct.
—This is news to me. If they want to go and deal with it immediately, good on them.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.
Ordered that further consideration of the message in committee of the whole be adjourned until a later hour this day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Herron, at the request of Senator Campbell) proposed:
That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the following bills, allowing them to be considered during this period of sittings:
Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill 1997
Commonwealth Motor Vehicles (Liability) Amendment Bill 1997
Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997
Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to the government yesterday that there are four bills in the list—two of them are about the sale of cars, one is about telecommunications and one is about higher education. The only one that the Greens (WA) would agree to exempt from the cut‐off motion is the telecommunications bill. The other three do not have our agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no urgency for rushing towards providing a subsidy for private car producers. That is what it is basically. It means that they are exempt and somehow or other there is this false level playing field which means that somehow private fleet owners are treated like government entities.

The other bill in relation to higher education, in my opinion, is not urgent. It certainly is not urgent to provide measures which end up being punitive in the medium to longer term on education. My understanding is that this could be done in the next session in the normal turn of events. It is not until next year that the government will try to do these horrible things to students.

Basically, the only bill upon which you have agreement from the Greens (WA) in relation to urgency, which is what we are being asked to deal with today—let alone non‐controversiality, which I guess we will have to deal with again later—is the telecommunications bill. That is the meaning of the words in relation to the standing orders and that is all that I believe fits into their definition.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Senator Minchin:
That these bills be now read a second time.
upon which Senator Sherry had moved by way of amendment:
At the end of the motion, add:
"but the Senate notes that the Budget:
(a) does nothing for jobs—the nation's most overwhelming current economic and social problem;

(b) squanders, by breaking the promise to introduce superannuation co-contributions, an historic opportunity to build a massive new private savings pool, and does so in a way that undercuts decent retirement incomes for lower and middle income earners;
(c) continues the assault on families, the elderly and the needy;
(d) contains many mindless and counter-productive cuts affecting the quality and decency of life in Australia, and harming our international reputation;

(e) for all its cuts and destructive impact, did not meet the exaggerated expectations the Government had created as to the size of its deficit reduction achievements and projected future surpluses; and
(f) has been characterised by even the Government's best friends as lacking in shape, direction and vision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This year's budget was actually far worse than it was generally portrayed. Last year there was the big announcement of the black hole into which government would consign the community sector. There were some nasty taxes on students, the young, the old, migrants and the perennial target of this government—Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. But it was just the beginning. A lot of the debt reduction was based on announcements that government would sell Telstra, the airports, Commonwealth car fleet and various other mobile and immobile assets—everything including those things which had been bolted down, I guess. There was a huge attack on workers but that did not increase revenue.

SPEECH.PARA: But the real poison in the bottom of this chalice was not last year's budget; it was the forward estimates. For example, last year it was estimated that, in the budget year, higher education grants would stay nominally about the same, a decline in real terms of about three per cent, but that this year they would be cut by 6.3 per cent in dollar terms, or 9.5 per cent in real terms. In this budget they were actually cut by 5.6 per cent in dollar terms or 10 per cent in real terms. That can be taken as the base data. It was not a budget measure and deserved no real attention. It was not a change because it was announced last year. There was nothing in the budget measure statement that said that $240 million would be lopped from this area.

Likewise, when the increase in TAFE funding of 2.8 per cent is below inflation, this is not noteworthy. It is according to last year's plan. Actually, it is a cut from last year's forward estimates which indicated TAFE funding would increase by 4.8 per cent. It seems that this government has been learning from the methods of the last government in terms of the way it presents accounts. Next year's forward estimates indicate that there will be an increase of only 0.6 per cent while inflation is expected to be up to 4.5 per cent. Public primary and secondary school funding increased one per cent in dollar terms, a decrease of 3.5 per cent in real terms. Next year is about the same. The year following, 1990‐2000, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) hedged his bet by suggesting primary education is only set to increase by 0.8 per cent in dollar terms.

In health, veterans' health and general practice reforms in rural incentives programs all go down in real or dollar terms. The preventative health area, the area that deals with vaccinations, women's health, AIDS, drug strategies, family planning and youth suicide prevention was cut by 11 per cent in dollar terms, 15.6 per cent in real terms. Next year, it will go down another 17 per cent in dollar terms or 22.7 per cent in real terms. It has been cut from $293 million last year to $215 million in 1998-99.

Health support services, the blood banks and so on, get cut by four per cent in this budget. Health research was not hit this year, but have a look at the forward estimates. Next year it is pegged to drop by 14.3 per cent and the year after by 14.1 per cent. This is a huge drop but totally consistent with the government's attitude on research generally and on social welfare specifically.

The big targets in health for this budget were doctors who bulk‐bill, and those patients who have chronic illnesses such as heart and circulatory disease and those with emotional and mental health problems requiring ongoing medication. The new pharmaceutical scheme is also likely to affect those requiring multiple antibiotics, those with diseases like multiple resistant TB—the disease of the growing urban poor—and those hospitalised and therefore exposed to staph aureus and other such infections.

The undermining of ordinary Medicare by refusing to increase Medicare fees sets the stage for the abandonment of bulk‐billing. I would say cynically that this is the intention of government. Health care will become just like education—free in theory but in actuality a movable feast of free and fee, with the fee component becoming bigger each year. For those who are not actually unemployed or on a pension, gone is the time you could find a doctor who bulk‐billed. Soon, even those who are card carrying poor will not be able to find such treatment. The outcome will be that the poor simply stop getting treatment with a consequent reduction in health. It will particularly affect the young, those with poor parents and the old who did not expect a pension to have to cover a growing range of medical costs.

We also see the spectre of community sector punishment. I put it as three stages—the government gets them to shut up, cutback and shut down. That is what I believe. It says, `Stop talking; stop speaking out; and when you have lost the ability to speak out for yourself, then we get rid of you.' That is what is happening and it is happening more and more. My advice is, don't keep quiet; at least go noisily. It will make a difference of only one year, in my opinion, for those community groups who are doing a good job. If they are quiet, it will mean perhaps they will be forgiven for an extra year, but they will go in the end.

BREAK.PARA: It is dumb. It is very bad economic and social policy because, in the end, it is the community support groups in self‐help and preventative areas who end up stopping the crisis spending in education, in social issues and in health. It is the community groups who are extremely good value. Cutting from them is false economy.

In summary, most of the real erosion of universal social services occurred as forward estimates and so warrants no attention in budget papers. Even if it warrants attention, it gets none. Such major cuts are in the forward estimates for the next two years. The slashing and burning is being done quietly, behind the scenes, so to speak. We all know it is happening, but it is hard to address since there is no legislation for these cuts—none save these bills, the appropriation bills. Senator Brown and I have some amendments to this legislation, and I will speak to mine presently.

Last year we had the bill that would bust unions, and workplace relations, and was designed to make workers more helpless in negotiation, exchanging collective bargaining for direct negotiations between each worker and management. This year, the government is working on increasing the number of unemployed—making their situation as grim as possible to ensure that, when workers are negotiating, the only possible option to accepting whatever an employer offers is poverty, a steady reduction of any assets they might retain and a hopeless choice of involuntary servitude or starving on the streets. This is not a training program—and we have just had this debate—work for the dole is punishment for unemployment.

As part of the general worsening of the lot of the poor, in real terms we have declining budgets for the aged, disabled veterans, the unemployed and the sick. We also have budgets which decline in both real and dollar terms for veterans, the non‐veteran disabled, parents, pregnant women, widows, Australian victims of disasters and asylum seekers.

There is a planned major targeting of those on welfare, with the object of increasing penalty income by 26.4 per cent. It is not so much that there are rorts; this is a budget‐driven policy and a lot of it is accomplished when the payments are made. The fact that the government plans to make so much money out of it indicates the payments will be later, leaving those poor enough to meet government tests waiting.

But the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has answers. Not long ago we saw him in a factory boasting of how the production of fighter planes may not replace all the jobs lost in the BHP steel closure but that it would go a long way. Personally, I do not think Australia's future is in the production of weaponry. It is a very inefficient way of using our resources, whether it is subs or fighters or Styer rifles or even trip‐wire grenades that are not really grenades, although they do tend to blow off people's legs reasonably effectively.

One of our amendments is to reduce the level of spending on war toys to last year's level. As an example, the funding for higher education grants, for which the Commonwealth paid $3.906 billion last year and proposes to pay $3.690 billion this year, is to be cut by $216 million. But the budget for defence equipment went from approximately the same base of $3.945 billion to $4.134 billion—an increase of $198 million, according to budget paper No. 1. I propose to eliminate division 183, defence production. That is a cost saving of $17.8 million. This is money we spend on promoting the sale of arms overseas and other issues involved with that immoral trade.

Frankly—and I know that this is a point of disagreement with government—I believe that there are many things that would do more for the nation than buying or selling war toys. Education is one option. Preventative health is another. Reversing the decrease in the housing budget is yet another. There are hundreds of cuts that look minor, though they are substantial cuts to specific programs.

My point is simply that it is indicative of government priorities when they are cutting social services in almost every sector because of dire economic news, but they are increasing the budget for war toys. I cannot understand why the most up-to-date capacity to kill people is so much more important than providing wellbeing for our friends, our children, our parents, our brothers, and our sisters.

I also point out that I have, many times, indicated other areas where the government, if it had the will, could reduce expenditure or increase revenue, without damaging the poor. I have suggested that the diesel rebate to mining could be cut, bringing in at least $800 million. The government cries `Jobs'. But it has no worries about cutting in other areas that cost jobs, such as manufacturing, computers or information technology, education, and so on—and in government service provision.

If the government wished to do so, I have indicated several areas in which it could increase revenue through taxing the rich. It could set a level of taxation below which corporate taxes could not be minimised. It could reduce the level of dividend imputation to 50 per cent, since corporations do not pay their full tax. It could eliminate a lot of the rorts around negative gearing. We also suggested a way by eliminating deductions for salary sacrifice through superannuation.

If it wanted to, government could easily do a huge amount for the environment by putting a carbon tax on energy. This could raise up to $7 billion per year—enough to substantially convert coal-fired power to wind and solar; enough to develop sophisticated systems for ensuring that most of the country's freight be transported by rail or sea; enough to substantially support energy efficiency, and to make a good start on restructuring cities. This is not, and it need not be, a painful thing.

A restructured urban environment and transport system would allow better and cheaper access to transport, while increasing equity and amenity—and employment. Life could be better, and we would not need to import oil, as we do now. We then would be relatively immune to many resource price shocks that we are likely to see. We would also probably develop competitive industries.
We could do a lot. But this government suffers from a failure of imagination and vision. Most of all, it suffers from a failure of empathy, sympathy and compassion.

I will not at this point put forward any specific transfers for my amendment, except for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. My amendment removes the excuse for some of the pettiest, mean‐spirited cuts that this government in this budget has introduced. This government clearly is working in every way it can to unravel the fabric of the community and return us to some sort of competitive economic jungle. This will quickly become a real urban jungle with physical predators, if the evidence from the rest of the world has any parallels here.

Therefore, it is interesting that one of the organisations it wishes to cut is the human rights watchdog. Twenty per cent of the budget is gone this year. Our amendment would restore that. It is not a lot, nor is it the only thing we need to maintain. But it is an indicative item. It is a focus item. It is the organisation most at risk from the ideology of this government, which seems hell‐bent on making sure that minorities and those most vulnerable get it in the neck. If enough insecurity has been created for everyone primarily to be concerned with their own skin and those most vulnerable are sacrificed, who will care? That is what scapegoat politics stems from.

This government goes one better. It tries to paint the vulnerable as non-humans, rorters, sly thieves or dole bludgers. They paint Aboriginal communities as having advantages over non-Aboriginal communities. They paint migrants as those who come to this country, wanting to live off the cream of our work. They paint students as those who make trouble and want handouts, instead of working for what they get. Does this all sound familiar? There are `young ingrate teenagers, who have nothing better to do than sit around and get drunk'; `old people, who are a burden on an ageing society'; `women, gays and the disabled, who think being victims gives them special rights'. No wonder the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) finds fertile ground where this government has spread its compost.

The human rights commission is one of those organisations which will be decimated, according to forward estimates. In budget paper No. 1, protection of human rights declines from $19.3 million last year to $17.8 million this year; in appropriations we see that it is actually a bigger decline. But in the budget papers we see that the decline is set to markedly increase, down to only $11.8 million. In other words, the funding for HREOC is about to be cut by nearly 50 per cent.

I believe that this is disgraceful, and so I put this as an indicative amendment. It is not a lot. Obviously I will be speaking briefly to this amendment when it comes up in the committee stage of the bill. But I do commend our concerns to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly today because I am aware of time constraints in this particular debate. I just want to canvass a few things. In particular, the budget itself was a nothing budget. It did nothing for the unemployed, it did nothing for families, it did nothing for the elderly—and, of course, it did nothing for small business. All we have as a result, now, of two budgets from this current government is a flat economy, suffering retail sales and people in a certain amount of despair.

SPEECH.PARA: People are scared to spend for fear of loss of jobs, and this leads to great insecurity in their lives. Jobs are the main issue and they hardly rate a mention in the budget brought down by the government. People want to have real jobs, not pretend jobs. They want security, and this government is not providing it.

I want to focus for a few minutes on what I consider to be the biggest blunder of the budget: the savings incentive scheme. This offered nothing to battlers who live from hand to mouth. It destroyed the concept of security in retirement by cutting a swathe through superannuation. There is no doubt that it has provided a barrier to super reaching 15 per cent, as it would have done under a Labor government. However, the 15 per cent barrier needed to be reached so that it would make certain a relevant and meaningful retirement package for those people when they reach retirement age. This is the very least that this budget has done for those people. Now those people will find themselves with their superannuation stuck at a high of nine per cent— clearly a level which is not sufficient for them to fund their retirement.

The second thing that came out of the savings incentive scheme was the ability for the opting out for those people who earn less than $450 per month between the award superannuation and the SG amount. This does not do one thing for the retirement savings of those people. If anything, it substantially diminishes their savings. In the future, it could diminish their savings by up to six per cent—that is, the difference between award super being three per cent and the SG amount being nine per cent. These two initiatives of the government in the budget, which fell completely flat on its face, did nothing for the battlers that they so much pretended to represent on the occasion of their election. The government's saving program was a total insult to low income workers. It does nothing to improve their life or their lifestyle.

Having made those few brief remarks, I want to turn briefly to the Senate estimates committee report of June 1997. In that particular report there was an addendum by Senator Cook and me. It raises concerns about the estimates process. During the estimates process, our particular estimates committee, the addendum report states, was delayed from commencing from 9 a.m. to 1.30 p.m. on 10 June because no minister was available. I understand that ministers are busy from time to time, but if the process is to operate and to operate properly for all parties, if there is a commitment that the estimates will start at 9 a.m. on a certain day, we need a minister to be available. If we do not have a minister available, it certainly delays the process and it makes the whole functioning and operation of that estimates committee fairly difficult indeed.

On two occasions during that particular set of estimates we failed to have the minister present. The minister left for some commitments unknown to me as to what they exactly were. Again, that left us in a real dilemma. It made the process of the estimates difficult indeed. There was no minister present to comment on matters of policy. What we were able to traverse with the public servants were matters of fact in the budget estimates and the PBS, and that is quite right. But we needed a minister there to be able to traverse issues of policy. That was not made available to us, because on those two occasions the minister was absent. That was from about 9 o'clock at night, and the rest of us had to spend time in the estimates until 11 o'clock or 12 o'clock on those two occasions.

Nonetheless, it is important that the government realise that, if this process is to work, they must have a minister there. Otherwise we could end up going down the road of the committee of the whole. As I understand it, that is not the desired process to be followed for the estimates process. I think the government need to get their act together and to ensure that, when estimates are on, we have ministers present so that they can answer questions of policy relating to the PBS.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —There are several matters I want to discuss in relation to schools and to disability services in this year's appropriation bills. The first relates to the youth allowance or the removal altogether of unemployment benefits for people aged 16 and 17 who are not in school or in other training. Like so many of the government's announcements over the past 12 months, this came, as it were, from the hip without any consideration about the effects of the proposal on our schools.

SPEECH.PARA: We know there are more than 34,000 young Australians who are not employed and not in education or training. The Democrats are in favour of young people staying on in school until they have completed year 12 or moved on to other training. We are absolutely in favour of that as an objective. Every indicator of success in later life points to education. We continue to draw attention to the declining retention rates in virtually all states in this country.

However, the reality is that for most of these young people they have left school because it no longer serves their needs. They do not see any point in staying on. When I went through secondary school, these young people left at year 10 to become mechanics, plumbers, secretaries or clerks. Very often they want to a tech school where the vocational link was very clear. They left school virtually at any age and they went straight into a job. The reality now is that the few jobs that are available to young people, even if they complete year 12, are extremely hard to get. Very often, they do not even use the qualifications that those students have.

As we all know, there is a much higher proportion of jobs than ever before in the service industry—casual part-time jobs as waiters, bar attendants and the like. It is very difficult to persuade young people without a decent job at the end of their 12 years of effort in school that it will be worthwhile. The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) points out that schools no longer appear to meet the needs of 75 per cent of their students who will not end up in university. This budget was the opportunity to do something about that, but it does not.

The government expects that it can force 34,000 students who have already chosen to leave school into training and back to school. Even if half that number return to school it would have an enormous impact on schools. In New South Wales alone the education department estimates that this measure would cost $59 million. Add to that the number of 15‐year‐olds who would have left school but who will now stay in full‐time education and you have the makings of a very major problem.

The minister has no answers. She does not even have any evidence that the financial incentive will shift young people back to schools or of the impact on those schools. Was this move discussed with principals, for instance? I do not think so. Her advice this week was that I should go back to schools and tell them to lift their game and start offering real opportunities to the 75 per cent of students who do not want to go to university. That was the advice to me. She said, `Give them real opportunities.'

I could speak at length here today about the sorts of initiatives that have been started for students for whom the structure and discipline of classrooms of 30 or more students are simply unsuitable. Let me start with a secondary college in Gippsland which had an outdoor education program running for students. The school acquired, through a disadvantaged schools grant, canoes, camping and abseiling gear and the like. These students benefited enormously in terms of ability, self-esteem, self-reliance, teamwork, vigorous physical exercise and the like. It sounds very good and it worked very well. The problem is that that school is now so short of funds that it cannot afford to employ an outdoor education teacher. That school is now having to fall back on the more formal subjects in classrooms. The minister for schools refers to these subjects as `core' subjects. Last year we heard a lot about the crowded curriculum in schools. We were told that there were too many unnecessary subjects. According to the minister these needed to be eliminated in our schools.

The group of students who have no desire to go to university will have to see out their time there. Many of those students have already failed to cope let alone excel in this environment. I ask the Senate to imagine how teachers and principals will cope with such students.

Going back to the story about the school in Gippsland, that outdoor education equipment which the school once used is now hired out to the local private school. This is indicative of what is going on in so many of our secondary schools.

More of these people are going to be returned to schools. People who return to education after some time in the work force usually make very good and very highly motivated students. But I ask you to consider how easy it will be for these students to cope and for the schools into which they will go—we can pretty well assume that they will be government schools—to cope with students who are there under duress. This budget does not, at least on the surface, cut funds from schools the way it does from other portfolio areas, but we have a system which is already grossly underfunded and which is waiting in fear and trepidation for the full impact of last year's states grants bill to come into effect.

BREAK.PARA: Next year the enrolment benchmark adjustment will come into play and this is the mechanism which will see the government schools pay and keep on paying for the expansion of private schools. Even if government schools hold their enrolments, in 1998 money will be taken from government school budgets to pay for the additional numbers in private schools. The natural increase in enrolments over the next four years, as we all know, is expected to be taken up by the private sector. Already we are seeing the emergence of new private schools, and many of them are moving into schools which were vacated by former government schools.

Last weekend Victoria's primary and secondary school principals held urgent meetings with the state government after the release of a report which found that a significant majority of Victoria's 1,700 principals believe that the school system has been poorly managed by government bureaucrats and has failed to deliver improved outcomes for students. It reported increased workloads, scarce resources and plummeting job satisfaction. One principal, Mr Jim Newnan, was reported in the Sunday Age as saying:
Students are now seen in terms of dollars and clients. I used to know all the kids; now I don't know any because I haven't got the time.
His school, the Princes Hill Secondary College in Carlton, had its teaching staff cut by three, from 60 to 57, even though enrolments increased by more than 20 per cent. He said:
I believe my staff have worked unreasonably hard in order to buffer the students from the effects of staff and budget cuts. The effect isn't on students; it is on staff and it's unfair.

The survey found that most primary and secondary school principals believe that inadequate resources were the cause of the system's inability to manage student problems and had led to big increases in truancy, expulsions and suspensions.

This is the system that this government wants to push to breaking point. This system, according to the minister, has to lift its collective game. The problem for schools in Victoria, and no doubt in other states, is that there have been funding cuts. In Victoria this has meant $300 million over the last four years, and 350 schools and 8,000 teachers have been lost. We are told that in this budget there will be no new cuts. I hope that that will be the case, but the real problem is what the government expects of our school system. It is the unreasonable demands that are being made on the system with the miserable funds it receives.

The real problems will emerge in the future, however. What will the enrolment benchmark adjustment do to our government school system next year? How many parents will be persuaded that the only way they can have their children in well resourced schools is to shift them to the private sector? How many parents have no such choice? How many parents with three or four children even on an average to good income can afford to exercise that choice? This budget does not deliver good news for schools.
Debate interrupted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the minister to the full bench decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which rejects the federal government's view that all industrial action outside a protected enterprise bargaining period was unlawful. Minister, has your attention been drawn to Justice Munro's finding that—and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . there is nothing in either the second reading speech or the provisions of the Act from which it should be inferred that unprotected action is per se to be treated as illegitimate to a degree that warrants it being automatically subject to direction.

Isn't it a fact that the full bench found that the parliament could have created a delineation between protected and unprotected industrial action had it so chosen? Is it the government's intention to amend the Workplace Relations Act in light of this decision?

TALK.START.PARA: —The great bulk of that question proceeds on the basis that I am aware of the decision, which I am not. I am, therefore, not in a position to tell you whether or not the—
—You're the acting leader.
—There is a logical gap in that proposition. It does not follow that because someone is in any particular capacity they spend the bulk of their time reading decisions of full benches.
—Define `acting'.
—That is what you have briefs for.

—I will answer the question in the form in which it was asked. If your question was: am I aware that the full bench made certain findings, the answer is that I am not. You asked me whether I was aware that they had distinguished between unprotected and illegitimate acts and, again, I am not.
—You have a responsibility for IR.

—You can ask me about a policy matter arising from the implications of the decision, but I am basically being asked about the legal implications. I am being asked whether I am aware of fine distinctions made by a full bench which, presumably, considered the consequences of each of these propositions before it handed down its judgment. I am more than happy to come back to you, but if you are going to ask a question on the basis that we should be spending our time reading decisions of the full bench, then you will not make much progress.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, when you do come back to us with respect to such a significant decision in the field of industrial relations, whose minister you represent in this chamber, could you also address the issue of whether any such amendments would be inconsistent with our international obligations.
—Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Alston. Minister, I refer you to point 4 of the Prime Minister's 10‐point plan which states—and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: As provided in the Wik decision, native title rights over current and former pastoral leases . . . would be permanently extinguished to the extent that those rights are inconsistent with those of the pastoralist.

Minister, isn't this statement inconsistent with the legal advice received by the government from the Attorney‐General's Department as set out in its legal practice briefing dated 20 May 1997, which states that the majority justices in the Wik decision `concluded that none of the grants necessarily extinguished all incidents of native title'? Why has the Prime Minister deliberately misled the Australian people as to the effect of this critical aspect of his 10‐point plan?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again the failing in that question is that it invites me to pass judgment on some legal advice of which you are apparently aware but of which I am not aware and on which, in any event, it would be folly to volunteer an opinion. You know that you are not even supposed to ask for legal advice under the standing orders but, putting that to one side, if the question—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question did. The question asked me whether point 4 of the 10‐point plan was inconsistent with legal advice proffered. I am not aware of the legal advice. If you want to know about that we will get you a legal assessment of that proposition in due course.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We do have a legal assessment; it comes straight from the Attorney‐General's Department. It is the inconsistency between that and point 4 of the Prime Minister's Wik plan that I am concerned about. Minister, my question to you is: why is the Prime Minister persisting with point 4 of his 10‐point plan when the advice from the Attorney‐General's Department is that the Wik decision does not clearly extinguish native title where there is an inconsistency? Why is there a conflict between what the Prime Minister is saying and the advice? How much compensation will the Australian taxpayer have to pay if the Prime Minister's 10‐point plan extinguishes native title rights that are merely suppressed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anyone is in a position to give you a quote on the amount of damages—
—Weren't you at cabinet?

—There are extraordinary propositions coming forward—that somehow cabinet has got out a calculator and made an assessment of the precise extent of the damages that might be awarded by a court in due course. The fact is, of course, that no‐one can make judgments on that other than to say that the sorts of estimates that are on the public record from people like Noel Pearson are clearly well beyond any reasonable assessment of the likelihood of damages. To the extent that you want me to pass judgment on some legal advice, which is presumably in the control of the Attorney‐General, then I am happy to come back to you on that.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason that the Prime Minister is proceeding with the Wik 10‐point plan is that it is the only way in which we can resolve a very difficult issue, one that is very much in the interests of all parties and all Australians. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the Labor Party's humiliating cave‐in today on the government's work for the dole scheme. Labor's raft of amendments, which sought to sabotage this vitally important initiative, were abandoned in the face of overwhelming community support for the scheme. Will the minister outline the opportunities and benefits for young unemployed Australians now that this bill has been passed by the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —As senators would be aware, the work for the dole scheme did pass this chamber earlier this afternoon. For that, I would like to thank the Labor Party for their humiliating backflip. A backflip, a somersault or whatever you might like to call it; that is what it is.

ANSWER.PARA: When the Prime Minister first raised the idea, the opposition were strident. Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, described it variously as an initiative `which is, in fact, a disgrace' and as `the counsel of despair and failure'. He then threatened, `We are going to amend it to blazes.' That was what they were going to do, amend it to blazes. Senator Faulkner said that work for dole is `nothing more than poll‐driven tokenism'. Martin Ferguson said, `You roll out one of the hairy chestnuts and belt the dole bludgers.'

On the important element of compulsion, we believe it is right that we can require a small number of the participants in work for the dole to enrol. But not Labor. Senator Faulkner as late as last Friday—perhaps he has forgotten—was supporting compulsion. He said:
. . . no case has been made for the inclusion of powers for compulsion in this bill. Accordingly—
he does not want to listen now—
Labor will be moving an amendment to delete the provisions of the bill which allow the secretary to compel unemployed people to participate . . .
It would be good if the Leader of the Opposition would actually listen to this. He might learn something about his own somersault.

So Mr Beazley was going to amend it to blazes. Senator Faulkner was going to amend it to remove compulsion and Senator Bolkus was adamant that the Labor Party would not be caving in. Just one week ago he said:
. . . don't expect us to bend between the first and the second vote because the principles are too important . . .
That is what Senator Bolkus said, but what did we get yesterday?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order on the question of relevance. How is it relevant that what I said in respect of the Constitutional Convention legislation fits into this minister's answer on a social security bill? She has got it all wrong—again.
—I remind the minister of the question that she is answering. If Senator Eggleston is not happy with the answer, he can follow it up.

—Mr Beazley went to jelly. That is what they do not want to hear. He capitulated, he decided to backflip and then he marched Senator Faulkner in and rolled him. We are used to that. Do you remember this headline—`The minister for getting rolled'? He has been rolled again and he is no minister any more. He is the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. It is just like the good old days.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Beazley is again displaying his utter lack of leadership. This is not just the government's view; it is also the view of some of their colleagues. Lindsay Tanner gave Mr Beazley the big backhander when he said:

. . . we must avoid becoming economically irrational, lapsing into mindless populism, recycling the policies of the 1950s and defining ourselves by what we don't like. If we adopt such a stance we will be virtually indistinguishable from Pauline Hanson in economic issues.
I can tell you he was right.

What did Mr Beazley do? He shut up the Young Turks. He does not want any new policy ideas at all, which is just what Glenn Milne said in his column recently. Glenn Milne was quoting the words of a young Labor Turk when he said:
Their life experience—a decade of running the country—
of course, the opposition frontbench here were all involved in it—
means they're washed out of new ideas.
The old orthodoxy is ready to be replaced.
They sure are.

The government is pleased that it is able to deliver a sensible initiative which will help young unemployed people, especially those who have been out of work for a long time, to get their self‐esteem back and to achieve satisfaction in what they do for their community and thereby have hope for the future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Alston, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Why, as reported in the Canberra Times on 20 June, has the Prime Minister been ignoring the voluminous material provided to him by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on the negative impact of the race debate on Australia's international standing and interests overseas? Hasn't the Prime Minister's inaction caused irreparable damage to our trade opportunities in the region, with the consequent loss of many thousands of jobs for ordinary Australians? Will the minister table all of the advice received by the Prime Minister reporting to this effect so that Australians can judge for themselves the impact of the Prime Minister's dereliction of duty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the sort of rhetoric you trot out when you want to try to make a case irrespective of the facts. The fact is that there would not be one person in Australia who is not aware of the Prime Minister's position in relation to the so-called race debate. Indeed, the Prime Minister has constantly and consistently made it plain where he stands on the issue and where the government stands on the issue. To ask about whether the government has ignored material on the so-called negative impact of the race debate is—
—So-called? You reckon there's no negative impact?
