—I am saying that your allegation is that there is some article in the Canberra Times which you say contains voluminous material on the negative impact of the race debate. I know nothing about any of that. I am happy to find out for you whether there is any such advice available, but you understand, as well as I do, that we are not in the habit of tabling advice for your edification and titillation. If there is advice provided to the Prime Minister on a range of issues, then he will use that advice to ensure that the government's position is properly represented.

ANSWER.PARA: So the government categorically rejects any suggestion that there has been any irreparable or, indeed, any damage done to Australia's reputation. You will judge that in a number of ways. You will not judge that because some people want it to be so or because some people get out there and say it is so; you will you judge it on performance and you will judge it on the relationships that exist in the region.

You will be aware of what has been said by various heads of state in the region that make it perfectly plain that they understand the status of Pauline Hanson in this country—that she is not in any shape or form a spokesperson for the Australian government; she represents herself and a small minority. She is entitled to her view, but in no way does it have legitimacy.

We have made that abundantly clear through all the channels that are available, and all the leaders in the region understand that precisely. They also understand that there are people in this country like you who are absolutely determined to try and whip up the issue in such a way as to cause damage to Australia's reputation and we reject those attempts.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have made it abundantly clear. You can go on saying it every day of the week if you want to, and there will always be some people around who will say, `You haven't said it enough' or `You only said it yesterday and you haven't said it today.' The fact is that there are some people who will never be satisfied, for their own political reasons. The government's position is well understood by those that matter. If you want to run an alternative agenda, let it be upon your heads, but the fact is that our position is unequivocal and those in the region and those who need to know do know.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't it true, as reported in the same Canberra Times article, that several Australian and foreign diplomats believe that, despite the PM's recent comments about the member for Oxley, it is just too little too late to have any hope of repairing Australia's image overseas? Why did the Prime Minister fail to act for over a year since the member for Oxley's maiden speech and thus blow his chance to nip in the bud this bad image that has been created for Australia?

QUESTION.PARA: If he had acted forcefully and early, wouldn't he have prevented much of the damage that has occurred to our international reputation and national interest? Minister, since you just said that you categorically deny that there are any adverse effects on Australian trade, and since Minister Fischer has said that Hanson is damaging Australian trade, who is telling the truth—you or Mr Fischer?

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of questions involved in that. To suggest that somehow a couple of nameless diplomats might have a view of the world that perhaps accords with yours is in no shape or form the basis for making an objective assessment about the impact of any particular statements. I think you will also find that there are very many diplomats in the region who do understand the realities of what has been going on in this country, understand that the Prime Minister has put our position on the record consistently and clearly, and that there was indeed a change in the attitude once Pauline Hanson formed her own party. Once One Nation became a separate organisation, she ceased to be simply an Independent member of parliament and she ceased to be a spokesperson for a group. Once she entered the political contest, it was certainly necessary to ensure that any policies or alleged policies that might be espoused by that party be comprehensively refuted, and Mr Fischer and the Prime Minister have done just that. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Acting Minister for the Environment, Senator Parer. What is your response to the comments by the Minister for the Environment, Robert Hill, on today's AM program:

QUESTION.PARA: When I see improvement on the ground, when we get to a year without extinction of species, when finally we've decided to destroy no more of the world's forests, so we get to a net end to reduction of native forests . . . then I think we'll be able to look our children and grandchildren in the face.

Minister, given your government's support for the appalling destruction of Australia's native forests and given that these forests are habitats for many endangered species, what are you going to tell your grandchildren and your children? What do you and Senator Hill suggest we tell our children as the chainsaws move into the Goolengook and other tall forests in East Gippsland this week as a result of your policies on the export of woodchips and whole logs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear what Senator Hill said this morning on AM , but I presume what he was doing, Senator,—
—Someone should have briefed you, Minister.

—Senator, if you listen I will give you an answer. I presume what he was doing was referring to a statement that he made at the 19th Special Session of the United Nations General Assembly to review implementation of agenda 21. Before Senator Hill left for overseas, he in fact made some general statements about how things had deteriorated globally since the 1992 Earth Summit. Let me just tell you, Madam President, what Senator Hill actually said in talking about comparisons with the Earth Summit in Rio and putting down Australia's position. If you would like a copy of his speech, Senator, I will be happy to give you a full copy.

ANSWER.PARA: But, in respect of Australia, he has said that we are moving on greenhouse emission reductions in cooperation with the business community—that is what we are doing in Australia. With regard to forests—and I think he concentrated on forests—we allocated an additional $48 million over three years to expedite completion of comprehensive regional assessment of the nation's forests, allowing the government to fulfil its election commitment to bring forward the completion of the regional forests agreement.

We oversaw the signing of the first Commonwealth‐state regional forests agreement for the forests of East Gippsland. If you want to ask me about Goolengook in the supplementary question, go right ahead. He went on to talk about a whole range of other things, mainly in relation to fauna, whales, albatross and dugong.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no whales in the forest, Minister.
—That is intelligent!
—Even you would have to admit it is true.

—A very intelligent interjection, wasn't it, Senator? He went on to describe what we had done in Australia in regard to world heritage and what we had done in regard to oceans, pollution and, of course, the Natural Heritage Trust. If my memory is correct, Senator Lees, you opposed the partial sale of Telstra to be able to provide $1.2 billion—the biggest investment ever in the restoration of our environment. After much grandstanding and, needless to say, delay by you, Senator Lees, and your party in the Senate, the parliament finally passed the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill, thus fulfilling a major election promise. Time is running out but, as I have mentioned earlier, if you want a copy of Senator Hill's full speech to the United Nations, Senator, I will be only too happy to give it to you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you really must be getting desperate to have to go all the way back to Telstra to try and fill up your answer time. Isn't this another case of Senator Hill telling the rest of the world what they should be doing and basically saying, `We're a special case. They can do more to protect the planet, but not us'? Is it another greenhouse scenario—or perhaps it is really a glasshouse scenario—with Senator Hill over there throwing stones?

—We in Australia and we in this government are very proud of what we have done on the environment. I think Senator Hill is very much justified in going overseas and telling them just what this government has done in the short period of 15 months. Senator, I know that you do not support the approach we have taken on greenhouse, but I think you and the Democrats have got to ask yourselves which country you are representing. It is certainly not Australia. One wonders whether, in the 1990s, you are not the Manning Clarks of Australia.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from India led by the Hon P.A. Sangma MP, the Speaker of the Lok Sabha. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate, and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of senators, I propose to invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

PARA.EMPHASIS: Mr Sangma was thereupon seated accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Family Services, Senator Newman. Minister, I refer to your extraordinary answer to a question I asked yesterday in which you stated that the government has no view—I repeat, has no view—on the imminent closure of child‐care centres in Tasmania. Minister, isn't it a fact that the Clarendon Vale Child Care Centre in Hobart has already closed and that the Children's Playhouse Child Care Centre in Ravenswood will close on Friday? Can you confirm that the Huon Community Child Care Centre will have to significantly cut programs, leading to redundancies, and that the Pilgrim Child Care centre also faces redundancies? Are you aware that industry sources have stated that another five child‐care centres in Tasmania will be forced to close? Who is to blame for these closures and program cuts? Is it the committees of management, as you stated yesterday, or is it your government's policies? When will you have a view on the dramatic loss of child‐care facilities in Tasmania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —When will Senator O'Brien actually quote in context? That was a disgraceful little exercise. I said, in fact, to the opposite—and I have the Hansard here in front of me, Senator. I said, in fact, to the opposite. We have put money into supporting their restructuring so they can survive, so get your facts straight—
—You said that yesterday.
—Order! There are far too many interjections on my left.
—It is a great pity that Senator O'Brien is learning bad habits very early on in his career.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections, and it is disorderly.

—I am interested to know that the senator has actually blown the cover once again on where the Labor Party gets its information from: industry sources. They are the lobby group for the child‐care industry union members.
—Shame!
—Lock them up!
—Order! The level of noise and intervention is far beyond anything that is reasonable.
—I am glad you acknowledge you are guilty as charged, because you never lobby on behalf of the parents and the families—that is the point I am making. Never, never, never!

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Only for your union mates—that is whom you lobby for. The situation is that the Minister for Family Services has recognised that there are a number of community child‐care centres all around Australia which are potentially in trouble because of inadequate management and for other reasons. Often, the reason they are in trouble is because of the inadequate planning arrangements that the previous minister, Senator Crowley—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of intervention is far too high. I regard some of the behaviour as quite wilful ignoring of the chair.

—We have had these questions asked in the chamber before. We have had them asked extensively in estimates committees. One of the acknowledged problems for child‐care centres is the poor planning of the previous government whereby child‐care centres grew willy‐nilly and in competition with each other and whereby they were not viable because of lack of children or because of people's changing circumstances in their communities.

ANSWER.PARA: Yesterday Senator O'Brien asked me a question. I gave him an answer based on the information I have from the minister responsible. It is, perhaps, a pity I did not give him more information than I did. Perhaps I could give it to him now, if I have got the time. I referred yesterday to the small amount of information available to the department from the report commissioned to enable the Ravenswood Child Care Centre to be viable. Senator, that report showed there were four possible scenarios for the continued operation of the centre.

In three of these options it is assumed that the service will cease to receive an operational subsidy. Each of these scenarios—for example, no longer providing hot meals—show the service remaining viable. If the provision of meals was to cease—if families brought their own meals, as they do in many child‐care centres—there would not be a need to increase the fees. It is a great shame that the management has not been prepared to adopt any of the options which they themselves proposed.

The Labor Party might be interested to know, too, that this child‐care centre received funding of $77,000‐odd for capital upgrading in November 1995 from their government. Then it received a management restructuring grant of $57,281 in December 1995. Since we came into government the centre has received additional amounts for fencing and replacement of glass panels to the tune of nearly $5,000. This is a child‐care centre which is receiving about $90,000 in child‐care assistance as well as the $23,000 operational subsidy. We are here with money to assist them to restructure. If they are not willing to be viable and efficient, then I am afraid what will happen is that somebody else will look to run the child‐care centre in their place. That is what is happening in Launceston now. Another organisation is looking to see whether they will take it over. The situation in regard to the other child‐care centres that you referred to has been addressed in this chamber before. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the Hansard reveals this sentence: `We have no view on centres being closed.' Isn't that what the Hansard says, and isn't it true that you have misled the Senate? Isn't it true that in Tasmania the child‐care industry is in fact run by the community sector, and that sector is run by committees of management made up of parents and members of the community? And aren't they the industry in Tasmania that you condemn in your answer?
—Why did you mislead the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Faulkner would do anything at the moment to cover his embarrassment, but this is not going to be good enough. I have lost count of the number of times that he has tried to suggest that I have misled the Senate, and every time it has proved to be simply a boy crying wolf.

ANSWER.PARA: When I studied law, I was trained that you interpret a document and any statement in it in its context. While I said the sentence the Senator O'Brien quoted, I also went straight on to say the sentence I just quoted. And there is no doubt about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you mislead?
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—This is a public record, a public document, of what was said yesterday. I do not walk away from it. We are concerned if child‐care centres fail, but we are more concerned if they have the opportunity to survive and they don't take the helping hand when it is offered. In Tasmania some have amalgamated; some have closed due to lack of children. That has been happening in fact prior to our coming into government, and that is something that you should have known before you asked the question. (Time expired)

—My question to the Assistant Treasurer is against the background of the debate stimulated by the government on the GST, which it says will be user friendly. It is also against the background of the huge amount of expenditure of taxpayers' money on the development of tax incidence models. My question to the minister is: in view of that, will the minister make available to interested members of the public a user friendly Windows based interface of the Treasury's PRISMOD model of the tax system so that taxpayers themselves can work out whether they are better or worse off under the proposed tax changes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, what has just happened, as you would be aware, Senator Harradine, is that a tax reform debate has started in the community, in which people are putting forward their various views and thoughts, trying to address the range of problems which we are facing with our tax system. There is even a wide range of views and thoughts, I must say, from the Labor Party—ranging from the Lindsay Tanner view that we need to broaden the tax base to the Gary Evans view that we need to raise the level of taxes and to the Wayne Goss view that we have major problems with the income tax system.

ANSWER.PARA: So there is no particular option, as you are aware, on the table at the moment, but there is a range of views that are being put forward by political groups, by business groups, by social welfare groups, to address what they see as fundamental problems. You have raised whether there could be a user friendly model put forward, Senator. My understanding is that these models are very complex, to be quite frank, very complex indeed. I am not in a position to say whether it would be possible to put forward a user friendly model, but, Senator, I will draw your views to the attention of the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be grateful if the minister did that.
—He says that every time, Brian.

—I will be expecting, I think, a response, because it is an important matter. As a supplementary question: will the government be encouraging the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling to also undertake an analysis of the various proposals that are being developed so that they too could make an analysis of who might or might not be the winners, given the GST proposals?

—As I said, Senator Harradine, there are no particular proposals which the government has endorsed. But there is a range of views that are being put forward. I am sure that anyone with an interest in this area and who may feel they have a model which can be used to analyse the various proposals is perfectly entitled to make use of those models.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women. Minister, I refer to the government's policy to avoid doing business with organisations which fail to comply with the requirements of the Affirmative Action (Equal Opportunity for Women) Act. Can you explain why the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Jull, has written to ministers warning them that certain government agencies are exceeding their responsibilities by alerting businesses to the contract compliance policy? Aren't government agencies acting responsibly in drawing businesses' attention to government policy and, furthermore, isn't this entirely consistent with the object of the act, which is to promote equal opportunity for women?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that it would be wrong to infer that the government's action is intended to do anything except keep the lines of communication on affirmative action clear and to keep compliance advice authoritative. The government recently wrote to agencies to remind them that they should remain within the scope of the guidelines for contract compliance policy in their dealings with business. These guidelines were issued by the Affirmative Action Agency in 1992 and have not been changed.

ANSWER.PARA: It was brought to the government's attention that at least one agency was overstepping their responsibilities in respect of the guidelines and the government's view is that the Affirmative Action Agency should be the only source of advice to businesses about their obligations under the act. This would ensure that businesses are not confused by advice from other sources which could be ambiguous or misleading. It is important that business gets the right message from the right source.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Don't Minister Jull's actions demonstrate that this government is far more concerned with deterring people doing business with government than the effect it may have on equal opportunities for women? And, more particularly, this exceeding of responsibilities and the action taken by Mr Jull: did he consult with you before taking this action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a misunderstanding by Senator Neal. I am not the minister responsible for the Affirmative Action Agency. It is not anything to do with the Office of the Status of Women. It is the responsibility of Minister Reith. Minister Jull has a responsibility for government contracting. I think that it is a shame that the article which referred to Mr Jull's letter misled, as it implied that there had been a change of policy. Clearly that has interested you but, as I have said already, it is not the case. The letter was simply intended to clarify the roles and responsibilities of agencies and the Affirmative Action Agency.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, under Labor, nearly one million Australians were out of work. In December 1992 unemployment reached a post‐ depression high of 11.2 per cent and hundreds of thousands of Australians experienced significant underemployment. What is the government doing to address Labor's terrible legacy? Are there any groups beyond our government's capacity to provide meaningful assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for that question, because Labor did indeed leave us with a terrible unemployment legacy—an unemployment rate over 10 per cent for 33 consecutive months and the creation of a mere 33,500 jobs over almost a six‐year period. That is a tragedy in anyone's terms. As a result we have introduced a comprehensive array of policies which are designed to address this very important issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Bringing the budget into surplus, providing a climate for lower interest rates, getting rid of Labor's job destroying unfair dismissal laws, providing a more flexible labour market to increase productivity and competitiveness, rollover relief, provisional tax uplift factor, reducing red tape and providing access to venture capital are all initiatives designed to ensure that small business is able to act as a jobs generator. We are also committed to removing the financial incentives on young people to go on to unemployment benefits and to re‐invigorate the apprenticeship and traineeship scheme.

I am also asked whether there are any groups beyond the government's capacity to provide meaningful assistance. Unfortunately, the answer is yes. We know that because of a devastating admission made by Senator Conroy in giving evidence before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Senator Conroy identified what he described as a mini‐ unemployment crisis. He said:
A lot of people, because they have been particularly a Labor member of parliament, are just incapable of getting a job, particularly in the private sector.

We have looked at what we can do for them. There are some labour market programs. None of them seem to be particularly appropriate. Often you need to have some degree of business acumen. Clearly, you would not qualify under the NIES scheme. There aren't employers who are prepared to take on people who have generally spent a lifetime bagging the private sector and showing no interest at all in the concerns of businesses struggling to make ends meet.

We have also thought of some political education programs to try and explain to them what the capitalist system is all about, how private enterprise can actually create markets and jobs, how choice and incentive are very important aspects. Indeed, the dead hand of Labor governments is something we would very much warn them against. You only have to ask yourself: who would give Kim Carr a job? Most people wouldn't feed him. The reason they wouldn't feed him is that he has never done anything other than be critical of all the private sector stands for. But if someone like Stephen Loosley can get a job, you would have thought there would be a bit of hope.

I can only say that we sympathise very much with Senator Conroy's concerns. His solution is yet another retirement village adjustment pay‐out. What they want is yet another government payment to try and smooth the transition from a trade union sponsored position. What we have got here, as you will notice, Madam President, is a delegates meeting, is it not? Or is it just the organisers having a bit of a chat? It is probably a meeting of the sandpit club, where the only qualifications are that you are not interested in public policy, you simply bury your head in the sand every time anyone comes up with any sensible ideas for actual job creation.

All I can say is that Senator Conroy and his colleagues have our greatest sympathy. If they really do want to get jobs in the private sector, they will have to make a much better effort to try and understand the problems, to try and ensure that there are opportunities available. They will not be able to go back to the trade union movement because they are already trying to train a new phalanx of seat warmers to come through the system. So clearly they would not want to take this lot back again. I think the future is pretty bleak for most of those opposite—two-thirds of whom do have that background.

Senator Conroy, the only solution really is to go along to those pre-selection conventions, try and recruit people who have an understanding of the way the market system operates, people who are likely to at least have some minimal attraction for the private sector. That way you will not be putting your hand up for yet another government—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, is it true that, with only six days remaining until the expiry of the current Commonwealth-state legal aid agreements, the Commonwealth is yet to finalise a single legal aid agreement with any state or territory? Indeed, isn't it true that, in the case of Western Australia, not even an agreement in principle has been reached? Minister, can you guarantee that the required legal aid agreements will be in place prior to midnight on 30 June and that there will be minimum disruption to the delivery of legal aid services to the Australian community from 1 July 1997?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to provide guarantees or to give a progress report on the state of negotiations. It is a typical union tactic, isn't it? You stall, you do absolutely everything you possibly can until the 11th hour, then you say, gun at head, `We want you to sign on the dotted line.' I cannot tell you what is going on in this particular area. I will certainly do my best to ascertain the facts for you. But it has to be against the background of your understanding of the way in which the budget deficit required us to take some pretty tough decisions. I know you are not interested. You want to pretend that somehow all was well, that the country would have just kept ticking over, that there would not have been any problems.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is we do have endemic levels of unemployment directly as a result of your failure to take those tough decisions, to cut back on levels of government expenditure and to simply allow Mr Beazley's $10 billion black hole to emerge without offering even the slightest suggestion about how the problems can be resolved. We know that the job of opposition in part involves opposing, but it does involve a little more than that. It involves an understanding of the difficulties that governments confront when they have budgets that are out of control as a result of the actions of their predecessors and the necessity for them to take cuts in a range of difficult areas.

We have tried to spread the pain. We have tried to ensure that the amounts that are required to maintain particular services are available consistent with budgetary constraints. Within those parameters, I am sure that there are negotiations that are proceeding to achieve whatever the particular deadline might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —But will there be agreement, any agreement by 1 July?

—I suppose that depends on the outcome of the negotiations, doesn't it? Somehow you think that, because there are negotiations in train, that inevitably means you must cave in, must do a deal in the terms that I think are reasonable. If these are even‐handed negotiations, then the outcome will depend upon the joint reasonableness of the parties and the willingness of the parties to acknowledge that there was a need to take those very tough decisions. I will get back to you with any more precise information about the state of the negotiations and the prospects in the lead‐up to 1 July.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I heard you say that you will get back to me. Given the urgency of this matter and the very real risk of disruption to legal aid service delivery and the justice system around this country, can you seek advice from the Prime Minister's office and report back to the Senate prior to the adjournment of the Senate this day?

—I can inform Senator McKiernan that the government will not be reconsidering its decision to reduce legal aid funding. Our decision was based on the principle that the Commonwealth should only fund legal aid for matters arising under federal law. The Attorney-General has now reached in‐principle agreement with Victoria. Joint service delivery will continue this year. We have also reached in‐principle agreements with the ACT, South Australia and the Northern Territory and we are negotiating—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is based on relevance. I do not know where the magic piece of paper that the minister is quoting from appeared from. It has nothing to do with the supplementary question that I asked him. I asked him: given the real urgency of the situation, will he seek information from the Prime Minister's office and report back to the Senate with that information prior to the adjournment today? It has nothing to do with the contents of that piece of paper that has been passed to him.

—On the point of order: I thought I was in the process of creating a world record by providing the information to Senator McKiernan now rather than before the close of business today. There is information that can be made available now. I will see whether there is any information that can be provided later.

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the acting Minister for the Environment. Minister, do you agree that the ABARE models on climate change that you used to justify Australia's position on targets assumed that markets work perfectly and that there are no cost neutral measures that we can take to lower carbon emissions? On the other hand, do you agree that your greenhouse challenge program for Australian industry actually relies almost entirely on businesses undertaking measures which are cost neutral? Aren't you telling domestic industry that substantial reductions can be made for next to nothing while at the same time telling the international community that emission reductions will be a huge burden and impose a huge cost on Australia. Which statement is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The greenhouse challenge, Senator Lees, relates to a voluntary agreement between industry and government. It relates very much to deregulation of the electricity, market which we have carried on and which was started by the previous government. One of the benefits that has come out of electricity deregulation is that, up until deregulation, most power stations were owned and operated by the states and the cost for electricity paid by industry was very much a fixed cost over which the industry had no control.

ANSWER.PARA: As we go down the track of freeing up the electricity market, there is now an awareness out there of two things. Firstly, it is no longer perceived as a fixed cost but one which can be negotiated. Secondly, because of the industry's desire to cooperate with government in going down the route of energy efficiency, they have been able to save money not only in respect of the direct supply of electricity but also in respect of energy usage. There are two benefits.

I am aware of the position of the Democrats in relation to ABARE. Senator Kernot has made it very clear over and over again. She questions ABARE simply because of remarks made by people like Clive Hamilton, who, I might say, is very dubious, Senator, but if you want to keep in contact with Clive Hamilton, that is fine. He has some inner self called Jacob who seems to advise him.

Megabare has been built by ABARE—an organisation with an acknowledged 50‐year track record of professional, independent objectivity and research excellence. It has further extended this reputation with the construction of what is considered world wide as a world‐class model.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not.

—Senator Lees says that it is not. It does not suit your agenda, Senator. As I said to you before in answer to a question, the Democrats have to make up their minds about who elected them into this parliament. Presumably it was the Australian people. The language the Democrats use would indicate that they are representing some other country, such as the European Union. If they go down that track, they are doing it at the expense of Australia. You may not care about that, Senator Kernot, but we do. I know by the silence on the other side that we have support on the other side.
—No, you don't.
—Oh, we don't. So the new Labor Party has changed its view. What did then Senator Evans say on this very issue back in August 1994?

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. As usual, I am being incredibly patient. My point of order goes to the matter of relevance. At this point, Senator Parer has not answered one word in terms of the question asked.
—Order! Senator Parer, I draw your attention to the question which was asked by Senator Lees.

—Thank you, Madam President. I was distracted by interjections. Let me make the point that Megabare has been accepted by the prestigious energy modelling forum based at Stanford University as one of the world's leading models for international policy assessment. What they found was—this is the information that we rely upon in our discussions and in our debate in regard to differentiation of fixed targets—that if we went down the track that is being promoted by the European Union, which you are pushing on the Democrats' side, we in Australia would suffer a disadvantage 22 times more than the European Union.

ANSWER.PARA: You may enjoy that, Senator. You may enjoy shutting down all the power stations. You may enjoy shutting down the alumina refineries. You may enjoy shutting down the steel works at Wollongong. You may enjoy shutting down the steel works at Whyalla and the Bowen Basin and the alumina refinery in Gladstone, if that is what you want, Senator. It is something that we will not be part of. (Time expired)

After all, it is the only one we have. We cannot pack up and go somewhere else that your Megabare model might suggest. A fair slab of that is the hydro‐electric systems. I suppose if the Democrats had been here 20 or 30 years ago they would have stopped the Snowy. But excluding the hydro‐electric areas, total renewables are about $250 million and about $100 million is exported. Certainly there is a market. There is a growing market for things like solar hot water systems, photovoltaic cells, the hybrid systems that relate to the photovoltaics and diesel—(Time expired)

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, I refer to a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald that Dr Meredith Edwards, Deputy Secretary of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, responsible for social policy has been edged out of the Public Service by Mr Max Moore-Wilton. —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do I understand from that that the decision to axe Dr Edwards is in fact symptomatic of the deteriorating relationship between Mr Max Moore-Wilton and other senior executives in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Will the minister advise what the effect would be on the Australian economy and on jobs in particular were the proposals of the European Union for uniform greenhouse gas reduction targets to be adopted internationally at Kyoto in December? What is the government's position on the international climate change negotiations?
—Which hat are you wearing?
—Order! Senator Schacht, cease interjecting!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Madam President—disorderly in the extreme. Australia's position is that we need to agree at Kyoto on arrangements that will be effective in reducing global greenhouse gas emissions consistent with the Berlin mandate of the Framework Convention on Climate Change. This means the reduction targets for developed countries need to be effective, achievable and equitable.

ANSWER.PARA: As we have said on many occasions, the European‐led push for the drastic uniform targets across Annex 1 countries achieves very little for the environment and has the European Union bearing the least cost of all Annex 1 countries. Under the uniform abatement regime proposed by the Europeans, Australia would be asked, as I said earlier in question time, to bear a cost 22 times greater than the people in Europe and eight times greater than those in America.

Economic analysis undertaken by ABARE highlights the damaging sectoral impacts on our economy under a uniform target regime. The ABARE analysis shows that a uniform reduction target even far less stringent than proposed by the European Union would cause significant output reductions for Australian industry. This would have devastating consequences on many regions of Australia involved in energy intensive industries where Australia is highly competitive internationally.

BREAK.PARA: The Labor Party has been milking the Newcastle steelworks issue for cheap political gain. The party which says we should subsidise steel making in Australia has said nothing on an issue which would reduce our overall steel making capacity by some 25 per cent. Thousands of jobs are at stake in our coalfields, ferrous and non-ferrous industries, the alumina and aluminium industry and in the thousands of small businesses which depend on them. Families would be devastated. But Labor remains mute. Businesses would close throughout our regional areas such as those mentioned earlier—the La Trobe Valley, the Illawarra, Newcastle, the Hunter, Central Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia.

The government has a very clear direction, arguing for an equitable differentiation approach towards setting greenhouse gas emission targets. This means the cost of reducing greenhouse gas emissions should be shared fairly. That is all we are asking. No country should get a free ride nor should it suffer through paying proportionately more than others. Australia is committed to an outcome at Kyoto. With safeguards, our economic and trade interests are equitable, efficient and environmentally effective.
It is interesting that Labor's Internet contribution to greenhouse is dismissed in four paragraphs. Listen to what they say in response to greenhouse:

Labor opposition is deeply concerned with the Howard government's greenhouse policy and will work hard to ensure that the Australian government accelerates rather than slackens its efforts towards addressing this serious issue.
What on earth does that mean? Talk about policy deprivation. It has become an endemic disease on the other side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. We have waited for—what are you doing?
—I was going to ask that further questions be put on notice.

—We have listened impatiently—

—Madam President, on the point of order: I will explain it to Senator Bolkus, because neither he nor the Labor Party understands it. We actually work on a whole of government approach, Senator. We talk to one another. In the previous government, they would not talk to one another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator O'Brien today, relating to child‐care centres.

I must say that, even in all the circumstances that we have had to date and the responses of Senator Newman in relation to the issue of child care, I was still somewhat surprised to hear the response given by her yesterday. Despite her denials and despite her attempts to mislead the Senate, I will repeat for the information of senators what Senator Newman said yesterday in response to Senator O'Brien's question, and this is recorded in the Hansard . She said:
We have no view on centres being closed.

This clearly indicates the indifference and callousness of this government, and in particular Senator Newman, in relation to the effect that their policies have been having on child-care centres and, further, the effect that will have on the children who are being cared for in those centres and the parents that rely on those child-care centres so they can go to work and carry out their usual other activities.

This government has taken a large number of steps since it got into government which have all had a negative effect on child care. Last year in its budget, it cut $500 million from child care and added insult to that injury by again cutting $321 million in the 1997 budget. There may be some people in the coalition who think that is a good thing, but it is certainly not a view that I share and it is not a view that is shared by the vast number of parents in this community. Parents think that having a workable, well set‐up, high quality child-care sector is a good thing for them and a good thing for their children.

The steps that this government has taken and the callousness that Senator Newman has betrayed are negative things. Parents will end up with a lower quality child-care sector that has higher costs. That is already starting to come about. A lot of the cuts that were put in place in the 1996 budget are, in fact, not yet having an effect. The cuts to child-care assistance will not have effect until 1 July. But already prices have risen.

In my discussions with child-care centres, because of the cuts to child-care assistance, there will either be a further increase of up to $20 a week or, alternatively, they will have to impose cuts. This will mean that children do not get the same level of service they are getting now; they will get a lower quality level of child care.

What sorts of cuts are they entertaining—not out of the wish to reduce their quality of service, but because of the necessity as a result of decisions made by this government? They will have to reduce the number of staff, which means that the quality of care and training provided to these kids is compromised, as also is their safety. It means that they may not be able to provide meals during the middle of the day. It means a lower number of resources with things such as toys, and with facilities generally. It may mean that they will not be able to provide the playground equipment that they had planned to provide.

I must say that it is a little worrying to me that the minister in this government who is in charge of providing child care does not seem to understand how the vast number of community based child-care centres operate. She assumes that there is some overwhelming conflict between members of the management committee and parents at the centre. She fails to understand or appreciate that, with the vast range of community based child-care centres, the members of the management committee are parents at the centre, and that the parents and the management are entirely in accord. That is, that they wish to provide the best quality child care they can while, at the same time, keeping costs at a reasonable level so that parents can actually afford to send their children there.

This is some of the anecdotal evidence that is coming across already: that parents who previously had children in child care are no longer able to afford to send them there. They are withdrawing them from care or they are reducing their hours, going from full-time to part-time care. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I might respond to this particular matter because it is a matter that is in my own state and, although I come from the south of Tasmania, I am interested in child care. In fact, I had much pleasure today in putting out a press release in Tasmania, announcing that the federal government is making money available for an additional 215 child-care places around Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: However, here we have today Senator O'Brien and Senator Neal attacking Senator Newman and, through her, the Minister for Family Services, Mrs Judy Moylan, about the lack of care that this government is showing with child-care centres. In fact, I think it is fair to say that, in the last year of the Keating government, $1.003 billion was spent on child care; whereas, last year, the first year of the Howard government, our government, we spent $1.102 billion. That is an increase of over $100 million, or 10 per cent, on the amount spent by the previous government. That is a fact, and you cannot get away from it.
My press release, entitled `Tasmanian child care gets a big boost', states:
The following organisations will receive additional places—
and this is in Tasmania—
Clarence City Council, Hobart City Council, Hobart Police & Citizens Youth Club, Lady Gowrie Tasmania, Lansdowne Crescent Primary School, Lipscombe Child Care Centre—

which is run by a very good friend of mine, Monica Dowd, who plays a leading role in child care in Tasmania; she represents Tasmanian child care on the federal body, and her concerns have been made known to Senator Newman on more than one occasion—
St Michael's Collegiate School, Taroona Primary Parents & Friends Association, Waratah-Wynyard Council, Sacred Heart College and Nixon Street Primary School Parents & Friends Association.
So, something like $142,000, plus another $39,000 in a one-off, will be spent in creating new year-round care places. That is the record of this government which has been announced just today.

So now Senator O'Brien comes in here and starts to talk about the Ravenswood matter. I saw the TV over the weekend, and I thought, `Gosh, what's going on up here?' It was supposed to be a meeting, I think you said yesterday; it looked to me more like a demonstration. Then I managed to get a copy of the Examiner. I had a look at that, and guess what? The federal ALP candidate for Bass, Michelle O'Byrne, had been addressing the rally. So, here we have it. Obviously, what we have here is a politically motivated attempt to try to upset the applecart in Bass. It is quite obvious.

The Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, Warwick Smith, is working very hard to ensure that parents in the Ravenswood area continue to have a service. But the fact is—and you cannot get away from this—that the decision to recommend the closure of that particular centre was made by the committee of management prior to the submission to the department by financial report without any discussion with the department. So, in other words, they decided themselves that they were in financial difficulties.

The matter has been taken up, as I said, by Warwick Smith, who is having discussions with the Launceston City Mission. I understand that, over the last two weeks, he has initiated and coordinated discussions with organisations around Launceston who are interested in taking over the operation of the Ravenswood Children's Playhouse child‐care centre.

I can understand Senator O'Brien's concern; that is his patch. But, as I have said, it is interesting to notice that one of the leading lights pushing the demonstration, the rally of the 100 placard waving residents, is none other than the nominated federal ALP candidate for Bass.

I think we should get back to the facts. The facts are that, since coming to government, we have increased child-care funding by 10 per cent. Over the next four years, the Howard government will spend $4.8 billion, and child care will continue to grow at three per cent real growth in each of the next four years.

Given the fact that we have decreased inflation to such a low level, that is over and above the level of inflation. So it is important to note that this government, since coming to office, has created over 31,000 new child-care places in a full year, at around a cost of $86 million. So there you go: you hear one story, and here is the real story. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) has is that yesterday she expressed herself in a way that can only really have one meaning, unless you accept what the minister says, which is that you need a legal interpretation to get the meaning that was intended. What we have to do with this minister's answers apparently is trot them out and get legal advice so we know what they mean.

The minister then said, `There's your problem. You are referring to industry sources.' Without quoting her, she said that they are not reliable, that they have a motive in this so you cannot quote them.

In Tasmania the industry is mostly comprised of the community sector—that is, child-care centres that are run by voluntary community citizens in committees of management. These sorts of committees are not prepared to do what the department says, which is to trade until they are insolvent. The reason they are not prepared to do that is that they could well be personally liable for any emerging obligations of that centre, be they employee obligations or otherwise. The question of opening more centres will probably not be one of opening centres or full day care places but after school care places. I suspect that is the sort of announcement that you are talking about.

They are not being attended to by the funding measures that are coming out of this budget. What we are seeing reflected in the circumstances with the closure of the Ravenswood centre is parents who have a need for child care who are losing it because the committees of management who run them are responsible enough to know that they cannot continue because they cannot charge the sorts of fees that the people who use their centres can afford to pay. Why? Because of your government's policies in relation to funding. That is the problem that they have. Your government has not addressed it. Minister Newman has to take it back to Minister Moylan and do something about it, because you have not done that to date. You have made it worse.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be very important for Minister Newman to have a look at what she said today because she actually said that this child‐care centre was closing because it was part of the previous Labor government's unplanned child‐care program. You will note, particularly if you were watching at the time that she said that, that she promptly drew in her breath and did not repeat it, because she knows it is absolutely wrong—just as Senator Patterson was skating very close to deliberate falsehood when she said that the Labor government was hopeless with child care because it was not planned.

SPEECH.PARA: The centres we are talking about are all community based centres and every one of them has been planned. They have all been placed in situations where the government's studies have shown a high need for child‐care places, family assistance and families' need for work. In fact, the private centres were disdainful of any of that information and data. As part of that planning process, in my time as minister I made that data available to the private centres so that they could also put their child‐care centres where they would most assist them. By and large they did not act on that and I will be very pleased to see how this government intends to require private child-care centres to open in a planned way. If they do not, of course, they will not be eligible for child‐care assistance.

We have here a minister who got it wrong today. She said that the Ravenswood child‐care centre is not built according to the planned process that the incoming coalition government wants to introduce. The senator is absolutely wrong on that. It was opened according to planning. I do not know the full details of Ravenswood, at least of the last little while, so I hesitate before I make this comment. But I would like to know why that committee of management, which has a fair idea of the people who live around it—a very poor area as I understand—thought that asking families to bring their own meals for the children was not something they wanted to proceed with. It might have to do with what that committee of management know about the poverty of the families around that centre. It was not a centre, as I understand it, that was largely devoted to working families, but it was a centre designed in large part to assist parents with occasional care or non‐work related care. It was also a centre in a poorer socioeconomic area.

Minister Newman says that the government has funds to assist those centres—yes, $3,000 to assist the management with restructuring. But this is after you have taken at least $23,500, on Senator Patterson's figures, out of that centre: $3,000 in to do nothing except to restructure and $23,000‐plus out, which was assisting with the recurrent costs of that centre. It seems to me a very bizarre equation if Senator Newman wants to say that that is the way we should think about it—`You should not look at the cuts. We are, after all, assisting these people.' If you take $23,000 away and give $3,000 back, most people understand what that means. It is a massive cut of the operational subsidy from this centre.

In my own state six community based child‐care centres have now closed. I am advised that in Western Australia it is 10, and they are all community based centres, very often in the lower socioeconomic areas where no private centre would open. It will be interesting to see if private operators will come in and take over these centres or not. There is also supposed to be money to assist families and provide child care in lower socioeconomic areas. I would like to see why that is not forthcoming to some of these centres.

Why would you want to shift the committee of management, which knows full well about the community there? Why is it not helping restructure and keep these child‐care centres open instead of being disdainful or disregarding as they close? Senator Calvert, you should check what child‐care places you are announcing today. I am sure they are outside school hours care. At least some of them that you announced were attached to schools, so that makes me suspicious that they are outside school hours care places. I welcome those. We welcome all of them. There is more need for child‐care centres and there is certainly no need to be closing places—and closing them with the disdain that Senator Newman brought into this place. That is no help at all. As for saying that families are not the regard of the Labor Party—oh, yes, they are. What are the women and representatives of the coalition who are supposed to speak for families doing when they disregard the needs of thousands of families who need child care? (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to speak to this motion to take note of Senator Newman's answer, particularly with regard to some of the points raised by Senator Crowley. We all know that in the ebb and flow of commercial activity, some commercial activity remains on an ongoing basis and some does not. The reasons for the ebb and flow of commercial activity are many and varied.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting that this particular child‐care centre, as I understand it, has been given opportunities to change the way in which it operates, and foremost among these is a management restructuring grant which, as I understand it, was for $57,281. That was given to the centre in December 1995. I am sure that the centre employed that money in the best possible way but you would think that, in the 18 months it had been given to restructure its activities, somewhat better use would have been made of the $57,000 to enable it not to close as it has just announced.

I gather, from material which has been passed on to me by the minister, that the decision to recommend the closure of the centre was made by the committee of management prior to the submission of the financial report to the department, and was taken without discussion with either the minister's office or the department of the options in that report.

The reason, of course, that the child‐care centre did not get the disadvantaged area subsidy is that this subsidy is provided to services located in areas where no other child care is available—in areas such as rural areas. Presumably, there are other child‐care centres available, and parents in the Ravenswood area will be able to take advantage of those. This government would very much like to encompass the provision of private child‐care centres and, although there may have been many community based child‐care centres in this area, in other areas of Tasmania, and indeed in other states, it is important to recognise that the expansion of private sector child care on an equitable footing with community care centres was something that was envisaged by this government.

The provision of operational subsidies to all community centres represented a significant inequity which saw 70 per cent of families unable to benefit from that subsidy and, indeed, parents in some rural and remote areas could not fund child‐care centres at all.

We have already remarked on the totally unplanned nature of the Labor government's child care expansion. This was highlighted in questions that I asked of officers of the department in Senate community affairs committee estimates hearings during our time in opposition. It was very obvious that there was little or no planning policy in place. This meant that we had oversupply in some areas and undersupply in others, which threatened the viability of the entire sector.

I would also like to point out that the closure of centres is nothing new. Under the Labor government in 1995‐96, 21 centres closed and a further 16 centres had to be propped up through additional government assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was the minister then?

—The minister then was, I believe, Senator Crowley—thank you for reminding me, Senator Campbell. The reality is that many centres which have closed have experienced ongoing financial difficulties. If those centres are in ongoing financial difficulties, why would parents want to continue with a centre such as that when they may well have access to a private sector centre which is starting up in the same area? Government support can only be justified when other alternatives are not available. That is why this government has made a feature of providing child care in rural and remote areas, and of rationalising, or further adjusting and planning, the supply of child‐care centres in urban areas.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure—as my colleague Mr Warwick Smith in the other House has announced—that all of the local community will be working to ensure that child care remains available to parents in the Ravenswood area, and he has indicated that in his press release dated 20 June 1997. He said:
The federal government will continue possibilities for future assistance when the new management organisation is established and the centre becomes operational.
(Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production; irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Save our ABC
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the vital role of a strong and comprehensive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) and asks that:
1. Coalition Senators honour their 1996 election promise, namely that `The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC'.
2. The Senate votes to maintain the existing role of the ABC as a fully independent, publicly funded and publicity owned organisation.
3. The Senate oppose any weakening of the Charter of the ABC.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned nurses and members of the public shows their concerns with the Aged Care Bill 1997 and the accompanying changes to the funding and regulation of Aged Care announced by the Government in the 1996 Budget. In particular regarding the abolition of specific funding for the provision of nursing care to residents of nursing homes.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate amend the Aged Care Bill 1997 so as to provide a requirement that funding of aged care be in such a form that specific funds are allocated to aged care providers for the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents and that aged care providers be allowed to spend that money only on the provision of nursing care to nursing home residents.

PARA.TAB: (a) to remove access to superannuation monies where the balance is less than $500;
(b) to restrict access to superannuation monies for persons under preservation age who are permanently leaving Australia; and

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That:
(1) A select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Human Biological Products, be appointed to inquire into and report, by the last sitting day of 1997, on the following matters:

PARA.TAB: (a) current and previous standards in the regulation, manufacture, supply and use of Australian and imported human biological products, including human pituitary hormones, vaccines and blood products;

(b) the role of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Commonwealth Department of Health and Family Services or any other Commonwealth department or agency in the production, use, testing, supervising and regulating of Australian and imported human biological products, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (i) the Australian Human Pituitary Hormone Program,
(ii) the testing of vaccines on children in Australian orphanages, and
(iii) the use and testing of human biological products in Aboriginal communities; and

PARA.TAB: (c) the fairness, adequacy and accessibility of compensation, grievance and redress mechanisms for the recipients of human biological products, with particular reference to the fairness of the recent settlement offered by the Commonwealth Government to recipients of human pituitary hormones and whether legal aid was unfairly denied to such recipients.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) The committee consist of seven senators as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a) three nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b) two nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c) one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d) one nominated by Senator Brown, Senator Margetts, Senator Harradine or Senator Colston.

SPEECH.PARA: (3) That the committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that not all members have been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(4) That the chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee.
(5) That the deputy chair of the committee be elected by and from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(6) That the deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(7) That, in the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.
(8) That a quorum of the committee be four members.

(9) That the committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place, to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives, and have leave to report from time to time its proceedings and the evidence taken and such interim recommendations as it may deem fit.

(10) That the committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.

(11) That the committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee with the approval of the President.
(12) That the committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it and that a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(a) notes that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) granted a degraded forest licence to North Forest Products in February 1997 which permits the clearing and woodchipping of over 3 000 hectares of pure rainforest, as well as other old-growth forest, on the Surrey Hills estate, Tasmania;

(b) considers that the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) misled the Senate on 6 May 1997, both in his answer to a question without notice from Senator Brown, and in additional information he provided later in the day, in that:

PARA.TAB: (i) the Minister claimed that `very little rainforest was involved at all' and later that `pristine rainforest was actually excluded on my advice, beyond that it had already been voluntarily excluded by North. . . So all care was taken in relation to rainforest', whereas in fact at least 3 000 hectares of pure callidendrous (cathedral-like) rainforest were licensed for woodchipping,
(ii) the Minister stated that `the assessment of the Forest Practices Board was to find that the Surrey Hills block was degraded', but in fact:

TAB.TAB: (a) the Tasmanian Forest Practices Board did not conclude that the Surrey Hills forests were `degraded' and found that `very little floristic change could be detected in disturbed rainforests',
(b) a CSIRO evaluation of the report by the Forest Practices Board found that there was insufficient data to determine whether the forests were degraded, and

(c) the Minister had been advised by his department on 24 February 1997 that `it is not possible to give an informed opinion as to whether the remaining native forest (which includes the rainforest) on the estate is degraded, to what extent it might be degraded or over what area it might be degraded';

SPEECH.PARA: (c) considers that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy acted improperly in engaging the Tasmanian Forest Practices Board to assess whether the forests were degraded, in that:

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I hate to interrupt Senator Brown, but I thought there was a standing order that precluded, or at least drew attention to, long quotes and long notices of motion. I ask you, Madam Deputy President, to have a look at this particular notice of motion that has been going now for quite some time.
—Senator Calvert, this will be viewed by Madam President under standing order 76. Senator Brown, please continue.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. My notice of motion continues:

PARA.TAB: (i) despite being required under sections 14(3)(b) and 14(4) of the Export Control (Hardwood Wood Chips) (1996) Regulations to engage a forest assessor who was independent of the applicant, the Minister selected the Forest Practices Board, which had received $60 000 from North Forest Products in the 1994-1995 financial year, and

SPEECH.PARA: (d) calls on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (i) immediately suspend the degraded forest licence issued to North Forest Products and place a moratorium on the export of woodchips from the Surrey Hills estate, and

(ii) conduct an independent inquiry into the circumstances surrounding the issuing of the licence, including an independent assessment of the values and condition of the forests of the Surrey Hills estate.
