That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
Practices Act, a hole that must be filled if small business in this country is to properly flourish in a genuinely fair and competitive economy.

For two decades, small businesses have been lobbying for legislative protection against unfair trading conduct by companies with undue market power, and for two decades various successive governments have allowed misuse of market power against small business to continue unchecked.

The situation has now reached crisis point in many industry sectors. That crisis is most acutely evident in the commercial relationships between shopping centre tenants and their landlords. But it is also a major issue in the oil industry in dealings between oil companies and their franchised service station operators, in the multi‐billion dollar franchising industry generally, in the banking sector and between exclusive suppliers and their customers.

According to the most recent Yellow Pages index of small business sentiment, competition and big business issues were the fourth biggest concerns of small business behind lack of sales, and almost level pegging with cash flow and consumer confidence. It ranked well ahead of government regulations, rising costs, staffing issues, taxes and bank lending. Small business organisations such as the Council of Small Business Organisations, the Motor Trades Association and the Pharmacy Guild have listed reform of fair trading laws as the biggest concern facing small business.

The 10,000 strong Australian Retailers Association has described retail tenancy laws, an aspect of fair trading, as `the single most important matter facing speciality retailers and impacting adversely their profitability.' With occupancy costs now often exceeding labour costs for Australian retailers, the association argues that the benefits of freeing up the tenancy market will far exceed the benefits of freeing up the labour market.

For many years, the Democrats have strongly supported the call for strengthening the legal protections available to small business against unfair trading practices. In June 1995, the Democrats sought to amend the Trade Practices Act to insert a new section 51AA to ban the use of economic duress in trade and commerce, to allow access to civil as well as criminal damages for breach of the unconscionable conduct provisions and to allow the ACCC to undertake representative actions. Speaking to the amendments, Senator Sid Spindler said the amendments were necessary because small business had not been able to access unconscionable conduct as a remedy because of the way the provisions were then drafted in the Trade Practices Act.

The ALP government at the time refused to support the Democrats' amendments, but introduced a somewhat narrower better business conduct bill four months later to deal with the issue. The late introduction of this bill saw it lapse without consideration with the calling of the 1996 election.

The coalition has been much slower in coming to terms with the issue, despite their professed support for the small business sector. Its election policy promised to `monitor' the issues, to `review' case studies and reports, to `educate' small business proprietors, to implement self‐regulatory industry codes of practice and alternative dispute resolution schemes, and to `consider . . . . if appropriate, amendments to the Trade Practices Act to complement the effectiveness of Codes of Practice and education programs'. However, the policy clearly fell short of the expectations of the small business community. To ameliorate concerns of the sector, the coalition also promised to refer the issue to a parliamentary committee to allow all views to be considered. In complying with this commitment, Minister Prosser referred the matter to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. That committee produced its report—Finding a balance—towards fair trading in Australia last month.

The committee received 198 submissions from small businesses, governments and industry bodies, and took evidence from 70 individuals and organisations. Half of its submissions were primarily on the vexed issue of retail tenancies. The committee concluded:

After detailed investigation the committee has concluded that concerns about unfair business conduct towards small business are justified, and should be addressed urgently. In an endeavour to find a balance towards fair trading in Australia, the committee has recommended a number of specific measures, including legislation, to induce behavioural change on the part of big business towards smaller business and to provide unfairly treated small businesses with adequate means of redress. These proposals will provide small businesses with a fair deal.

This bill implements the unanimous recommendations of the 10 coalition and five Labor members of the committee. The evidence gathered by the committee presents a compelling case for reform, a case put repeatedly by small business organisations over two decades.

The unanimous recommendations are all the more startling because they clearly run counter to the broad approach of the government's policy preference for self‐regulation. This was summed up by the Minister for Small Business, the Hon. Geoff Prosser, in a speech to the Property Council of Australia on 25 October 1996. Speaking about retail tenants' concerns about current retail tenancy contracts, the minister concluded:

Many of these complaints are either unfounded or at least one sided. It is the government's view that landlords should be free to exercise their property rights in all but the most exceptional circumstances.
In the speech, the minister also outlined his expectations of the committee's report:

I am seeking strategies that are in keeping with the government's commitment to minimum effective regulation. The strategies should take into account our preferences for solutions that do not involve legislation. In other words, they will need to take into account the application of voluntary codes of conduct and associated industry self‐regulation strategies.

Given the government's clear preference for voluntary self‐regulation, the committee's recommendations are all the more remarkable. The committee concluded that voluntary codes of practice simply are not effective, as the collapse of the Franchising Code Council amply demonstrates. The committee has concluded that there is a place for codes of practice, but that these need to be made mandatory by being underpinned by the Trade Practices Act. This is a view that the Democrats have long held.

As I said, the bill implements, in full, the recommendations of the committee in relation to legislative changes to the Trade Practices Act. It should be emphasised that, in doing so, it is only the start of the process of achieving fair trading rules. This bill will ensure that industries have a major incentive to develop codes of practice, while giving the ACCC a strong oversight role in approving codes of practice. With small business and the ACCC working hand in hand, these legislative changes are the first important step in establishing, sector by sector, what commercial behaviour is acceptable and unacceptable.

I will now outline the details of the bill itself. Item (1) of Schedule 1 inserts a new clause 51AA into the Trade Practices Act. This replaces the current largely ineffective provisions dealing with unconscionable conduct with a new broader provision on unfair conduct. Subsection (1) prohibits a corporation, in trade or commerce, from engaging in conduct that is, in all the circumstances, unfair.

Subsection (2) lists, without limiting the matters which the court may have regard to, a number of matters the court may have regard in determining whether the conduct is unfair. These matters encompass the relative bargaining power of the parties, the conduct and intentions of the parties, the nature of the contract and the good faith of the parties.

A particularly important provision is subsection 51(AA)(2)(i) regarding the requirements of any code of practice applying to participants in the area of trade or commerce in which the corporation is involved and which has been approved by the ACCC. It would be expected that industry specific codes of practice would cover issues such as pre‐contractual and continuous disclosure, contractual terms, the clear obligations of both parties, dispute resolution, any variations in costs and charges and so on, as are relevant for the industry.

Some critics of unfair trading laws, particularly large corporations and their representatives, have argued that enacting a new section 51AA will increase contractual uncertainty. The Democrats do not share this view—a view also rejected by the committee. As codes of practice are developed by the relevant parties, clear standards of what is fair business conduct will be established. Indeed, the process of developing a code of conduct can be as important as the final document itself as it forces an industry to consider what practices are fair and unfair. This will lead to greater certainty of contracting, and will avoid many of the disputes over unclear contractual terms, particularly where terms are open ended and one party is able to exercise dominant market power over another.
Subclause (3) provides that a corporation does not engage in unfair conduct by reason only that it institutes legal proceeding or refers a dispute or claim to arbitration.

Subclause (4) further limits the clause by stating that the court shall not have regard to circumstances which were not reasonably foreseeable at the time of the alleged contravention, but may have regard to circumstances existing prior to the commencement of the section.

Subclauses (5) and (6) make it clear that a court cannot make an order in respect of a contravention of the section unless the parties have first attended a mediation conference. The court will have regard to the good faith of the parties at that mediation conference in assessing costs in relation to the action. These sub‐clauses fulfil the recommendations of the committee that the provisions should be subject to compulsory arbitration.

Item (2) gives the ACCC the power to approve codes of practice, provided it is satisfied that associated corporations in a field of trade or commerce have agreed to be bound by a code of practice for fair dealing, and that organisations representing other interested persons have been consulted. The power in section 51ABA is discretionary—the ACCC need not approve the code if, for example, the code does not establish fair dealing practices.

Items (3) and (4) amend section 76 to ensure that civil as well as criminal penalties are available for breaches of section 51AA or of the consumer protection provisions of Division 1 and Division 1A of Part V of the act. These amendments were accepted by the committee on the advice of the ACCC as a means of providing a wider choice of remedies depending on the nature of the breach. Under the proposal, if a person contravened Part IVA or these provisions of Part V, he or she would be liable for a civil penalty. If, however, the conduct was engaged in knowingly, intentionally or recklessly and with an intention to cause significant loss or detriment to another or with knowledge of the likelihood of causing such loss or damage, the person would be liable to a criminal prosecution.

Item (5) seeks to make it clear that an action for damages for loss is clearly available in section 82 for breaches of the unconscionable conduct provisions in Part IVA. I am particularly pleased that this provision was picked up by the committee, as it was a matter Senator Spindler drew attention to with his amendments in June 1995.

Item (6) amends section 87 to make it clear that the ACCC is able to take representative actions for breaches of the competition provisions of the act—Part IV—as well as the unconscionable conduct and unfair trading provisions—Parts IVA and V. This extension of the ACCC's capacity to take representative actions on behalf of small business is important to ensure that small businesses have an effective means of redress to end unlawful behaviour. This amendment was also sought by Senator Spindler in 1995, and again I am pleased that it has been picked up by the committee.

In summary, this bill widens protections for small business against unfair trading practices in the Trade Practices Act, and also widens the choice of remedies available to the parties and the ACCC for breaches. The bill follows exactly the unanimous recommendations of the fair trading committee report. In doing so, it is hoped the bill will have broad cross‐party support to address issues the committee correctly identified as needing urgent attention. The protections are absolutely essential for small business to be able to operate in conditions of fair and genuine competition. I commend the bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the following committee report: Foreign Affairs Defence and Trade References Committee report on the development of Australia's air links with Latin America. I seek leave to incorporate the response in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
THE DEVELOPMENT OF AUSTRALIA'S AIR LINKS WITH LATIN AMERICA
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE SENATE FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE REFERENCES COMMITTEE.
INTRODUCTION

On 30 November 1995, the Senate referred the 1994‐95 Annual Reports of the Department of Transport and Qantas Airways Limited to the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to review the development of Australia's air links with Latin America.

The committee received a total of 19 submissions from relevant government departments and agencies, the private sector, and other interested parties. Public hearings were held on 11 and 17 June 1996 in Canberra. Evidence was heard from the Department of Transport and Regional Development, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Australian Tourist Commission, members of the Latin American Heads of Mission in Canberra, Aerolineas Argentinas and Qantas.

The committee's report containing 11 recommendations was presented to the President of the Senate in July 1996. The recommendations encourage the continued development of air links with Latin America, particularly Argentina and Chile.

Government policy is committed to liberalisation of international aviation, but stops short of pursuing a policy of open skies. The policy of liberalisation has already seen expansive outcomes in the negotiation of Australia's bilateral air services agreements since the government took office.

Latin America as a region can present significant future opportunities for increased business activity, tourism and investment. Australia has bilateral air services agreements with both Chile and Argentina and has exchanged draft agreements with Brazil as a basis for further discussions on the establishment of direct air links. To fully explore its potential, appropriately focused strategies across a number of portfolios are needed to remove obstacles to potential growth while recognising the essentially embryonic nature of Australia's relations with the region. Improved air links is but one of a number of factors necessary for growth; indeed, it would be irrational to expect that simply operating additional air services in the absence of commercially sustainable levels of demand is a course which government policy does, or ought, encourage.
Air services between Australia and South America continue to be characterised by very low levels of demand.

Experience of current demand suggests that sustained direct air services are fragile and unlikely to be able to sustain competitive entry without further growth in passenger and freight levels. The most efficient way to promote and develop this market, certainly through its developmental stage, may be through allowing airlines to develop cooperative commercial arrangements using off‐shore collection and distribution points.

The government supports the development of hubbing operations and has encouraged commercial agreements such as code sharing between Australian and Latin American carriers as an appropriate means of developing these markets and providing potential consumers with a range of services to the South American Continent.

Air services arrangements with Argentina and Chile were expanded in 1996 to provide carriers with further opportunities to promote and develop the Australia—Latin American market. The new arrangements provide airlines, including Aerolineas Argentinas and Lan Chile, with the opportunity to facilitate and develop air links.
The preparation of the government's response to the report has involved consultation with relevant government departments and agencies and the Australian carriers.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade welcomes the positive outcome of the latest air services negotiations with Argentina and Chile. These new arrangements provide carriers with enhanced opportunities to develop the route, encourage more frequent services as well as underpin the commercial viability of the route. These developments will be a positive factor in broad efforts to further build strong trade, investment and political linkages between Australia and Latin America.
RECOMMENDATION 1

The committee recommends that the Australian Government recognise that the opportunities for increasing business activity and investment in Latin America are very significant and that every effort should be made to remove obstacles to potential growth. Further, the committee recommends that the government accept the view put forward by a variety of interests that inadequate air links are a major impediment to growth and believes that more frequent services would be a significant means of stimulating further commercial activity between Australia and Latin America.
RESPONSE

The government supports this recommendation while recognising that in the presence of a liberal regulatory environment the number of air services on the route will reflect the commercial decision of airlines based primarily on the level of demand. Growth in the promotion of trade and tourism links should increase the level of demand for commercially viable air services.

While growth in trade and tourism links should increase the demand for air services, it is recognised that air services are important to the expansion of trade and investment links and that the availability of more frequent and direct services could generate potentially significant trade, investment and tourism benefits.

The revised capacity and commercial opportunities negotiated by this government with Argentina and Chile provide for current and expected future levels of demand for travel between Australia and the Latin American region at the same time as continuing to provide opportunities for as many airlines as possible to enter and operate in the market. The government will not `pick winners' amongst the South American carriers; and Australian carriers have the right to expect that their commercial strategies will get at least as fair an opportunity to succeed as foreign carriers.

The developing nature of the route is reflected in the fact that none of the carriers participating in this market operates direct services in its own right. Aerolineas Argentinas, Lan Chile, Air New Zealand, Ansett, Qantas and carriers operating via the United States (16% of the total traffic) terminate their services at intermediate points and extend their reach to South America or Australia on a joint service basis. As the market strengthens, provision has been made within the current arrangements for carriers to operate direct services in their own right.
RECOMMENDATION 2

The committee recommends that the Australian Government recognise that the potential for tourist visits to Australia from Latin America will only be realised if air services on the route are significantly improved; whereas travel between Latin America and Australia is currently not a sufficiently attractive option.
RESPONSE

The government recognises that the level of air services is an important factor in the development of international tourism between Latin America and Australia. Since coming into office, the government has negotiated significantly expanded air services arrangements with Argentina and Chile and has commenced air services negotiations with Brazil.

Other factors, such as the economic conditions in Latin America, the level of promotion of Australia in the region, the relative price competitiveness of Australia as a tourism destination and historical and cultural ties also play an important role in determining tourism flows.

Although Australia has limited control over factors such as the economic conditions in source countries and historical and cultural ties, increased tourism promotion by Australia in the region can have a significant positive impact on inbound tourism. It is important, however, that the limited promotional funds be used in the way that maximises the returns to Australia. This will require, among other things, a close coordination between promotional activity and the level of airline services.

The government welcomes advice that the Australian Tourist Commission has recently completed its second South American Travel Mission conducted in Brazil, Argentina and Chile. Thirteen Australian companies attended the Mission as well as representatives from the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation (QTTC), Tourism Victoria and the Northern Territory Tourist Commission.
RECOMMENDATION 3

The committee recommends that the Australian Government recognise that greater frequency of air services would stimulate air freight, which could improve profitability and lead to cheaper passenger fares.
RESPONSE

While accepting that air freight can make a positive contribution to the profitability of airlines, a correlation between increased air freight activity and improved airline profitability leading to lower air fares with a subsequent increase in passenger demand in this particular market has not been demonstrated and is structurally very unlikely. Around the world, and even in Australia, passengers subsidise freight, rather than freight support passengers.

Currently there is no shortage of freight capacity for exports. Freight load factors year round average in the 70% range with rates available to exporters of perishable products already at extremely low levels. Frequency of airline service can generally only stimulate the carriage of air freight in mature markets when the demand for goods at the buyer's end of the route is greater than the supply of capacity and the yield available from export freight rates are high enough to cover the freight operating costs. These circumstances do not yet exist in the Australia—Latin America air freight market.
RECOMMENDATION 4

The committee recommends that the Australian Government recognise the potential for Australia to become a regional hub for the increasing Latin America‐Asia traffic, and the possible significant economic benefits to be gained from establishing itself as such. Everything should be done to facilitate the development of the concept and that the relevant parties should explore the possibilities for developing smooth traffic flows Latin America‐Australia‐Asia, either by granting beyond rights to the existing Latin American carriers through code sharing with Australian carriers, or through another means.
RESPONSE
The government is prepared to support the development of hubbing operations in Australia for Latin America‐Asia traffic once the potential economic benefits of such operations are demonstrated.

Australia already operates as a regional hub for traffic between Latin America and South East Asia albeit at very low levels of demand (approximately 3,500 passengers in 1995). The greater flow of passengers will continue to be carried over North Asian routes via the United States to Latin American destinations, given powerful commercial and historical factors supporting US hubs.

There is no impediment to the development of Australia as a hub for Asia—Latin America traffic. Currently over 30 international airlines operate into Asia from Australia with over 450 services per week. There is an open capacity regime on the trans Tasman route and very liberal arrangements have been developed by New Zealand with a number of South American countries and are complemented by arrangements agreed between Australia and Argentina and Chile. There is no impediment to South American carriers entering into commercial cooperation arrangements on an interline basis via Australia to Asia with any airline of their choice.
RECOMMENDATION 5

The committee recommends that the Australian Government recognise that competition in the market is desirable and an important element in the improvement of quality of service and in the reduction of fares. It also recommends that the government recognise that where an operator has been willing to demonstrate its commitment to a market and to take commercial risks over an extended period, especially where its is offering a service that is in Australia's national interest, it should be encouraged to develop that service further. Increased demand for services will provide opportunities for all carriers willing to commit resources to the market. It is the responsibility of individual carriers to make commercial decisions as to whether, and to what extent, they wish to do so.
RESPONSE

The Government supports the principles expressed in developing this recommendation. A central element of the government's aviation policy is to actively encourage and promote improvements in competition, quality of service and the reduction of air fares. This is reflected in the negotiating strategies employed in all of our major international markets.

The government acknowledges the Latin American carriers' contribution to the development of this market. The arrangements reached with Chile and Argentina will enable their carriers to expand services significantly on the route.
RECOMMENDATION 6

The committee recommends that at future negotiations with Argentine and Chilean aviation authorities Aerolineas Argentinas and Lan Chile be granted the right to increase the frequency of their services, as they see the need, up to daily flights.
RESPONSE
The government has commenced implementing a strategy consistent with the recommendation.

The negotiations held with Argentina in August 1996 allow Aerolineas Argentinas to operate the equivalent of daily B747 services on a code share basis with an Australian carrier to up to five destination points in Australia. The carrier also has access to the entire Australian domestic network behind these gateways on a code shared basis with an Australian carrier.

The arrangements reached with Chile in April 1996 allow Lan Chile to operate: up to 3 weekly B767 services via New Zealand and Tahiti; fifth freedom rights on the basis of code share arrangements across the Tasman with an Australian carrier; and an open freight regime.
Future negotiations will review market trends and possible expansion of entitlements. Under both arrangements airlines are permitted to operate supplementary services during peak demand periods.
RECOMMENDATION 7

The committee recommends that Aerolineas Argentinas be granted fifth freedom rights out of New Zealand, on the condition that it maintains at least three weekly services year round, and that similar fifth freedom rights be extended to Lan Chile.
RESPONSE

The government will consider fifth freedom rights in any market based on an assessment of the additional benefits to Australia through the provision of lower fare levels, higher service quality and other gains.

In developing its strategy for the development of air services between Australia and South America, the government has focused on putting in place regulatory arrangements which ensure the maximum number of airlines possible have the opportunity to be involved in the promotion and development of services on the route. Under arrangements put in place by this government, Latin American carriers can now exercise full trans Tasman traffic rights using code share or other joint service arrangements with Australian carriers.
RECOMMENDATION 8

The committee recommends that the Australian Government encourage Qantas‐Lan Chile and Aerolineas Argentinas to negotiate the timings of their services in order to offer a greater range of services to travellers between Australia and Latin America.
RESPONSE

The government is unable to respond to this recommendation as timing of services is a commercial matter for the airlines involved. The government does not see its role as encouraging airlines to develop particular strategies; nor favouring market planning to any greater extent than is required by the bilateral negotiation system itself.

However, the government notes that Qantas has improved connections with Lan Chile by doubling its South American linkages and now terminates two B767 services per week at Papeete. Connections eastbound are now three hours and westbound, just one hour. Services are operated on Mondays and Fridays from Sydney and Thursdays and Sundays from Santiago.
As the market develops, Qantas will consider additional services with Lan Chile in order to increase the range of services available to travellers.

The government also notes that Ansett has an established commercial relationship with Aerolineas Argentinas and is discussing means of improving arrangements to provide better connections for its passengers.
RECOMMENDATION 9
The committee recommends that Latin American carriers be granted the right to market routes within and beyond Australia on the basis of code sharing with Australian carriers.
RESPONSE

The government does not believe the development of air services between Australia and South America will be assisted by granting Latin American carriers access to our Asian markets at this time. As noted above, these routes are highly competitive already, providing consumers with excellent service levels. The granting of the rights necessary to implement this access, even on a code share basis, would be inconsistent with negotiating strategies already developed and in place with a number of our major trading partners in the Asian region. For Australia the balance of advantage lies with continuing good relations with Asian partners.
RECOMMENDATION 10

The committee recommends that negotiations with aviation authorities of Latin American countries ensure that Australian carriers have equivalent rights to those recommended above, so that Australian carriers can enter the market on an equal basis whenever they wish to do so.
RESPONSE
The government supports the intent of this recommendation. In negotiations with Latin American countries to date, reciprocal rights have been obtained for Australian carriers.
RECOMMENDATION 11

The committee recommends that the Australian Tourist Commission continue to develop its presence and its activities in Latin America and that it explore the potential for co‐operation with Latin American carriers in marketing Australia to Latin American travellers.
RESPONSE

The government accepts this recommendation and notes that the Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) will continue to develop its activities in Latin America. The ATC maintains a close working relationship with airlines operating in Latin America, including Qantas, Aerolineas Argentinas and Lan Chile. ATC activities in Latin America will continue to concentrate on Argentina, Brazil and Chile as the majority of visitors to Australia come from these countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's responses to the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties' fourth report and the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties' sixth report. I seek leave to incorporate the responses in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
Government Response to the 4th Report of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties
Treaties Tabled on 15 & 29 October 1996

As is the case with all the reports tabled since the committee's formation in June 1996, the fourth reflects thorough and expeditious inquiry into a remarkable range of subjects. The government appreciates the marked improvement the committee's scrutiny has made to the Australian community's awareness of and confidence in the treaty‐making process.

The report supported Australian entry into all of the sixteen treaties in question, and appropriate action is being taken in each case; as of March 1997, six were already in force. The only formal recommendation was 1.20: `The committee recommends that Australia takes action in due course to propose that the Convention on Nuclear Safety be amended to include research reactors.' Australia ratified the Convention on 24 December 1996, and it entered into force for Australia on 24 March 1997.

Along with other countries involved in the negotiation of the Convention on Nuclear Safety, Australia has taken the view that a nuclear safety incident involving a research reactor would be unlikely to have international consequences warranting coverage in the Convention. Nevertheless, the government takes note of the committee's recommendation that Australia propose the amendment of the Convention to include research reactors, and will consider in due course whether any such action is appropriate in the light of our experience with the Convention's operation. In this context, it should be noted that the Contracting Parties have yet to hold their first review meeting, at which proposed amendments could be discussed. The first review meeting must take place before 24 April 1999.
The report also made some observations on consultation in treaty making that call for government comment:
. 1.19: `we believe it would be useful if, in future, NIAs provided information about the actual responses from the states and territories about the texts of treaties proposed for accession.'

. 1.99: `The committee is concerned that the Australian rice industry was not consulted during the preparation of the NIA for this Agreement [recognising the International Legal Personality of the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI)]. Implicit in the reforms to the treaty‐making process is wide and thorough consultation, during the NIA process if not before, with bodies likely to be affected by treaties. In its supervisory role of the process, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade needs to devote greater attention to consultation with such bodies.'

. 3.7‐10: `The committee believes that the revised processes for treaty‐making are working well, with one exception: consultation with the states and territories. Although no specific action was taken, in both the first and second reports we had concerns about the quantity and quality of some of the consultation which seemed to have taken place with the states and territories in the processes which led to the tabling of treaties and the accompanying National Interest Analyses (NIAs). . . The process of parliamentary scrutiny of treaties was established, in part, to ensure that the views of the states and territories were registered because of their legal responsibilities for some matters about which the Commonwealth Government enters into binding international obligations for Australia. . . Because of these general and specific concerns, the coordinating role of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in consulting with all interested parties on the treaties which come before the committee will receive particular attention in future.'

In response, it should first be noted that a summary of the views of the parties consulted on the terms of a treaty, including the states and territories, is now required in the pro forma for a National Interest Analysis (NIA) for presentation to parliament. Since late 1996, the version provided to line Departments and agencies has included under the Consultation heading: `A relatively detailed statement setting out the consultations that have occurred in relation to the treaty action between the Commonwealth and the states and territories and with community and other interested parties. A summary of the views of these parties should also be included.' Another change recommended in the committee's First Report, provision in NIAs of contact details for the responsible areas of Departments or agencies, has also been acted on in recent tablings. And prompted by the committee's remarks, especially in the fourth report, the Department of Foreign Affairs & Trade has prepared a simplified table of treaty‐making steps—a condensation of relevant sections of the Information Kit (Australia and International Treaty Making ) and Negotiation, Conclusion & Implementation of International Treaties & Arrangements that are already widely distributed—and is making it available to line officials, with reiterated advice on the importance of consultation.

Second, the committee's concern for the adequacy of consultation with the states and territories is noted by the government. In no case that the government is aware of (since the May 1996 reform of the process) has any area of Commonwealth Government failed to inform the states and territories of significant treaty developments, or resisted cross‐jurisdictional co‐operation when the states and territories have sought it. The government would be interested to know of any specific examples the committee may be able to provide in which consultation with the states and territories has been deficient, and especially in which the treaty negotiations have been of sensitivity and importance to the states and territories.

The commonwealth will continue to provide full and early information to the states and territories about treaty negotiations and actions contemplated or underway—but thereafter relies on the other jurisdictions to identify their own interests and to become involved accordingly. There are already several Commonwealth‐State institutions that provide forums for discussion of treaties, both general (notably the Standing Committee on Treaties (SCOT) and the Standing Committee of Attorneys‐General) and subject‐specific (such as the Intergovernmental Committee for Ecologically Sustainable Development, or the Consultative Forum on Mutual Recognition Agreements on Conformity Assessment). The Council of Australian Governments (COAG) established the Treaties Council to consider international instruments of the greatest concern to the states and territories at Head‐of‐Government level. And there is the general principle, spelt out in the Principles & Procedures for Commonwealth‐State Consultation on Treaties agreed on by COAG at its meeting in June 1996, that the states and territories will be fully involved at every stage—from the negotiating mandate through the negotiating delegations to the domestic implementation—for all treaties that they identify as being of sensitivity and importance to themselves.

Third, as to the underlying philosophy of community consultation and the role of the Department of Foreign Affairs & Trade in giving effect to it: consultation in treaty making was the main theme of the government's reform of the process last year. There is no standard formula for adequate consultation (beyond the invitation to states and territories through the SCOT process); Departments and agencies are advised to think widely and carefully about those interested and affected. Different circumstances apply to different instruments, so deliberate duplication was built into the system. Sections of the community with concerns about a treaty or class of treaties are welcome, for example: to contact the Department for information about the status of the instruments in question and to be pointed to the responsible area of the machinery of government; or to develop dialogue with Government Departments about continuing programs; or to make representations through ministers; or to raise concerns through Members of Parliament; or to enlist the states and territories in taking an interest. The responsible officials in line Departments and agencies must identify the main stakeholders for particular treaties—but the safety net for consultation is parliamentary tabling and the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties. It is not a lapse of the process when proposed treaty actions before the committee attract some submissions or evidence that has not already been incorporated in the government's consideration; this is one reason the Trick or Treaty? inquiry recommended such a committee's establishment.

There are several reasons why an NIA might record only limited consultation before a treaty reaches the final and most public forum (that is, parliament): international practice as it relates to the confidentiality of bilateral treaties before signature; the routine nature of the action in question or the fact that the government had not been aware of any particular controversy; a nil response from those invited to contribute; or urgency (not that urgency lessens the eventual requirement for transparency). In the case of the IRRI‐NIA, the government had taken the view that the regularising of the Institute's international status was not directly of concern to the domestic industry—though it is now prepared to accept that it would have been better to seek confirmation from farming and ricegrowing industry bodies before presenting the action to parliament. The Department of Foreign Affairs & Trade ensures a standard format, readily understood prose, and the provision of an appropriate level of detail against all the sub‐headings of the NIA pro forma. Its invariable advice in discussing treaty finalisation with the responsible officials is to remind them that before the binding step is taken, the whole proposed treaty action will be published and scrutinised by the committee, and that the consultation undertaken must therefore be defensible.

—I present the response from the Minister for Foreign Affairs in relation to the resolution of the Senate of 29 May 1997 concerning Nigeria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I of course do not know the contents of the reply of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) at this stage, but this is a very important resolution. It relates to the military dictatorship in Nigeria and the continuing oppression of the Ogoni people. Some 20 community leaders are in gaol and face the potential for summary execution. I now do have a copy of the minister's response, which simply reiterates the points made by Senator Parer back in May. I would have expected that we would get more from the Minister for Foreign Affairs on this matter. It has raised a great deal of concern and horror amongst Australians.

We can all remember that during the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in New Zealand just two years ago, despite world appeals to save the lives of the then eight Ogoni leaders, including Ken Saro-Wiwa—the great poet, community worker and environmentalist of the Ogoni people—General Abacha's dictatorship in Nigeria took them out and hanged all eight of them in front of the world, defying the Commonwealth heads of government. My motion simply said, `Time's up, General Abacha. It is time the Commonwealth governments got tough with you.'

The next meeting is coming up in Britain in September. The Australian and British governments should be saying to the Abacha regime, `There is no place for you at our table.' That is not what we have got back from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. He has ducked the call by this Senate for the Australian government to take sterner action. It is a complicated business. It arises out of the arrival of the Shell oil company in 1958 in Ogoni land and the consequent massive degradation of the homelands of the Ogoni people, with billions of dollars being extracted in profits by that company, but the failure of the return in social welfare and opportunities to the Ogoni people. They have become active because of this. They have rebelled against it in a peaceful manner, but they have been met with repression by the Abacha regime and a totally inadequate response from the Shell oil company, which has been an instigatory factor.

No wonder we now see car stickers on many cars around this country saying `Boycott Shell', `Avoid Shell'. There is a great concern by citizens who are aware of this that the Shell oil company is deeply implicated. That being the case, however, there is a dictatorship which has the hide, in recent times, to be pretending to have a finer side to it as it has moved in to restore what it calls democratic principles in Sierra Leone, just along the way.

That aside, the Ogoni people continue to suffer. There is enormous repression. There is a failure to provide public services. There is continuing environmental degradation. There is great fear by anybody who speaks out. Recently we have had Komene Famaa, the representative of the Ogoni people, brought to Australia by the good offices of the Body Shop, who has spoken at a number of public meetings and shown the harrowing films of the torture, the death, the homeland destruction of the Ogoni people by the oil extraction process. There are over 100 oil wells worked there by Shell and other companies. In particular there is the repression of civil liberties by this nasty and violent and cruel dictatorship of General Abacha.

The best the Minister for Foreign Affairs in this country can do is say, `I can't expand on the words that Senator Parer gave to the Senate a month ago.' What about responding to the motion? The Senate has called on the Australian government to put a block on General Abacha's apparatchiks appearing and sullying the conference in Britain in two months time. What about responding to that, Mr Downer? Well, no such thing.

We get this wimpish response, this one‐sentence throwaway saying, `Don't ask me; Senator Parer said something in the Senate a month ago, and that will do.' It will not do. It is a pretty disgraceful abrogation of the obligation on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to act like a statesperson, to have a bit of spine and to stand up for the Australian sentiment which, as far as I can gauge, is totally with the Ogoni people in their extreme suffering on the other side of the world.

It will not do that we get a cast‐off response to the Senate like this. If we are going to pass motions here which mean something to the Australian government, then we should expect a more considered, in‐depth and thoughtful response at least. But we have not got it. No doubt, Minister Downer has not got it—a little like the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who is currently touring overseas, has not got it. I will guarantee that the plight of the Ogoni people was not brought up while the Prime Minister had afternoon tea yesterday with Baroness Thatcher. It would not suit either of their sensibilities to get into such a topic and determine what they might do about this dastardly lot who are in control—not through the ballot box, but through the gun—in Nigeria.

This is a pretty appalling, pathetic and totally unsatisfactory response that the Senate has been given today. The people of Australia who are concerned about this vile dictatorship in Nigeria will know—from the failure of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, to give a proper response—that he does not care adequately about this situation in a Commonwealth country. Apparently, as Mr Downer sits on his hands, he is going to be invited yet again to sit cheek by jowl with these people while at home their thugs are killing and torturing people and depriving people of their civil rights.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Calvert and the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports: No. 6 of 1997 entitled Decontamination for disposal of the former Albion Explosives Factory site, Deer Park, Victoria , and No. 7 of 1997 entitled Sydney Airport: International Terminal—Olympic upgrading . I seek leave to move a motion relating to the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to have Senator Calvert's tabling statements incorporated in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
The statements read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Decontamination for disposal of the former Albion Explosives Factory site, Deer Park, Melbourne

SPEECH.PARA: Madam President, the first report which I have tabled concerns the proposed decontamination for disposal of the former Albion Explosives Factory site, Deer Park, Melbourne. This project was referred to the Committee in March 1994, but the Committee was unable to report on it for reasons which I will explain later.

The project examined by the Committee involves a proposed agreement between the Department of Defence and the Victorian Urban Land Authority for the decontamination of the site of the former Albion Explosives Factory at Deer Park. This is part of a series of steps which would also allow the Urban Land Authority to develop the 460 hectare site for housing, industrial, retail and community services, setting land aside for nature conservation purposes, for open space and for habitat protection.

The Urban Land Authority will be responsible for the management of decontamination of the site and its development for sale. The return to the Commonwealth would be a series of payments from the Urban Land Authority, based on the value of the land assessed in an uncontaminated state. Under these arrangements, the net cost to Defence for the remaining remediation works was estimated to be $3.84 million.The Committee has recommended that Defence should enter into the proposed arrangements with the Urban Land Authority. The proposal put to the present Committee is vastly different from the earlier proposal. That proposal, referred to the Committee in 1994, was for the decontamination of the site with no development. The cost of the earlier proposal was $57 million—this was in addition to about $15‐20 million which had been spent on cleaning up sixty per cent of the site before it was referred to the Committee.

It was due to the diligence and persistence of the previous Chairman of the Committee—the Honourable Member for Throsby, that these savings to the Commonwealth are now possible. Therefore, the present proposal, estimated to cost $3.84 million, is a marked improvement on the earlier proposal and demonstrates the effectiveness and importance of the Public Works Committee as a watchdog on public expenditure.

The main findings of the Committee's report are that there is a need to decontaminate and remediate the remaining 40 per cent of the Albion Explosives factory site and for total site disposal. Furthermore, any costs to the Commonwealth of decontamination and remediation should be offset against the potential value of the property.

The Committee also concluded that the involvement of the Urban Land Authority as the manager of the cleanup and development of the site can be justified on the basis of expertise and a proven track record. It was suggested that the developer of the site should have been tested on the open market. The Committee considers, however, that the decision by Defence to enter into a single source arrangement with the Urban Land Authority, without testing the market, was based on independent advice to Defence from a number of sources.

Contaminated soil stored on the site or still in situ will be relocated to specially engineered repositories. Based on expert advice, of the remediation options considered, the on‐site repositories are feasible technically, offer the greatest flexibility and have cost advantages. Whilst the Commonwealth will retain the long‐term risk arising from site decontamination, expert advice to the Committee indicated that there will not be any health problems caused by the use of on‐site repositories.The question of responsibility for monitoring the repositories remains unresolved and the Committee has therefore recommended that this responsibility should be assigned to relevant State authorities at the time of the finalisation of the formal agreement for the remediation, disposal and development of the site by Defence and the Urban Land Authority.
A Preliminary Land Use Plan for the entire site has been developed. This plan will need to be further refined into a Local Structure Plan under the Brimbank Planning Scheme.

Under the proposal, the State of Victoria will assume ownership of a large amount of parkland to be managed by the Victoria University of Technology. For this reason, the Committee has recommended that in land transfer negotiations between the Commonwealth and the State of Victoria the significant improvement to public amenity arising from the transfer should be recognised. The Committee has also recommended that any additional costs associated with infrastructure improvements on land designated for public use should not be the responsibility of the Commonwealth.

A large proportion of an area designated as parkland is the habitat of the endangered Legless Lizard. The Committee was assured that relevant Commonwealth environment protection agencies are satisfied that the process involved in the progressive sale will adequately provide for Commonwealth commitments relating to the protection of endangered species on the site.

Very little of the old explosives factory buildings remain. The Committee has recommended that apart from tree lines and the black powder mill, all existing structures on the site should be demolished as they present a potential health and safety hazard. A management regime will need to be developed for the black powder mill.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sydney Airport: International Terminal—Olympic Upgrading Proposal

SPEECH.PARA: The second report which I have tabled involves the proposed Sydney Airport: International Terminal—Olympic upgrading proposal.
The proposal examined by the Committee involves the provision of additional terminal facilities required to meet the expected demand by 2003. In summary, these facilities are:
ten additional aircraft parking positions;
extensions to the aircraft taxiway system;
new airside departure lounges and associated retail facilities at Piers B and C;
additional check‐in and baggage claim facilities; and
associated building works and related engineering and building services improvements.
An elemental cost plan prepared for the project provides for a design and construction cost at completion of approximately $350 million.
The Committee's inquiry extended over two days, taking evidence from a variety of organisations and individuals and noting carefully comments made by local government and community groups.
Witnesses were asked a series of standard questions to elicit their response to the fundamental issue under consideration, namely the future of Sydney Airport.

Faced with the increased demand on the international terminal, that a decision on the second airport has not been made and that construction of any new facilities must be completed by the end of 1999, what choice does the Committee have other than to recommend that the work proceed.

The so‐called "do nothing" option is not feasible. To do nothing would result in a decline in the level of service to passengers and compromise the efficient operation of the terminal. In terms of aircraft, the option would result in aircraft possibly waiting for an hour or an hour and a half on taxiways before accessing aircraft parking positions. Inside the Customs hall, passengers could be left waiting for up to two hours for their baggage. Clearly, this is unacceptable.
Against this background, the report concludes:
First, that Sydney Airport, as the main gateway to Australia, has an essential role in meeting increasing passenger demand into the next century.
Secondly, as no decision on the location of a second Sydney airport has yet been made, Sydney Airport remains the only international airport in NSW.
Thirdly, if the improvements required to cater for increased traffic are not made, the ability of the airport to cope with demand will be seriously impeded.
Fourthly, the timing of the Olympics and its associated pressures on facilities mean that any improvements will need to commence immediately in order to avoid construction during the Olympic period.
Finally, forecasts provided by the Federal Airports Corporation indicate that ten additional gate positions and associated facilities are required which would satisfy requirements until 2003.

The Committee concluded that the success of the project is dependent on continuing and adequate consultations between the Federal Airports Corporation and all affected users. In this context, particular attention should be given to the needs of people with disabilities during the detailed design phases.

The report notes that a large proportion of the cost of the proposed investment will be offset by increased revenue expected from retail operations. The Committee was assured by the Federal Airports Corporation of the commercial viability of the project.

There is one matter about which the report is critical of the Federal Airports Corporation. The proposal had not received the required clearances by relevant Commonwealth environment protection authorities before it was referred to the Committee.

Many of the issues raised by local government authorities and community groups regarding the impact of further development and the Federal Airports Corporation's responses to them, should have been the subject of environmental impact assessment and subsequent clearance by protection authorities before the public hearing.

The Federal Airports Corporation was in the process of preparing a Notice of Intent, which it intended lodging with Environment Australia some time after the hearing. The Committee believes the Federal Airports Corporation proceeded on an erroneous assumption that the timing of environmental clearances could await the Committee's consideration of the proposal.

It was stated by the FAC that issues raised during the Committee's inquiry would be taken into account in the preparation of the impact assessment. The Committee does not see itself as a substitute for an appropriate environmental assessment of any proposal.
This responsibility rests with proponents complying in a timely manner with the provisions of the Act before proposals are referred to the Committee.
The Committee has therefore recommended that any further development of Sydney Airport should have appropriate environmental clearances before being referred to it.
I commend both reports to the Senate.
Debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, along with a number of senators from the opposition, am conscious of the time and the particular stage we are at in the parliamentary cycle—this being the last week. I seek leave to incorporate my remarks on this legislation in Hansard . I understand that the government whip has agreed to that request.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
APPROPRIATIONS
The unwritten sub text to this bill is about the failure of this government to come to terms with its national responsibilities.

A subtext underlined by a government which promised honesty, integrity and accountability but delivered lies, deceit and secrecy—a government committed to the trickle down effect, determined to implement a far right agenda that directs govern ment resources away from those in need, away from Australian families.

A government whose policy direction is in shambles. A government wreaked by internal tension and indecision. A government whose total preoccupation with the powers of the market is rapidly delivering plummeting consumer confidence, declining national standards and escalating unemployment.
A government who has totally abandoned the pretext of any commitments that they gave to the Australian public in the last election.
DEETYA—THE BIG LOSER
I wish to speak specifically on the effects of the budget on the programs administered by DEETYA.
What we see contained in this Appropriation Bill is a total abandonment of urgency in the Governments effort to tackle the question of unemployment—particularly youth unemployment.
We see a total abandonment of national responsibility for ensuring quality and equity for the whole gamut of educational provision.
We see an abandonment of Commonwealth responsibility for growth funding for schools, TAFE and universities.
Further, we see a continuation of an arrogant and irresponsible attitude towards the education community, an attitude which sees policy replaced by rhetoric and leadership replaced by dishonesty.
CUTS IN 1997—98
On May 2nd, the Minister said quite categorically that `there would be no bad news for the education sector' in the 1997 budget—no bad news!
What have we seen—further cuts to universities and TAFE and the abandonment of support for a quality, public, national mass education system.
We have seen:

. A further 4700 undergraduate places abolished through the phasing out of the Higher Education Commonwealth Industry Places Scheme. This reduction, of $67.4 million over 4 years, will weaken universities, particularly regional universities' ability to establish strong industry links and funding sources.
. we see a further $72 million cut from vocational education and training.
. A further 1% cut in university funding on top of the $400 million cut announced in the 1996-97 budget.
. The unilateral removal of growth funding for VET
. we see the phasing out of 4.5 million over 4 years in specific funding to Language Australia—,
. 38.7 million over 4 years cuts to Abstudy,
. $11.2 million from NBEET's abolition—of course we are still to see the legislation debated in the Senate and the list goes on.

Despite widespread community concern and turmoil in the education sector we have seen a budget which not only totally fails to come to grips with the problems but which further exacerbates those problems—totally contrary to the pre-budget statements of the Minister.
The Federal Government's policies at the primary, secondary and tertiary levels are designed to shrink the public sector and promote the private.

Clearly, despite misleading media reports and deceptive statements by the Ministers, these measures will result in a market of `advantage'—promoting advantage for the privileged few and resulting in disadvantage for the many.
VOCATIONAL EDUCATION
The deception of the government is no more evident than in VET funding.

Last week I asked Senator Vanstone about the findings of the KPMG consultants report, Costing and Resourcing of New Apprenticeships, Senator Vanstone was unable to respond, she knows, as does the rest of the community, that assertions made by the government about growth in the sector are largely unjustified and unfunded.

The KPMG report states that resources must be lifted from the current 20% to as much as 30-40% of the Vocational Education budget to meet what is expected to be projected demand. That means an increase of $400-$500 million needs to be found to fund the Government's New Apprenticeships scheme.

Given that this report has been canvassed extensively at the recent Senate Estimates and has created an uproar with State Education Ministers in Darwin on Wednesday June 11 and Thursday June 12, the Senator's feigned ignorance of the report is astounding.
Senator Vanstone knows that the Commonwealth has budgeted no more money for TAFE than that required to pay normal entitlements to trainees and employers.
It will be the states, who have already had their Financial Assistance Grants slashed, who must now be responsible for funding growth in the National Vocational Education System.
A prospect that according to the states is completely untenable.
The states rightly point out that they have already lost millions of dollars that were provided by the Keating government's labour market programs.
As well TAFE will lose its virtual monopoly of government funded training to private providers from the start of next year.

And yet Dr Kemp continues to make misleading statements. Promising 100,000 new apprenticeships in 1997/98 when he knows that the Commonwealth is only funding an additional 9000 new apprenticeships on top of the 91,000 apprenticeships in already existing programs.

Promising an additional 500,000 TAFE places—places which are to be funded by state governments. State governments that have just suffered an `efficiency gain' cut to their budgets of an additional $70 million over 4 years on top of last years cut of $183 million and the unilateral scrapping of $70 million in growth funding.

Is it any wonder that following the recent Ministerial Council in Darwin, State Ministers collectively criticised Dr Kemp's conduct. Accusing him of `smoke and mirrors' tricks with the national media by implying that the Commonwealth was contributing more to TAFE than was actually the case.

The Victorian Minister Phil Honeywood has stated that `The hypocrisy is there for all to see'. . . . .That his colleagues were `aghast' at Kemp's press release and the way he had carried on television.
But this isn't the end of government deception in regard to the lack funding for their Vocational education announcements. . . .

On June 3rd at the hearing of the Employment, Education and Training Senate Estimates Committee Minister Vanstone, in her defence of Dr Kemp, misinformed the committee about the government's aborted plans to introduce a HECS style system into Vocational Education and Training (VET).
She did it both in her own words, and by her silence about the apparently misleading answers given by Mr Moran, the CEO of ANTA.

On this specific issue of HECS fees and in response to my highlighting the section of the KPMG report which stated `In the future, the option of deferred payment through a HECS type scheme might be examined when the market benefit of VET qualifications is widely recognised', Mr Moran responded:
Just a view from the consultant, which simply has not been considered . . . it has not been considered by ANTA and as far as I am aware, it has not been considered by ministers.
Minister Vanstone was invited to respond and in her response she gave what is at best a misleading answer.

Senator Vanstone: I can tell you that I certainly have not asked for anything to be prepared on it to assist my mind on it, and I can assure you that Dr Kemp has not either. Whether there is someone out there who aspires to having both either or both either or both of our jobs cooking up a scheme to have this raised, I cannot tell you, but I can tell you that I have not asked for it to be considered, and Dr Kemp has not asked for any work on it to be considered, so that is about as conclusive as I can be for you.'
Even more was to be confirmed about the Commonwealth's supposed total ignorance of any plans for HECS in TAFE.
Mr Moran:
There was no consideration of changing fees paid by students, either in its own right or as a means of finding a contribution to the figure to which you refer.

But this was far from the truth and it was left to the Victorian Liberal Party Minister for Training to expose this deceit, claiming on June 11 following the Darwin MINCO meeting that there were secret plans to introduce new TAFE fees.
In the words of Phil Honeywood Dr Kemp had committed `a betrayal of trust' over plans to expand the number of tertiary places.
On the issue of `consensus', Phil Honeywood assessed the views of state ministers stating that:
There is a complete sense of frustration that Dr Kemp is a centralist who does not acknowledge the part states play in funding training I feel there is a betrayal of trust.
Mr Honeywood stated that:
David Kemp tabled a report that envisaged a HECS fee being introduced for students.
He said:
Victoria moved successfully, with the support of other states, that a HECS fee for TAFE students not be supported.
Mr Honeywood clarified the situation further in the Age on Friday 13 June. In a vicious attack of the Commonwealth government's TAFE funding plans, Mr Honeywood claimed that:
..it may lead to the dismantling of the system and the introduction of university-style fees.
Mr Honeywood said:
Victoria did not agree to the conditions under which the Federal Government proposed to continue its normal funding. That's why the resolution says we disagree,
he said, describing yesterday's meeting between the states and Dr Kemp as `extremely heated'.

Mr Honeywood further called into question Dr Kemp's motives, saying that at a recent meeting of Training Ministers, Dr Kemp had tabled an Australian National Training Authority document that canvassed a `deferred payment mechanism' for TAFEs.

Dr Kemp's spokesman replied by saying that, the training authority document was as much the states' document as it was the Commonwealth's, and said it was Dr Kemp who had said the `deferred payment' clause should be removed because it was inaccurate and he had not such plan.

Dr Kemp, also tried to weasel out of the situation by claiming that it was he who had personally moved to have reference to the fee plan scrapped from the report—a report which was written by the government's vocational education adviser—ANTA.
What does Mr Honeywood say about this proposition?

Mr Honeywood said that at the ministers' only meeting in May, where the document was tabled, Dr Kemp had argued the clause should stay. It was after states protested that—as chairman of the committee—he proposed the clause be removed.

He said the federal plan was viewed by the states as a way of forcing them to deliver up to 40 per cent more TAFE places (there are now 1.2 million nationally) with no extra funds from the Commonwealth.

What we have here is not only a prima facie case that the Commonwealth's Vocational Education Program is in disarray, that Dr Kemp plays fast and lose with the truth, but that Senator Vanstone and Mr Moran, the CEO of ANTA apparently misled Senate Estimates.
He apparently misled Senate Estimates on an issue as basic as the Commonwealth's ability to fund their plans for the VET sector and their proposal to introduce a deferred payment scheme for TAFE.
This is a very serious issue which requires the Minister to respond promptly to the request from the Senate Employment, Education and Training Committee for an explanation.
SCHOOLS EDUCATION
It is in the area of schools education where the ideological bent of this government is most evident. Where the market approach is encouraged and equity is outlawed as a socialist concept.
Where the principle of universal free public education is abandoned and our public schools left to die the death of a thousand cuts.
What we see in the schools area are policies designed to fundamentally undermine the traditional long standing commitment of all governments to a quality education for all students.
In schools, as in VET, we have seen DEETYA officials and the state governments expose the hypocrisy of the government.
Dr Kemp proclaimed on May 13th that there would be a `$152 million boost for schools'.

The truth is that this figure comprises around $108 million automatically built-in for inflation, $41 million for increases in enrolment, and a further $25 million to fulfil a promise of the previous government to needier schools. Net result? A real cut in schools funding! And how was this word trickery explained by departmental officials at the recent round of Budget estimates? It was described as `the best presentational gloss on the normal operating of government.'

It is in the area of funding support for government schools that Dr Kemp's rhetoric has been most exposed. State Education Ministers, Liberal, National and Labor have publicly supported Labor's consistent stance that the Enrolment Benchmark Adjustment will be a disaster for public school systems.

Even the Minister's own department has confirmed that through the EBA, $26.763 million will be cut from public education this financial year and some $270 million over the forward estimates to the year 1999-2000.
Another public exclamation by Dr Kemp, not supported by specific funding measures was that schools would benefit from a further $200 million to act as labour exchanges.

Upon closer examination at Senate Estimates, it was revealed that very few schools would actually get any money under the program at all, they would simply be allowed to tender for the service on the open market, in competition with many established, specialists providers.
UNEMPLOYMENT—`BE PATIENT SAYS THE MINISTER'

In regard to tackling unemployment, there is little in this budget to give hope to those who are long term unemployed. It is an inditement of this government that unemployment continues to rise and jobs decline.
This month we have seen labour force figures which show a loss of 40,300 jobs in one month- 33,100 full time.

This months unemployment figures show that there are now 242,5000 long term unemployed people in Australia—the highest number in two years. This is not surprising to us on this side of the chamber, we said this would be the result of the government's reckless dismantling of Working Nation programs a year ago.
In the last 15 months since the Howard Government came to office we have seen:
- the number of full time jobs has actually fallen by 700
- the number of male full time jobs has fallen by 9900
- the number of people unemployed has risen by 39,000
- unemployment rate has risen from 8.5% to 8.8%
- and most importantly in regard to the promises made at the last election, youth unemployment rate has risen from 27.4% to 27.5%.
