SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I am not one given to rendering my remarks in this chamber in writing.
—A brilliant speech. It was a brilliant speech.
—I am sure that what you have written, Senator Carr, is a brilliant speech. I look forward to reading it in Hansard to be overawed by its brilliance.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the appropriation bills, which is an opportunity for senators in this place to express their views about the last budget. As Senator Carr has said, because of the time constraints placed upon us in this chamber my remarks will need to be brief and will be given in summary form—unfortunately, I will not be able to develop my arguments in full—in order to save the necessary time for other legislation.

Let me say up‐front what the opposition's view of this budget is, and, in particular, what major failings it has. This is an extraordinary, lacklustre budget. It was off the front pages of the newspapers by the Friday of the week in which it was brought down. It is the only budget I know of that registered a less than one-third approval rating with the public. Less than one-third of the public approved of this document. It also generated about a four per cent fall in the approval rating of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard).

So it should have done, because it did nothing to improve employment and it really did nothing to improve national savings—one of the areas targeted for this budget. When the government targeted national savings they went off and brought back a scheme that leads to national dissaving. It is a budget which continues the attack on families that occurred in the last budget. It is a budget that continues with further mindless cuts to various government programs that should stimulate demand in the community. It is a budget that got the thumbs down from the financial markets because it failed to actually go about its job in the way in which it boasted it would before the budget, raising expectations which, when we saw the actual document, were dashed.

This budget comes behind the major cost cutting budget—the first budget for the conservatives after 13 years of Labor rule in this nation—brought down last year. That budget made massive cuts to Commonwealth expenditure. The effect of that was to contract domestic demand in the economy and slow down growth of the economy. The purpose of the budget before last was not to expand or grow the economy, create opportunities for employment, deal with the long queue of unemployed and offer job prospects in growth industries and attractive and interesting highly skilled and well trained technically proficient jobs across industry; it was to contract domestic economic growth. That was the impact of the massive cuts that the government made in public sector outlays set down in the budget.

This budget—the one we are now debating—followed on in that course. The strategy behind the last budget and this budget is that the world economy is growing relatively strongly—in particular, the economies of the Asia-Pacific area are growing startlingly strongly—and that Australia, despite having a contractionary domestic budget, will be pulled through and our economy will grow because of the strength of the international economy. That was the thinking behind it.

When we look at the outcome of this last budget we see that the target for the 1996‐97 budget for economic growth in this nation was 3.5 per cent. But we find that at the end of one year of coalition rule the growth level was in fact 2.4 per cent—that is, the government forecast about 1.1 per cent more for economic growth than they achieved. In other words, the strategy behind the budget did not work and did not deliver the growth outcomes that they expected.

The contraction in the domestic economy was so great that we saw that last month's Yellow Pages survey of small business opinion found that 80 per cent of small business people in Australia believed that there was a lack of confidence for them in the future of the economy, that the demand would not be there to justify them having a rosier view of the prospects for Australia. The fact that the government underscored its growth rate has permeated the economic thinking and the confidence levels in the community.

I want to say today that there are a number of things that the government can do to improve unemployment. We know that jobs are being lost at the present time in Australian industry. Australian industry is in job shedding mode. Last month 40,000 jobs were lost in Australia, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The biggest failure in the first budget and in this budget is that there is no strategy in place at all to focus on unemployment. In fact, the amount of attention given to the problem of unemployment—the problem recognised in Australia as the most serious economic problem of all—is a few meagre lines hidden away in the documentation that accompanies the budget papers. There is no direct attack on that problem.

Labor has four basic strategies for what can be done about unemployment. The first is that the budget has to be a budget for growth, not a budget for contraction. We believe that the budget should be set not to achieve 3½ per cent growth, as it is, but rather to achieve greater growth, of 4 and 4½ per cent, so that school leavers will have jobs to go to at the end of the year.

Shooting for a 3.5 or 3.75 per cent growth rate, as the budget does, means that the government has made a deliberate choice not to grow the economy at a level to provide work for school leavers or diminish the unemployment queue. The Australian economy should grow at 4 and 4½ per cent to make a dent on unemployment. The fact that the government have not done that means they have chosen to continue with their contractionary line of the past.

The budget also has been more restrictive than it could have been and should have been with respect to monetary policy. I must say that the government will boast about its record on monetary policy and the number of cuts that have been achieved for interest rates, but the economy is still flat and the first interest rate reduction was three or four months later than it should have been. It was late because of the Reserve Bank's anxiety about the implication of the government clearing up the accord and abandoning wages policy. It is certainly arguable that the Reserve Bank, with the direct support of the government, has been overly focused on its statutory anti-inflationary objective and insufficiently attentive to its pro‐employment statutory objective as well. I make the point that monetary policy could have been set more effectively and, if it was, growth would have come sooner.

I think we ought to do more to hitch onto external demand. As I said, the underlying philosophy of the two budgets has been that world growth is going strongly and therefore Australia will benefit. But when you actually look at what the budget does, you see that the things that connect us to economic growth have been cut back or dismantled. Austrade has been cut back in its total expenditure, crimping the ability of our trade agency to find openings for Australians and Australian companies that wish to sell abroad and export, earning foreign credits for Australia.

As well, the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference is now to be abandoned—a conference which has a proven record of generating massive income for this country. Our showcase of Australian industry to the world—the sort of thing one ought to do to connect Australia to the international economy and the growth levels to be achieved there—is now to be abandoned and, we are told at some time in the future, privatised. The only conclusion one can come to is that this government is not interested in promoting Australian industry to the world market.

BREAK.PARA: We know from the previous budget that the export market development grants scheme has been cut back. Now a cap has been opposed for the total funding of that scheme. The government persists in maintaining that situation. Therefore, support for Australian exporters to win contracts abroad are circumscribed and limited at the very time we need to grow our export market much higher. In terms of opening up new markets, we have had from the government this cute little phrase of `aggressive bilateralism'. When I explored the detail of aggressive bilateralism at the Senate economics committee that dealt with budget estimates we got back a fair range of hollow answers—answers that did not explain what the achievements of this policy had been.

The only conclusion one can come to is that this is some sort of slogan but a slogan which does not have any direct impact on getting Australian goods and services into foreign markets where there are market obstructions to access. The record of so-called aggressive bilateralism, which is touted as the solution to our trade woes, is in fact a sorry record indeed. The only example I know of any like success was with the negotiations that the government engaged in with the United States automobile producers over Howe Leather. But that set our cause back, not forward.

In summary, the underlying structure of what this government can do to connect Australian industry, to hitch its wagon, to the star of massive growth in Asian economies has been demolished. The connection is not there. Australian industry confidence is down as a consequence. We are missing out on the opportunities of growth in this region because of that and, in doing so, Australians are out of work as a knock‐on effect of the indolence of this government.

The fourth thing that the government should have installed in this budget in order to attack the primary problem of unemployment was a conscious commitment to improving the nation's skills base. It has still not done so. That means not destroying university funding and not having a HEC scheme deterring people from higher education. It means not running down our state school system in Australia. It means having effective labour market programs that will provide real job experience, real training and a real psychological boost for those who might otherwise become permanently welfare dependent.

It means all of those things, but, in essence, my message is that there are four major points that the government should have implemented in this budget which have been ignored. The budget is not a budget that deals with unemployment; it is a budget that neglects that key issue. It is a budget that proposes changes to national savings, as I said earlier, and other senators have covered that in considerable detail, so I do not need to repeat their contributions to this debate.

The net effect of the government's initiative on national savings is in fact to reduce the potential for national savings that would have flowed had the government stuck with the scheme of the former government and developed the relationship between national savings and individual superannuation contributions of workers. Had it done that, we would have developed a much bigger and much more impressive national savings pool which would have enabled Australian investors to own Australian industry and enabled Australia to invest in the growth of Australian industry.

The fact that the savings proposal put forward by the government has been universally rubbished by the markets and by commentators is some indication of the government's failure to actually address this issue. What they have is a bandaid in place to try to stop the haemorrhage of a major wound in the economy. They have done away with all of the other stitching and all of the other bandages to solve this problem. They have cut them free and tried to put a bandaid there that will fix it. It will not. The problem is far greater than they recognise. Touting the national savings initiative around as some sort of answer has got a hollow laugh from all of the economists in this country.

National savings is a problem for Australia. We do not generate enough savings in this country to invest in the development of our nation. We are net importers of capital. We are not exporters of capital to the world in net terms. The sooner we can generate a level of national savings and a pool of national savings in order to start to own our own industry sector, the sooner we can start to see better, more solid and more sustained economic growth in this country. Labor had that structure in place. This government has dismantled it. The people who will suffer most because of that are the unemployed and those who are soon to be unemployed because of these things.

There are a lot of things I would want to say in this debate, but my time is limited. I conclude my remarks at this point by reminding the Senate that, if we are going to hitch our wagon to the star of the fast growing East Asian economies, we ought to do more about promoting trade to those sectors, not cutting it back. This budget cuts it back.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —This budget and, indeed, the policies of this government remind me of an event that took place over the weekend. SPEECH.PARA: This government relies upon a faith in the market. This government has said as much many times—that it is freeing up the market. he asks, tongue in cheek—

Isn't that true? Isn't that exactly what has been happening in this country? This is the way Australian universities are being forced to go under this government.

The 1996‐97 budget cut higher education by $1.8 billion, putting a university education out of the reach of many low‐income people. Changes to HECS—the higher education contribution scheme—has meant differential charges for courses. This will mean that low‐income students will choose cheaper courses or will give up on study altogether. This budget cuts $14.3 million from vocational and industry training, and another $72 million from education and training grants to states. That is on top of the $183 million worth of cuts in last year's budget. The government cannot continue to keep cutting in the vital areas of industry training and education for it not to have an effect. Growth in apprenticeships is the perfect example—the number of apprenticeships have actually fallen. The rate of growth in traineeships fell from 117 per cent in Labor's last year in office to 68 per cent during Prime Minister Howard's first year in office.

Unemployment has grown steadily since this government came to power. The government says that it wants teenagers to get jobs, yet they have cut employment programs that have been proven to work. If there is one issue that I feel Australians should be angry about, it is that in last year's budget the government cut more than 230,000 training places by taking $1.8 billion from labour market programs. That was a significant reduction in a proven way of tackling the problem of long‐term unemployed people. It is little wonder that the unemployment rate has risen to 8.8 per cent while the growth rate is 3¾per cent. We know it is far lower than the four per cent growth which is the minimum requirement to tackle unemployment. These figures represented a fall of 40,000 in the number of jobs in May, wiping out all the growth of the last six months.

The depression that exists in people's minds across Australia and the insecurity that people feel in this country are a direct result of these cuts that are occurring. It is not good enough for the coalition government, led by Prime Minister Howard, to try to confuse the issue. The cuts I am describing are of millions of dollars. The programs have gone.

Next week we will have increased prices for things from the pharmacy; a trip to the chemist will cost more. Next week you have got the next episode in the process of putting a burden on family members. Next week many Australians will realise that they are completely disadvantaged when they have to go to the chemist. Pharmaceutical costs, even for pensioners, will be greatly increased.

That reminds me of the threat to the older members of the community that this government represents. I do not know of any greater insecurity than that many people face because nursing homes are allowed to charge whatever they can get away with. This is now the government's approach to people who are old. We estimate the average home entry fee will be about $30,000, but could be as high as $88,000. The Uniting Church estimated it could be up to $200,000.

We know that, if one person has to go into a nursing home, the family will have to face the tension of selling the family home. For the people in the twilight period of their life in the family that is the epitaph that this government is going to give them—the threat that they will have to make a decision to sell the family home. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start my contri bution to this debate on the appropriation bills by focusing on the cuts to the ABC, specifically those to Radio Australia. The ABC has had its budget drastically cut by $55 million, reducing its base funding to $468 million. That move ignores the government's own inquiry which recommended that the base funding for the ABC be no less than $500 million for broadcasting networks.

SPEECH.PARA: Why did the government do that? The obvious answer is because the government hates the ABC. It has a real problem with anything that might constitute criticism of government policy. Put simply: the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and other cabinet ministers believe the ABC has predictable views on a range of causes, lacks a prominent conservative commentator and, basically, is hostile to the coalition.

It is difficult to tell, though, how long the government has harboured this terrible antipathy towards the ABC. Certainly, none of the treatment the ABC has suffered since this government was elected was flagged in the coalition's election policy on the ABC called `Better broadcasting'. In fact, if you read `Better broadcasting', you would have thought that this government was in favour of the ABC, in favour of independent broadcasting and in favour of Radio Australia and ATV in particular. That is what it says in that policy. That is what it says will be one of the things it will be committed to when it gets into government. Well, that is not what has happened.

In hindsight, it appears that the government—or at least certain elements of it—has harboured malignant grudges against the ABC for some time. We should have remembered that the Prime Minister would not be part of the pre-election debates as long as Kerry O'Brien was the compere. I am sure that all ABC viewers and listeners will remember that next time they vote. Prime Ministers Hawke and Keating also demonstrated their dislike for the ABC when the Labor governments cut the ABC's funding during their terms in office.

Especially in this day and age, it is impossible to sustain an argument that the ABC and all those who work for it are lefties and, therefore, are antagonistic towards the coalition. A more realistic thesis is the one which suggests that the ABC is prepared to be critical of government approved actions and policy, is willing to investigate those issues and is willing to report on them. In short: the ABC upholds its charter obligations by `providing an innovative and comprehensive broadcasting and television service of a high standard . . . that contributes to a sense of national identity and informs and entertains, and reflects the cultural diversity of the Australian community'.

Even the government's own inquiry into the ABC conducted by Mr Bob Mansfield found that the ABC was not biased. Mr Mansfield, who is now special policy adviser to the Prime Minister, found that the ABC enjoyed a reputation in the Australian community, the likes of which most companies would envy. He recognised the special relationship the ABC has with its audiences—and its audiences are very large.

Mr Mansfield came to at least one conclusion which was based on no evidence whatsoever. He proposed that the ABC divest itself of its international broadcasting responsibilities and concentrate on domestic broadcasting. This recommendation was made without any community consultation and without his inquiry even having it as a term of reference.

By the time I requested correspondence in relation to RA and ATV be tabled, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and the Prime Minister had received 574 letters and 357 e‐mail messages about the closure of Radio Australia and ATV. Not one of those letters congratulated the government on its decision to stop the service; they were all against the decision to stop the service. I did not even ask for the letters, e‐mails and all the rest of it that had been sent to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer). I am sure there are even far more there.

Goodwill is spread by Radio Australia and Australia Television throughout this region. RA and ATV help create an awareness in the region of Australia. The divesting of these services is a breach of the government's policy commitment to the ABC and to international broadcasting. Radio Australia in particular is able to provide information on regional and domestic issues in areas where state‐operated broadcasters provide no independent broadcasting service whatsoever. Those are the sentiments in the letters received by those two ministers.

E‐mail messages were received mostly from Western industrialised countries while handwritten letters came predominantly from Asian countries. What we can read from that is that wealthy countries have access to new technologies and access to their means of purchase—that is not surprising—and that those living in poorer countries do not share that luxury. But the minister maintains that short wave is a dying technology. That snapshot clearly demonstrates just how wrong he is.

Several of those countries are run by autocratic and undemocratically elected officials who deny their people access to new technology, such as computers and satellite dishes. Those governments know their power. They are not about to allow open and free access to broadcasting services when the people on those services seek to criticise them.

At the eleventh hour, the government agreed not to destroy Radio Australia for the time being at least, not least because of the huge demonstration of public support for the ABC from overseas and from within our own shores. That was demonstrated at the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade inquiry into RA and ATV. But even so, from next week—from 1 July—Radio Australia will speak in fewer languages, with reduced information and with a quieter voice. As one person who wrote to that Senate standing committee inquiry said:
We will whisper to the world.

Radio Australia will speak in fewer languages because, along with a 54 per cent cut in staff numbers, it will no longer provide the Cantonese service. We also lose the French service. Mandarin, Indonesian and Vietnamese services are reduced. Khmer and Tok Pisin services are retained, but only because the ABC itself stepped in with funding for them—and goodness knows where it got that from. The government wanted to retain English and Tok Pisin only, ignoring the pleas from foreign governments to retain greater services.

RA will speak in a quieter voice because the most powerful of the short‐wave transmitters—the one on the Cox Peninsula in Darwin—will be closed down from 30 June 1997. The minister made this decision happily because:
. . . when I discovered that the service could be mothballed and reopened at very short notice, it became apparent to me that we were able to proceed with the original proposal—
that is to close down that service—
but still accommodate any subsequent interest that might be registered.

Is that a good enough reason to shut down the Cox Peninsula transmitter? No, of course it is not. The government has spent almost $12 million in the past five years on this world‐class short‐wave facility. The world's major international broadcasters know its value, and are literally queuing up in the hope of leasing transmission time for access to the region. And Australia is moving out so the government can save $1.6 million.

The government is also saving $3.5 million by the sale of Australia Television. By closing our international broadcasting service, as we are, we are symbolically pulling up the drawbridge. It must cause concern that this affluent nation, seeking its place in the region as a friendly neighbour and a host, as a trading partner and as an honest broker, cannot afford to maintain or expand the cheapest and most effective form of public diplomacy that we have.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) claims that Australia is committed to the region in the long term, but even his plea to maintain Radio Australia could only guarantee funding for this financial year. What will happen next year is anybody's guess. The foreign affairs minister also claims that some people are promoting an insular Australia—inward‐looking, narrow‐minded, and separate from the region. Was he thinking of some of his own cabinet colleagues when he said that? I would suggest yes. Or was he thinking of his own department's budget cuts?

BREAK.PARA: For instance, Australian overseas aid has been cut by 13 per cent over two years, resulting in the lowest overseas development aid to GNP ratio in living memory. This budget's three per cent overall cut masks the huge cuts to the neediest regions. Aid to Africa has been cut by 13 per cent, totalling 25 per cent over two years. South Asia, the region with the largest number of poor, has been cut by 18 per cent over two years. Aid to UN development agencies, such as UNICEF, the UN Development Program and the UN Environment Program, has been drastically cut over the last two years. Australia's withdrawal from UN agencies reflects a lack of commitment to international cooperation in resolving complex global issues. These cuts, and other budget policy decisions, create a picture of a country with a reduced commitment to equity, to our region and to multilateral solutions to global problems. And, of course, that is not just in the ABC or DFAT.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the statutory authority with a mandate to promote respect for, and observance of, human rights is primarily responsible for administering the Commonwealth's anti‐discrimination legislation. Central aspects of HREOC's functions include the handling and conciliation of discrimination complaints, education and advocacy, research into systemic forms of discrimination, and advising governments on legislation and policy affecting human rights and discrimination issues.

HREOC is also responsible for overseeing Australia's obligations under seven key international human rights instruments. HREOC's budget has just been slashed by 43 per cent over the next two years. You have to ask yourself if it is because the government does not want to hear from those agencies that do not agree with it. It does not want to hear from an agency that suggests that the Wik plan may contravene our international obligations. It does not want to hear that the position of women, the disabled, Aboriginals and those of a non‐English speaking background is not any better under this government's restrictive budgetary measures. It does not want to hear that the number of race complaints has dramatically increased since the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) and the race issue became prominent.

In a healthy functioning democracy, we should place great emphasis on institutions and organisations that monitor and protect human rights. In international terms, Australia has had a relatively good human rights record. One of the reasons for that is that we used to be universally acknowledged as having an independent commission that could administer and inquire into laws that monitor and protect against abuses. Human rights abuses do not just include violence, discrimination or vilification, although they certainly do include those things. They also include ignoring people and not catering for their needs. It is a sad indictment of our political system that those groups which seem to have the loudest and the best‐funded voices are the ones that appear to have more access to government. HREOC exists for all Australians and is especially needed by those who are not necessarily loud or well funded. The recent cuts to HREOC will serve only to limit its role.

It is now becoming clear through questioning at estimates hearings exactly what these cuts will mean to Australia's human rights watchdog. In real terms, the cuts will exponentially increase the delays in the handling of complaints of discrimination. There will necessarily be an abandonment of major research and development projects directed at reducing and eliminating discrimination and abuse of those classes of persons protected by federal human rights and anti‐discrimination law. There will be an abandonment of or, at the very least, a significant reduction in the public educational activities directed towards reducing and eliminating discrimination and abuses of those classes of persons protected by federal human rights and anti‐discrimination law. There will be a loss of 60 skilled and experienced staff from the commission. The Australian Democrats are disgusted by the cuts to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.
Let me conclude by adding my support to the views of People with Disabilities (NSW). In a letter to Senator Allison, that organisation wrote:

We believe that the cuts are motivated by an unstated policy of the government to dismantle those structures which protect the rights and interests of vulnerable minorities within the Australian community. Indeed, it is difficult to resist the view that the severity of the cuts constitute a `punishment' of the Commission by the government for its entirely proper criticisms of federal government policies adversely affecting the rights and interests of protected classes, in particular refugees, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and people with disabilities.

I could not agree with that more. It must appear to anyone watching from outside the cabinet room that this government does not work by policy. It works by prejudice, by polling and by personal vindictiveness. I hope I am wrong, but it certainly looks like that to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the second reading debate on the appropriation bills for 1997, I would like to thank all senators who have contributed to the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate last night I did hear a comment made by Senator McKiernan—I think it might have been just before a quorum was called—that the budget for 1997‐98 was so bad that no coalition senators wanted to contribute to the debate on it. I know it was a fairly frivolous remark by Senator McKiernan, who has a very well developed sense of humour which I appreciate as much as most. For the record, coalition senators have shown great restraint in speaking on government legislation over the last few months in order to ensure that a very heavy legislative reform program finds passage through the Senate.

Many other senators in this place from the opposition party, the minor parties and the Independents have a lot of speaking opportunities. But coalition senators, in the interest of getting the government's legislative program through the Senate, have on almost all occasions refrained from speaking in the second reading stage debates and in most committee stage debates. In my role as Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate, I particularly thank coalition senators for their support. We could not have achieved the government's legislative program if all senators wanted to speak on all the bills. I thank coalition senators for that.

The reality is that coalition senators like me have worked most of their adult lives trying, firstly, to get into parliament and, secondly, trying to get the coalition to government so that we could change Australia's direction, and particularly so that we could change the direction that Australia had gone down over the past 13 years under the control of the Australian Labor Party government. All coalition senators are very proud of the direction that has been put in place by the budgets brought down in August last year and in May this year by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and this government. These appropriation bills form part of the delivery thereof.

I listened to almost all the speeches in the second reading debate; not always in the chamber, but glued to the television monitor in my office. I listened to many of them and, of course, I had officers present to monitor the debate. However, I did not note—I may have missed a couple of bits; I am sure Senator Sherry or others will remind me if I have—anyone proposing any cuts to government expenditure. A range of speakers said that we should not have cut. In fact, virtually every single cut, every expenditure reduction and every bit of fiscal consolidation has actually been opposed by a range of speakers from the Australian Labor Party, the Democrats, the Greens and others. I think they virtually opposed every single piece of fiscal consolidation which the 1997 budget puts in place.

Many senators who spoke on these bills actually proposed greater spending in a number of areas. None of them said how that might be paid for, although I did note that former Senator Gareth Evans made some comments to the media some time ago when tax reform was first raised as an issue. He said that he thought that Australia was under taxed in world terms. I suspect that former Senator Evans, now the shadow treasurer, was alluding to potential tax increases. I must say that if all the wish lists of the Labor Party senators who contributed to this debate were put into the policy paper that Mr Gareth Evans is developing, there would have to be either tax increases or significant increases in Australia's debt.

I really do suggest that if Australians want to see what the Australian Labor Party or the Greens or the Democrats stand for at the moment, they should go through these speeches on the appropriation bills and list all the areas that show where the coalition should not have made cuts and, indeed, where there should be increased expenditure. If people thought we had a problem when we inherited the $10 billion deficit, then they would have to add on the billions of dollars of spending proposed during the last few hours of this appropriations debate.

With that sort of policy of increasing spending no savings would be made. No‐one who spoke in the debate advocated any savings or advocated where we should have made some cuts. With that approach the deficit would increase quite significantly—by some billions—the $10 billion we inherited, and the interest rate reductions we have had would not have been possible because of fiscal consolidation. We would not have been able to repay $5 billion worth of debt and, of course, that would hurt the small to medium businesses we are trying to help.

We suggest to the Australian people that it is never going to be easy to try to save $10 billion. It is never going to be easy to turn the massive deficit that we inherited from Mr Keating and Mr Beazley into a surplus after three years, which is what we are hoping to achieve if the forecasts come in. It is not going to be possible to achieve that without some pain and without some cuts—it is simply unachievable. But, when we do achieve that goal from that sound fiscal basis, it will be possible for Australia to see the improvements that we have seen in interest rates.

Ultimately, Australia will also see improvements in the capabilities of small and medium enterprises in particular to get on with the task of expanding both nationally and internationally and employing young people. In conclusion, I want to respond to the senators who criticised the savings rebate proposal—the savings measure which cuts the tax on savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will cut that.
—Senator Sherry says they are going to get rid of that.
—No, we will cut it.

—You will cut it? Senator Sherry is suggesting that he does not think that people should get a tax break for savings. I think I heard Senator O'Brien say a little earlier this afternoon—a couple of speakers ago—that it was a billion dollar handout for `the Liberals' rich mates'. I will send Senator O'Brien a copy of the survey, if he would like one. If he is listening, he can just call my office and we will send him a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: An independent survey by one of Australia's investment banks—I think BT did the study, Bankers Trust—found, to the surprise of the spokesman, that 79 per cent of the benefit of the savings rebate announced in May goes to people in the $40,000 or less wage bracket. So very much middle to low income earners are the winners out of this.

I again urge people to not listen too carefully to the rhetoric of the Labor Party, to read the fine print and to believe the independent observers who have analysed this savings measure. It is designed to help Australians, particularly low to middle income earners, to give them an incentive to save, to give them a bit of a break—particularly young couples saving for a deposit on a house or putting money into other investments such as securities—and of course it is a support for people who choose to invest in superannuation.

It is a good measure. It is a significant breakthrough as far as taxation treatment of savings is concerned. It is not discriminatory. It does help families. It will help small business people. It is a modest measure. Of course, we would love to be able to take it further, but it is in keeping with a sound and sensible budget.

I conclude by sincerely thanking senators opposite for making that contribution, for nailing the Labor Party's colours to the mast—once again confirming where they stand on fiscal consolidation, that is, to oppose it lock, stock and barrel.
Amendment (Senator Sherry's) negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1997-98

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997‐98. There have been two sets of requests for amendments to the bill circulated in the names of Senator Margetts and Senator Brown.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the bill by increasing or decreasing the votes for departments in accordance with the following schedule:

BREAK.PARA: I mentioned my amendments during my speech on the second reading. I will not be belabouring the issue, except to remind the Senate that there are issues of fairness here. The very least that we think should be done on the issue of fairness in this Appropriation Bill is that defence is asked to pull its weight just a little in relation to what other people have been asked to shoulder in terms of cuts.

One specified area of request is that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission be funded to the level it was going to be so that its funding is maintained, which is extremely important at this time. In Australia's history, not for quite some time have we had so many potential problems with human rights. As a country you cannot stand back and allow people's ability to be represented to be taken away in this way.

The amounts of money for defence allow some discretionary spending where governments say, `We have to take away this $2 million because of the black hole. We have to take this $5 million because of the black hole.' Well, here we go: here are some funds available, some discretionary funds, for those most needy. Those words have been used. They have certainly been used by Senator Vanstone: `We are targeting the most needy.' Targeting nearly always backfires, nearly always means more people suffer. But there are many people who deserve support in this community, and this is certainly a way that this support can be paid for.

We have given lots of ideas. Certainly, during my speech on the second reading I reminded the Senate of many ideas for which extra revenue could be fairly obtained to provide for reasonable expenditures and reasonable services without destroying the lives and work of many people. But those options have not been taken. Here is another chance for the government and, hopefully, the opposition to support an issue of equity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate. I do not think Senator Margetts or any other senator will be surprised to hear that the government will not be supporting the request. Senator Margetts is welcome aboard the budget cutting task force. With this earnest effort to cut the deficit and being able to find $200 million like this, I think the Treasurer might even invite her to join the Expenditure Review Committee of cabinet.

SPEECH.PARA: But there is a quite serious point here. And that is that defence—I just note from some material that I have been given by the defence minister—at these levels has been quarantined from cost cutting in the last two budgets, and for a very good reason. In the early 1980s I took a very serious and close interest in defence policy. A group that I formed in Western Australia to monitor defence policy in the late 1970s and early 1980s used to support the proposition that Australia should have defence spending set ideally at about three per cent of gross domestic product.

I remember back in those days that defence spending as a proportion of gross domestic product had dropped below three per cent and was heading south. At the levels that it has been held at by this government, the $10.4‐odd billion represents about 1.9 per cent of gross domestic product. So there has been a significant reduction of the defence vote as a proportion of GDP over the last few years. The Australian government believes that it should not continue that trend, that we live in a world where there are changing strategic needs and requirements, and that to reduce our defence capabilities and the vote that is provided to defence would be a serious derogation of our duty to ensure that the defence of Australia and Australia's responsibilities in the region and in the globe are carried out.

Further to that, of course, the Minister for Defence, Mr McLachlan, has announced the defence reform program, which over the coming years will see something like a billion dollars of savings in the administration and non‐combat areas of defence moved towards key combat capabilities. This will effectively, in cliched political rhetoric, ensure that we get a bigger bang for our buck. It will move defence resources from the blunt end to the sharp end of defence. I think the minister is to be congratulated for the announcement of the defence reform program. It will see savings of something like $500 million in the next year, building up to about a billion dollars, potentially, moving out of administrative and non‐combat areas into combat capability.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor will not be supporting the amendments proposed to the appropriations bill. We do not believe it is the appropriate place to deal with these issues. There is a range of concerns Labor has about the budget; many of my colleagues have outlined that in their contributions to this debate. There will be a range of legislation presented to this Senate over the coming year—possibly longer—with respect to the implementation of changes in a significant number of government departments, and we believe that that will be the appropriate time and place to make our contribution to various government measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not wishing to hold the Senate up longer than is necessary, but I do need to respond to some of the statements made by Senator Campbell. Senator Campbell talked about percentages, but I think if you follow through the paper trail on defence you will find that many areas which might well be related to defence come under different areas. They include, perhaps, industry portfolios or industry assistance in other areas. So if we actually had the total, we would probably be a lot closer to three per cent than what the official figures are that come specifically under defence. Many of the proposals for Australia's cooperation in other countries ends up coming out of specific budgets. It could be medicine, foreign affairs, police; it could be a whole lot of areas, potentially, if Australia participates in those particular operations overseas, which are otherwise considered training operations.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have got to look at it all in the context of the fact that the so-called savings from other departments, for which you read `cuts', go into general revenue. In fact, defence gets to pocket them and to buy more war toys. We also have to keep in mind that it is quite clear that the government have announced that, if they get elected again, not only are they going to quarantine defence while other things—really important things in our community—are being cut, but they are planning to massively increase the defence dollar. That has got to be kept in mind. Everybody else is asked to suffer. Not only are we going to be quarantining defence, but in a while it will massively increase.

However, the question should be asked: what are the major security risks to Australia? The average person believes that security risks will be created by things like access to resources. It could be inequities between countries and within countries. And these days there are also insecurities associated with environmental damage. There are issues which A

ustralia is actually pulling back their funding on. We are pulling back our funding to aid. We are pulling back our funding in relation to decreasing inequities between rich and poor in developing countries. Then we are increasing the dollar for the `sharp end' in defence. So we are looking at the boys' toys side of security and actually closing our eyes to many of the major issues—foreign affairs and environment and international cooperation. Australia is putting up its finger to many other countries around the world in relation to working out the world's problems, but we are prepared to spend more on trying to be technically ahead of the club within the region. I do not think that makes sense.

History has always shown that if you start pushing ahead with technical developments in relation to defence, other countries in the region will race to do the same. So what we will get in the region is an arms race. At the moment, apparently the official response still is that it is not an arms race, it is a buyer's market. However, I think that is what we are going to get. Where is the end to that, the spending upon spending for a threat we are not even sure of? Commonsense must apply. We are talking real people here, real issues, not just people's pride, regional pride, as to how much expensive war hardware they can show—maybe never use but show. I think it is time that we grew up.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the interests of brevity, I ask that Senator Brown and I be recorded as making `yes' votes.
—Is leave granted? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the bill by increasing the votes for departments in accordance with the following schedule:

The parliamentary secretary said, in terms of keeping the defence budget intact, that in a world of changing strategic needs and requirements it would be a serious derogation of our duty to the region and the globe to cut defence spending. I would like to take out the word `defence' and put in the words `overseas aid'. Then he would have said that in a world of changing strategic needs and requirements it would be a serious derogation of our duty to the region and the globe to cut overseas aid. That is what this government is doing.

Moreover, if you ask what sort of strategic needs and requirements Australia might foster in the region and indeed around the globe one of those would be making alternative clean green technology affordable to our neighbours and indeed to the whole world. Amongst that technology would be solar technology, photovoltaic cells and wind power. That can be used at a local level. It does not require large polluting central power stations—coal fired or nuclear, for that matter—but it would give those people who are amongst the one billion poorest on this planet and who are struggling to survive some opportunity to move into the age of electric power gadgetry. They could also move into world mass communications, literacy and all that comes with that.

So the government is right in saying that changing strategic needs and requirements have to be recognised and that to cut the budget would be a derogation of our duty to the region and the globe. I maintain that the priority should be providing our neighbours with the wherewithal to feel that their basic needs are being met and the security of knowing that they are catching, even if they have not caught, the images of prosperity and well-being that they see the richer people on the planet, including ourselves, having when they tune into the village television set, if one is available.

Yet we have the government cutting those very things. We know that it has cut overseas aid to the lowest level in a quarter century—flouting totally our commitment at the Earth Summit in Rio in 1997. No wonder Prime Minister Howard is ducking the Earth Summit which is taking place in New York as I speak. Seventy of the world's leaders are there, but not John Howard. He apparently does not count himself as a leader. He has ducked out altogether.

He is flying from London to Washington and going to twiddle his toes for two days waiting for the President of the United States, Bill Clinton, to get back from New York. The President of the United States happens to think that the Earth Summit has priority over John Howard. Somebody has their priorities right. It is not until Friday—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a hard conclusion to come to.

—No, it is not a hard conclusion to come to. What a sad and embarrassing conclusion for Australia. Where is the dignity of this nation? Where are the changing strategic needs and requirements, to quote the parliamentary secretary opposite, of this nation? They are being totally ignored by an embarrassed Prime Minister.
—Order! I feel that you need to confine your remarks to the requests, Senator Brown.

—I am very happy to do that. I thank you for that direction because I could go on about the Prime Minister at great length and it would not change things at all. What I can do is recommend that this com mittee adopt this request for amendment moved by the Greens to restore funding to the Energy Research and Development Corporation and to the national energy efficiency program. They are both being cut. In the 1997 budget the Energy Research and Development Corporation is being effectively abolished. We are not going to have any government moneys going into alternative technologies. The rest of the world is trying to find solutions to the global greenhouse problem. Some 2000 American economists and yesterday some 130 Australian economists said we should move to these alternative technologies. They are sunrise industries. They mean prosperity and jobs. That would be a start to addressing, in a realistic fashion, the awesome problem of global warming.

SPEECH.PARA: What is this budget doing? It is cutting the pittance that previous budgets have put into this area of Australian expertise. It is pulling the rug from under it. What blinkered thinking. What addled thinking. Let us have a go at it. Let me again take up the words of the parliamentary secretary. Let us be serious about our duty to the region and the globe. Let us even be serious about our obligation of supporting alternative clean green technologies in this country of ours. Let us restore in this budget the tiny amount—I am talking about a few million dollars—to bring budgeting on these alternative energies back to $12 million in the coming year. This is an amount out of a budget of more than 1,000 times that amount.

I recommend to this committee that we send to the House of Representatives a request to amend the budget to restore funding on alternative energy in Australia to the level that was evident in previous budgets. I am sorry there is no response from the government on this. To me it is an important matter. Obviously, the Greens are going to get voted down on this but for the government to sit there and say nothing about it just underscores how short of the mark they are in addressing the needs and the business interests of this country in fostering in a small way the alternative energy options that Australia has.

I was interested today to hear that some of our neighbours in this region are getting their solar energy alternatives from Norway—hardly the sun-drenched country. They are going to the other side of the globe to get technology that we should be exporting from Australia. No wonder Norway has the drop on us. It is a mile ahead as far as environmental and new technology fostering by the government is concerned. Yet here I put a proposal that we maintain past pitiable levels of support for energy research and development, instead of cutting it to nothing, and the government cannot even respond.
Question resolved in the negative.
Bills agreed to without amendments or requests.
Bills reported; report adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most important promise that John Howard, the Prime Minister, made when he was Leader of the Opposition prior to the last election was that he wanted to ensure that Australians felt relaxed and comfortable under his government. I do not know of too many groups left in the community who feel relaxed and comfortable today. In fact, I cannot think of one.

BREAK.PARA: I certainly know that parents with young children requiring child care are not feeling relaxed and comfortable because in a week's time the real impact of this government's changes in child care will be felt with higher fees. Parents with children at school do not feel relaxed and comfortable following this government's decisions with respect to funding for school education. Students at university or TAFE colleges no longer feel relaxed and comfortable after what this government has done with higher education, ripping about $1.5 billion out of the sector.

The young unemployed who were previously working under labour market programs set up by the previous government under Working Nation no longer feel relaxed and comfortable. People in need of health care or pharmaceuticals no longer feel relaxed and comfortable after what this government has done and proposes to do to the hospital system in this country or with respect to the provision of pharmaceuticals for people with illnesses. People working under industrial awards of this country do not feel relaxed and comfortable, nor do people in small business, nor do people with superannuation.

But if there is one group in our community who deserve to feel relaxed and comfortable but will not any longer feel relaxed and comfortable it is our aged community. They are entitled to feel relaxed and comfortable as best they can in their remaining years. That is particularly true of those elderly, frail people who, because of their situation, are required to be residents of nursing homes.

People do not choose to go into nursing homes, just as they do not choose to go into hospitals. We all recall years ago under previous coalition governments that many of our aged community spent their remaining days in public hospitals. These people, in the future, are clearly going to be seriously affected by this government's proposals under the aged care legislation that we are now debating.

This is legislation which reduces funding to the aged care sector. In excess of $550 million has been ripped out of the aged sector by this government since it came to office. This legislation particularly reduces govern ment funding for nursing homes. Yet this government has the hide to say that this is a reform package; that this is a package of legislation that is going to improve the position for the elderly in our community.

But the providers out there know that those people will not feel relaxed and comfortable under John Howard's government because they are threatened with the real possibility, indeed the likelihood in many cases, of being forced to sell their homes to gain access to nursing home accommodation. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and the government say, and no doubt speakers from the government will try to stand up in here and say, that nobody will be forced to sell their own home to gain access to a nursing home. Of course it may not say that specifically in the legislation, but that is going to be the reality for many people out there.

It is clear that there are many aged people in our community who, first of all, will not qualify to be concessional residents in nursing homes. Secondly, there are many no doubt who, even if they do qualify for concessional resident status in nursing homes, will find it difficult to get access to nursing homes because of what will become a limit on the provision of concessional resident places in nursing homes at about 30 per cent on average figures.

Those people clearly, whilst they may have an entitlement under the legislation to concessional resident status, will nevertheless find themselves in a position in which, if they want to get access to a nursing home because they need such access, the pressure will be on them to sell their house to find the finance to put up an accommodation bond, because that is the only thing in the future that is really going to guarantee people a right to nursing home accommodation. If you have the money—the assets—to put up a bond under this government's legislation, then you can pretty well guarantee yourself a place in a nursing home. But if you do not have the money or the assets, or you cannot sell your home then you have no such guarantee.

So what we are going to have in the future is a market based system. It will no longer be accommodation for people who need to be cared for in nursing homes. As I said earlier, it is not a matter of choice for those people and it is not a matter of choice for their families; it is a matter of necessity. Those people are clearly going to find themselves in the position where the market will determine whether they get access or not.

This legislation will have a dramatic effect upon the availability of nursing home accommodation for the elderly. It will also have a dramatic effect upon those people who work in the aged care sector and those organisations that provide the facilities. This legislation will not, as the government claims, improve access to nursing home facilities and it will certainly not improve the standard of care. As much as this government may claim that it will, it certainly will not.

You do not have to take my word for it. All you have to do is read the report of the Senate Community Affairs Committee to see the views of those involved in the aged care sector. They are very worried. They are concerned about the significant loss of funding that is going to occur. They are concerned about the way in which this government is forcing this legislation through this parliament without proper and adequate consultation and without proper and adequate opportunity for the industry and for the parliament to consider it.

This legislation was rammed through the House of Representatives just a couple of weeks ago by use of the guillotine. Debate was severely restricted. Many members who would have liked to have spoken on this legislation, and who were entitled to speak on this legislation because of the representations that had been made to them by facilities located in their electorates and by persons involved in providing aged care, did not get that opportunity to speak. This government has had this legislation floating around now for ages. But when it came to the time for it to be debated in the parliament—one of the most significant pieces of legislation that this government has put before the parliament—what did the government do? It stifled the debate and rammed it through using the guillotine.

In a frenzy to try to get this legislation through the Senate this week, the minister has been running back and forth trying to negotiate some form of a package with the industry and with the Australian Democrats. As recently as only a couple of hours ago, we had the third variation, if you like, on this issue of the concessional resident subsidy.

I am sure senators will recall that this has been a matter of debate out in the community for some time now. The government initially offered the paltry amount of $5 per day for the concessional resident subsidy for nursing homes—a figure which was derided by those in the aged care sector and a figure that really was so low as to be a joke. It was described that way by many in the industry.

But this is not a funny matter. What we are dealing with here is the amount of finance being provided to nursing homes to care for concessional residents. After pressure had been applied, the minister moved a bit and, on 19 June, put out a further statement proposing a sliding scale. But that was not sufficient either.

Today we note—and no doubt we will come to this, and no doubt Senator Woodley will address it in his remarks at some stage in the debate—that the government finally offered to increase the concessional resident subsidy from $5 to $7 per resident in homes with up to 40 per cent concessional residents, and then $12 for each and every resident in homes of between 41 per cent and 100 per cent concessional residents. We welcome that move by the government, because it is a recognition of just what a lousy offer was made in the first place and, indeed, of just how wrong this government has got it from the start in looking at aged care accommodation.

But, whilst we welcome that move today, we still say that it clearly does not go far enough. It is not $12 as a minimum for every concessional resident in nursing homes, which was identified as the bare minimum that would be required; and it is well short of the equivalent of $19 or $20 that results from the application of the accommodation bonds and the draw down of $2,600 per year that nursing homes will be able to access; and it is certainly well short of what Professor Gregory recommended would be required by the aged care sector.

Time and time again this government have quoted Professor Gregory's report which, they claim, supports their package. But, whilst Professor Gregory recognised a substantial need for injection of capital funding into the nursing home sector, he also made specific recommendations—and I have already referred to the issue of concessional resident subsidy. However, having claimed support from Professor Gregory's report, this government then proceeded to put forward legislation which will introduce accommodation bonds, contrary to the recommendations of Professor Gregory. As Professor Gregory in his report stated:

"The circumstances under which clients seek access to nursing homes are considerably different from hostel clients. Approximately 60% of nursing home admissions are from hospitals. This is one indicator of the fact that nursing home entry is often urgent, motivated overwhelmingly by the need for nursing care.

The sheer size of entry contributions and the impact on a client's life of having to agree to sell assets to receive care would be a considerable barrier to entry. Thus, while allowing residents who can afford it to pay extra may be the fairest way to provide the extra funds needed for nursing home stock, the substantial increase in the amount that could be paid by allowing entry contributions seems too harsh a measure.

Just interrupting the quote for one moment, of course what we are talking about there are amounts estimated to be up to $80,000 or $100,000; there is no cap at all upon the amount that may be set. He goes on:

Even if entry contributions were only allowed for long stay nursing home residents, the emergency entry would mean that issues such as how much might be charged some time in the future are unlikely to be thought through properly when entry was being sought, leaving the resident effectively bound to whatever was agreed.
In contrast, most people entering hostels have time to look for the hostel of their choice, taking into account factors such as how much will be charged."

I have read that quote out because one of the principal arguments that the government and the minister have put forward in support of accommodation bonds, and how they will be the great saviour for the nursing home industry in terms of capital improvement, is that this is simply an extension of what the Labor government did in the past with hostel accommodation.

That argument is a lie. That argument states, `The Labor government put in a similar system for hostel accommodation; all we're doing is extending it to nursing homes.' But what the government fails to acknowledge and state is that there is a clear difference between hostel accommodation, which is a matter of choice for those aged people who elect to enter it, and being in the position where you have to go into a nursing home.

So do not come at us with this argument that what you are doing by introducing accommodation bonds is simply an extension of what happens with hostel accommodation. It is not. What you are doing is destroying forever the right of the aged who need nursing home accommodation, where there is no choice in the matter, to have access to that accommodation on the basis of need. You are introducing into the system the principle that you can have access to nursing home accommodation, if you can come up with the $80,000 or $100,000 to buy your way in. You have shifted the ground in that area. I say this to the Democrats, who have indicated they will support this: that fundamental shift destroys the principle that our aged who need nursing home accommodation should be able to access it, irrespective of their income and assets.

There are a range of other issues in this legislation that no doubt we will get on to in the committee stage. There are many issues still unresolved. For instance, I have received much correspondence expressing concern about the proposed resident classification scale that will be introduced, and the impact that that will have on funding for nursing homes.

There is major concern about the fact that we still do not have any prudential arrangements in place or even out there to be con sidered. How is it going to be ensured that the accommodation bonds will be used for improving capital infrastructure and improving facilities? How can we be sure that the money will be safe? These issues, of course, will come up during the committee debate, and the opposition will be moving amendments to that effect. But I just point out in conclusion that this is not a reform package which improves aged care; this is a package which ultimately rips $550 million out of the aged care sector and creates a lot of uncertainty, and it will force a lot of elderly people to have to sell their remaining asset, their home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating a package of bills of which the major bill is the Aged Care Bill 1997, and then there are consequential bills which rely on that. It is hard to remember the last time that a package of reforms has caused as much concern and confusion as this one has. The concern of many aged care providers, both for profit and not for profit providers, has centred on the rushed time frame in which this package of reforms has been put together and the lack of detail which for many months surrounded many of the crucial aspects of the broader reforms we are voting on today and in the next day or two.

SPEECH.PARA: Concern for many elderly Australians and for their families has centred on the impact the proposed introduction of nursing home entry fees, or accommodation bonds, may have on their ability to gain access to high quality nursing home care and whether or not they will have to sell their family home to pay an accommodation bond.

It has taken the Democrats a long time to decide how we will vote today. I have never consulted as much as I have on this bill—with providers, consumers, peak bodies in the industry; people whose judgment I trust. It has taken a long time to distil all of the advice I have received, because often it was contrary—and sometimes, of course, it was not based on the full information which was needed.

The Democrats have stayed with this debate from the beginning. We have not announced a firm position at any point until today, because we did want to ensure that we understood fully what was being proposed and that we were able to get assurances from a majority of providers, peak bodies and consumers whose advice we trusted that this was going to meet their needs.

BREAK.PARA: We have had to weigh up carefully the various arguments, both for and against the introduction of a nursing home entry fee, and on the move towards greater reliance on user pays for residential aged care. In forming our final position on the reforms contained in this legislation, we have relied very heavily on the advice given to us by organisations and individuals involved in the area of aged care. But we have been especially concerned that those paying accommodation bonds would go to the head of the queue—in this debate, what we term the two‐tier system.

Since these reforms were first announced in the 1996 budget, we have had ongoing discussion with the Minister for Family Services, Judi Moylan, and during these meetings we have regularly raised the concerns of the various organisations involved in the provision of aged care and the concerns of many elderly Australians. We do want to ensure that those at the bottom at the end of their lives are not forced to stay at the bottom but that there is some equity.

Over the past 10 months, the minister has consistently stressed that the purpose of many of these reforms, and the introduction of nursing home entry fees in particular, is to address the chronic shortfall in nursing home capital infrastructure funding which was identified in the Gregory report in 1994. She has also stressed that the residents who meet the `financially disadvantaged person' criteria will not be required to pay an accommodation bond and that the family home will not be counted in determining whether a person can pay an accommodation bond if a spouse or dependent child is living at home or if a carer or close family member—that is, father, mother, sister, brother, child or another person who, in the secretary's opinion, should be treated as a close family member—has been living in the home for at least five years and is eligible for a pension or benefit themself.

The Democrats agree with the government when they say that there is an urgent need to find a way to address the massive shortfall in capital funding for nursing home infrastructure. On this there can be no dispute, as the problem was clearly spelt out in 1994 by Professor Gregory. The Gregory report highlighted the poor physical condition of the present nursing infrastructure. And I must point out that there is general agreement throughout much of the aged care sector that the lack of capital funding, in particular, for nursing homes, estimated to be approximately $800 million, identified by Professor Gregory constitutes nothing less than a crisis which must be urgently addressed.

As Gregory highlighted, 40 per cent of nursing home stock does not meet basic fire standards. In addition, many other nursing homes are skating pretty close to the edge: many have insufficient space, or staircases which are too narrow; and many residents have to share a room with four or five other residents and thus have little privacy. That state of affairs is simply not good enough. This government has been faced with a real crisis and the need to do something about it urgently.
The 1995 Australian Law Reform Commission report, The coming of age, pointed out:

The number and proportion of older people in Australia is steadily increasing with this increase being particularly significant for people over 75 years of age . . . lt is estimated that by the year 2051—
Some of us will probably not be around then.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long?
—By 2051. The report continues:

BREAK.PARA: . . . 22% of the population will be over 65 years of age and nearly 11% over 75 years. The likelihood of disability, including dementia, increases substantially as people get older.

With Australia's population aging, this situation is not one we can afford to ignore any longer. Something clearly has to be done. The huge problems with nursing home capital infrastructure are only going to get worse unless we do something to address these problems now.

It has been interesting over the course of this debate to see just how quick the opposition has been to condemn the government for failing to address this funding crisis. When considering the highly adversarial stance the ALP has taken on these reforms, let us not forget for one moment that, when they were in government, the ALP also had plenty of opportunities to address this shortfall in capital funding. But did they? No, not in any adequate way. They failed to effectively address this issue.
I do give them credit, however, that they introduced additional recurrent funding in 1991‐92 to be paid over a 10-year period but, as Gregory noted in his report:

Very few of the projects which were approved for funding ever went ahead. Of the 210 upgrading projects approved in 1992-93 for example only eleven were completed and only seven nursing homes were replaced over a three year period.
That means we were going backwards. As Gregory pointed out in 1994:

This low level of actual building suggests that the private sector does not consider the proportion of the cost met by the funding sufficient to justify the contribution required although the number applying indicates an interest in improving stock.
He went on further to say:
Unless the attractiveness of the funding is increased it would not be used and there would be little improvement in stock.
As the attractiveness of the funding was not increased, we seem to have here, once again, yet another case of the pot calling the kettle black.

When it comes to accommodation bonds, the Democrats' main concerns have always been how this measure will affect the standard of care which is available to financially disadvantaged nursing home residents. One of our greatest fears has always been that the introduction of nursing home entry fees may actually lead to two tiers of nursing home care with one standard of care for the rich and one for the poor.

The government has consistently said that a two‐tier system in nursing home care will not develop because they will pay nursing home operators an additional subsidy for financially disadvantaged residents, and that this subsidy will make financially disadvantaged residents as attractive to nursing home operators as those who can afford to pay an accommodation bond. I, for one, had high hopes that this would in fact be the case. But I was disappointed on 26 May when the government announced that the additional subsidy they would pay nursing home operators for financially disadvantaged residents would be a meagre $5 a day—not enough.

Nearly all nursing home operators condemned the government for this $5 a day subsidy, including those groups which have actively cooperated with the government and worked closely with the minister to try to ensure that the final package of reforms is a workable one. The Uniting Church described the $5 subsidy as, `An insult to our elderly and a slap in the face for charitable providers.' Other organisations, such as the Australian Nursing Homes and Extended Care Association and Anglicare, clearly stated that this $5 a day subsidy is `likely to foster a two‐tiered system in aged care'. Many organisations stated that, in order to prevent two tiers of nursing home care emerging, they would need a subsidy much closer to the $12 a day recommended in the Gregory report.

Many organisations were also worried at some of the details of the new resident care classification and funding structure, which the minister also announced on 26 May. In response to widespread industry condemnation of the $5 subsidy, on 19 June the minister announced that the government would pay nursing home operators a sliding subsidy scale for concessional residents. However, once again the industry rejected this saying that, even at this new level, the development of two tiers of nursing home care would still be inevitable. By 20 June things between aged care providers and the government had pretty well reached a stalemate.

Many aged care providers were publicly saying that they had reached a point where they would have no choice but to reluctantly oppose the government's whole package of aged care reforms. Late last Friday the Democrats brokered a series of meetings between the minister and the major church residential age care providers. I have to say, and let me put it on the record, that we do have a different kind of minister in Judi Moylan. The Democrats have not always had a very helpful relationship with some government ministers, but I commend Judi Moylan for her willingness and staying power to continue negotiat ing and meeting—we were on the phone from Friday evening until today—with the industry. It is important that that be put on the record.

As a result of these meetings the minister agreed to the following measures. First, an independent review of the residential classification scale instrument after three months of operation. That is very important.
