Reasons of the House of Representatives for disagreeing to the amendments

The Amendment proposes a preamble be included which specifies the role of the Convention and the appointment and election of delegates to the Convention. The House of Representatives does not accept the Amendment, as it does not reflect the purpose and scope of the Bill.

These Amendments focus on the method of voting for half of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention which will meet for 10 days in December 1997 to consider the question of whether or not Australia should become a republic. The Amendments require that voting in the election be by a compulsory attendance ballot, which will make Australians who choose not to vote in the election for delegates liable to prosecution and add up to $20 million to the cost.

The Amendments also propose that the election be conducted along the lines of a Senate election. In light of the large number of candidates which could contest this election (possibly exceeding 200‐300 candidates in New South Wales) a pure Senate "style" election would make it difficult for electors to vote for someone other than a group, and would extend the time needed to count the vote.
Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes these Amendments (Numbers 2‐8 and 11‐68).

This Amendment provides that candidates' $500 nomination fee should be returned if the candidate is elected or the candidate/candidate group receives at least 4% of the total number of votes. Given the Government will be providing a tax deduction for election expenses up to a limit of $1,000 to candidates, whether successful or not, the House of Representatives does not accept Amendment Number 10.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the committee further considers the Senate's amendments to this bill which have been disagreed to by the House of Representatives, I should draw attention to a potential complication. This is the situation which arises if there are equally divided votes on questions to determine whether the Senate insists on its amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: When Senate amendments to a bill first introduced in the House of Representatives are disagreed to by the House, the Senate has to decide whether to insist on its amendments. The standing orders provide for alternative motions to be moved to determine that question, but the substantive result is not affected by the form of the motion.

BREAK.PARA: If a vote is taken on that question, and the votes are equally divided, the ruling of President Sibraa of 21 October 1993 applies. That ruling was upheld by a majority of the Senate at the time and subsequently by a unanimous report of the Procedure Committee.

The ruling distinguishes between two types of amendments. The first type, which has been called type A, is a Senate request for an amendment or a Senate amendment which consists of an alteration to the text of a bill. Equally divided votes on the question whether the Senate insists on such a request or amendment means that the request or amendment is lost and the bill proceeds without it. The rationale of this is that such a request or amendment requires a majority to be carried in the first instance, and the equally divided vote indicates that the request or amendment no longer has the support of a majority.

The other type of amendment, which has been called type B, takes the form of striking out a self‐contained item in a bill. An equally divided vote on the question whether the Senate insists on such an amendment means that the amendment is insisted on. The rationale of this is that such an amendment can be made by an equally divided vote in the first instance, as every such item in a bill must be carried by a majority, and the subsequent vote would indicate that the item still lacked majority support. Examples relating to this bill are as follows.

Senate amendment No. 1 to the bill inserted a new item. It is therefore a type A amendment. This amendment required a majority to be carried in the first instance. An equally divided vote on the question whether the Senate insists on this amendment would indicate that the amendment now lacks majority support and the Senate would therefore not insist on the amendment.

Senate amendment No. 2 to the bill strikes out a clause of the bill. The question put by the chair was that the clause stand as printed. This question was negatived. It could have been negatived by an equally divided vote, indicating that the clause lacked majority support, and the clause would have been left out by such a vote. This is therefore a type B amendment. If the question to determine whether the Senate insists on this amendment is negatived by an equally divided vote, this will indicate that the clause still lacks majority support and the Senate insists on leaving out the clause.
Following this statement there is an attachment which lists whether each Senate amendment to the bill which has been disagreed to by the House of Representatives is a type A or a type B amendment.

A complication arises if the Senate's amendments to a bill consist of a mixture of type A amendments, amendments to the text, and type B amendments, striking out self‐contained items. This is the situation with the bill now before us. When the Senate determines whether to insist on its amendments, an equally divided vote means that the type A amendments, amendments to the text, are lost, while the type B amendments, amendments striking out items, are maintained. If that situation arises the Senate may wish to consider its position and, in particular, to consider whether it wishes some amendments to proceed in the absence of others.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the committee does not insist upon the amendments disagreed to by the House of Representatives.

I would like to deal with this matter on the basis of addressing the electoral system which the Senate insists that the government adopt for the election of delegates to the convention, because that is what we now have—not the government's preferred system but the opposition parties' preferred system for electing delegates to the convention.

The Senate is telling the government that we cannot have this convention unless the election of delegates is conducted on a compulsory attendance ballot using the normal Senate style ballot paper. That is the position we now find ourselves in. Without taking too much time, I want to address my remarks to the system which the Senate insists that we use.

Firstly, I want to address the Senate ballot paper issue and urge you again to think about the practicality of that. We have no ideological hang‐up on this. We are trying to deal with this in a practical way. We, as a govern ment, came to this issue on the basis of discussions with the Electoral Commission on the sort of election we could find ourselves in. With 20 positions available in New South Wales, 16 in Victoria and 13 in Queensland, this is a much bigger show than even a full Senate election. It involves a situation where candidates would be elected to positions for just 10 days, not for six years as is the case in this chamber.

Therefore, we must plan on the basis of the possibility of enormous interest in it. And particularly in New South Wales, there is a lot of interest in this issue. My office has been inundated with queries about the process, the election and becoming a candidate. I said to the government, `We are going to have to plan for an election that could have anything up to 500 candidates. How are we going to deal with that?'

I think that is realistic. There are 20 positions in New South Wales. You only need 20 teams of 20 running for election and you have 400 candidates. There has been nothing like that in any Senate election. Frankly, the Senate system cannot cope with that sort of election. The proposition that the Senate is insisting on, that it be the normal Senate system, could make this an absolute shambles.

I note that the Proportional Representation Society of Australia, which I trust you all treat as reasonably neutral in this debate—apart from its obvious advocacy of proportional representation, but we are proposing a proportional representation election—has written to a number of senators. In its letter, the society said:
We believe that the government's efforts to cater for the possibility that very large numbers of candidates will nominate in some states are quite reasonable . . .
It went on to say:

. . . experience in the most recent New South Wales legislative council election and the first ACT election using the discredited and discarded d'Hondt scheme shows that the Senate type ballot paper becomes extremely unwieldy when around 100 candidates nominate. There would be utter pandemonium if 200 or more candidates came forward.
So the Proportional Representation Society of Australia is endorsing our system. It is warning the Senate, as I do, that the adoption of the full Senate system could be an utter shambles.

We as a responsible government have had to plan for a situation where not 200 but 500 candidates might nominate. I remind you that the Electoral Reform Society and Malcolm Mackerras—whatever you might think of him—have both endorsed the system we have proposed and do so from, I think, a more neutral corner than any of us in relation to this debate.

If the Senate insists on this amendment and we were to have an election on the basis of the full Senate election system, we could have a ballot paper one metre long by half a metre wide. It could be twice the size of the ballot paper used in 1989 ACT election, where, as you all know, it became a joke. It has the incidental fact of costing considerably more for the scrutiny as well as taking eight to 10 weeks merely to count. We are electing delegates to be there for 10 days, but it is going to take up to 10 weeks to count it.

Below‐the‐line voting in such situations, according to the Senate system and on the amendments you have proposed, would be extremely difficult. If there are, say, 400 candidates, to have a formal vote you have to number from one through to 400 below the line without making a mistake. I suspect that those voting below the line will suffer a very high risk of casting an informal vote. For all those reasons, that element of the Senate's proposed electoral system is unacceptable to the government.

The question of an attendance ballot—which is the second of the three major issues that we must address in the electoral system proposed by the Senate—was not proposed by the government and is not supported by the government. We have allocated some $35 million for the election that we proposed to conduct—a postal vote. One of the reasons we did so was that it is $13 million cheaper than an attendance ballot. It will cost some $49 million for a full attendance ballot for the election of delegates to this convention.

BREAK.PARA: We are not trying to be unduly fiscally conservative on this matter, but we do think that that is not cost-effective or reasonable in the circumstances. For an election which does not involve a government or a parliament but delegates to a convention, that sort of expenditure is unwarranted when it can be done effectively for considerably less money. So we do think that the cost involved in a full attendance ballot is not necessary and is wasteful.

I do point out that the postal ballot has the great advantage of enabling us to get into every household in Australia a great deal of information about this election. It is an unusual election and people will be looking for information. Your amendments have had to go to the extent of providing for material to be in libraries and other things. We will be able to deliver into every household the statements of all the candidates saying exactly what they stand for and full how‐to‐vote information about an unusual election. We think that is a considerable advantage of the method we have proposed.

We have, as you know, proposed security systems to minimise the extent to which there can be fraud, but I put to you that the incentive to defraud in an election like this is very limited. You are talking about statewide electorates of one million people—that is for my state, the second smallest state. To actually have any influence on the outcome would require fraud on a scale that is unheard of. Labor spent 13 years telling us that there was no fraud in the electoral system so I think it is a bit much to say that we cannot have a postal vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —You spent 13 years telling us that there was.

—I am on record as saying that the problem with the electoral system is the walk‐in walk‐out electoral roll—not the method of voting, but the fact that we have no guarantees whatsoever that the electoral roll is accurate. I do not reflect on the AEC in that. Simply, there are no checks whatsoever on enrolment. That situation obtains whether you have a postal or an attendance ballot.

BREAK.PARA: As I say, we are not talking about electing a government; we are talking about electing delegates to a convention with statewide electorates of a million-plus people. The incentive and the opportunity to engage in fraud, I think, are absolutely minimal. We have taken, I think, sensible steps to minimise that in any event.

The third area we have to deal with is this question of compulsion, whether this is a compulsory ballot. As Senator Bolkus honestly and sensibly stated the other day, if you are going to have a postal ballot, it is simply not practical or possible to make it compulsory. You cannot enforce a postal ballot for the reasons I think we all understand. That is partly why we propose that this be voluntary.

We do think that, in principle, it is not sensible, feasible or reasonable for this parliament to force people to vote in an election of this kind. I again remind you that we are not dealing with any proposition to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act to require compulsory voting; we are dealing with a unique election, an election of delegates to a convention about the issue of the republic.

While it might surprise us in the public domain, there are many Australians who are undecided on that issue. The most recent Newspoll from News Ltd, which is an advocate of change, revealed that 25 per cent of Australians are undecided on this issue. It would not be unreasonable to find that in an election there may be that 25 per cent of people who say, `I am not in a position where I can sensibly cast a vote for either a republican or a constitutional monarchist candidate. Therefore, I choose not to vote in this election but to observe the outcome and observe the debate in the convention. As and when the nation votes on this critical issue I will make up my mind. But I am not ready to do so at this stage.'

We know we have got 25 per cent of the electorate undecided. That is nearly three million Australians. What you are proposing is that every one of those three million is liable for prosecution should they choose to honour their position of being undecided and choose not to vote. They will be guilty of an offence, hunted down by the Electoral Commission and prosecuted.

I just think that, in the circumstances of an issue based election of this kind where it is not unreasonable that a quarter of our fellow Australians are at the moment undecided, they should—free of guilt—be able to stand back from this election. I would encourage them to vote; I would like them to vote and I would like them to make a decision on this, but to make them all guilty of an offence and to have the Electoral Commission prosecuting up to three million Australians is absolutely unacceptable to the government.

There are Liberals, as you well know, who disagree with me about the question of voluntary voting or compulsory voting for federal elections, but even those strong advocates in our ranks of compulsory voting for federal elections support this election being voluntary for the sorts of reasons I have outlined.

Much of this debate has been around the question of compulsory or voluntary voting for federal elections. That is not the proposition before the parliament, and I ask you to deal with it on its merits. I also ask you to note that this parliament and the then Labor government endorsed and adopted voluntary voting for ATSIC elections, and yet we have heard that we must not denigrate or downgrade this election of delegates to the convention by making it voluntary—that would somehow signal that we do not think it is important. I put that back to you in relation to ATSIC elections. By your own rhetoric and your own actions, you condemn ATSIC and its elections to that status, which is entirely unreasonable.

We have plenty of local government and union elections in this country which are all voluntary, and I do point out that the governments of Great Britain, France, Germany, Canada, New Zealand and, yes, the United States are all elected by a voluntary vote. To suggest that we cannot elect delegates to a convention to discuss the question of a republic by a method used by all the world's great democracies to elect their own governments does seem to me somewhat unreasonable.

Finally, I just make the point in closing that what the Senate is proposing—and we are now dealing in this motion with the question of the Senate's preferred electoral system, not ours—is that you add $20 million to the cost. This will cost $55 million to conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where's this from? That's outrageous.
—No. It is not. Of course, it is up to $55 million, but if the 25 per cent that I have indicated to you are undecided all choose not to vote, which I have said is possible—
—Who?
—The 25 per cent of Australians who are undecided on this issue. If they choose, because they are undecided, not to participate in this, which is entirely feasible—
—You're in fantasy land now.

—Fantasy land because I say that 25 per cent of Australians may, because they are undecided on this question, not vote and then it would cost the Electoral Commission $5.2 million to prosecute all those Australians. The three million Australians who remain undecided about this issue—if they were to choose not to vote, it would be $5.2 million of public expenditure to prosecute those Australians. That is the Electoral Commission quote. So it is our estimate that it will end up costing around $55 million. That is the cost of conducting a federal election.
—The more desperate you get, the more the figure goes up.

—If you want to quibble about a few million—through you, Mr Temporary Chairman—you can, but this election is likely to cost around $55 million, which is $20 million more than the government's proposal and therefore is unacceptable to the government, and the AEC figures to substantiate that figure have been produced.

BREAK.PARA: I put it to you in closing that it is unreasonable for the Senate to prevent the Liberal Party and the government from implementing the policy we went to the last election with. We won the election with this policy. The Labor Party proposed a plebiscite and was defeated. We believe it is reasonable for us to seek to implement our policy in the method we have proposed. I understand your objections to this system, but we think it is absolutely unreasonable for you to deny us the opportunity to implement our policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the opposition will not be supporting the proposition that the Parliament Secretary to the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, has moved. As senators would be aware, when this bill was originally debated, the Senate successfully amended the bill, effectively ensuring that the 76 elected convention delegates would be elected by a process of compulsory attendance secret ballot. The Senate has also taken steps in the debate on the bill to ensure that the ballot paper for the election of delegates to the convention would be a normal Senate style ballot paper rather than the extraordinarily complex hybrid that has been proposed by the government for the purposes of this Constitutional Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say in relation to that that Senator Minchin's arguments in relation to the ballot paper are very flimsy ones indeed. After all, we do have in the Senate style ballot paper a ballot paper that Australians are used to, a voting system of which—since its introduction for above‐ and below‐the‐line voting—there is a good understanding in the Australian community. You only need to look at the number of people who vote informally now in Senate elections to reinforce that particular point.

I must say to Senator Minchin—through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, and I made this point previously in the debate and I think it is worth reinforcing here—that it is wrong to suggest it is an easy system to work through. To have below‐the‐line voting that requires voters to go to a booklet that accompanies the material that comes to voters in the post, find a number next to a candidate's name, insert that number in a box on the ballot paper and then, if you wish, to extend that same process to from nine boxes up to the maximum number of delegates to be elected, which I believe is 20 depending on the state where the election is being held, is by any measure both a new and an extraordinarily complex voting system.

I do not necessarily argue here that this has been designed on advice from the Australian Electoral Commission to always deliberately confuse voters, but it certainly gives me that impression, I must say, given the fact that Australians will not be used to such a ballot paper. It has been described by the AEC itself as something that many will be used to because it is like going down to the TAB and filling in a betting slip, but I think that is a very poor argument in defence of a new ballot paper.

The opposition cannot back down from our insistence that the vote for delegates to this convention be undertaken according to what we believe are tried and true Australian electoral traditions. I think that it is reasonable to make the point that the government has used the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill 1997 to experiment with a new voting system and ballot paper, and to fundamentally attack the integrity of the Australian electoral system.

We in the Labor Party do have an unwavering commitment to the Australian style ballot. We think the massive changes that are being proposed by the government—firstly, changing from compulsory to voluntary voting; secondly, changing from an attendance ballot to a postal ballot; and, thirdly, changing to optional preferential voting in the sort of system that I outlined a little earlier—are ones that ought not be accepted by any responsible parliament. It would be irresponsible of the Senate to allow the Constitutional Convention (Election) Bill to pass the Senate in the form that is being proposed by the government.

I have said previously that Senator Minchin is one of the very forthright advocates—I acknowledge that; I acknowledge that he has been a very forthright advocate—of voluntary voting in Australia. I want to say to Senator Minchin that he has been very honest in that respect. He has not attempted to hide his commitment to a fundamental change to Australia's voting system. I acknowledge that, Senator Minchin. I think that when Australian politicians are open and honest in that way, it ought to be acknowledged by those from opposing political parties. You have not tried in any way to play down what I think is an ideological commitment—I think I can go further, frankly, and say it is an ideological obsession—in support of voluntary voting. But I do believe that you and some others in the government have tried to use the constitutional convention election of delegates process as a trojan horse to force voluntary voting in federal elections.

I think that is reinforced by the recent report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, which made a public recommendation in relation to the introduction of voluntary voting for Australian elections and referendums. I must say again that I believe that was driven by Senator Minchin, who has been a very effective henchman for the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in this regard. It does appear to be a very strong commitment of the government—to the point that that particular report, driven by Senator Minchin on behalf of the government, is now before the parliament and is a matter of public record. As far as the Labor Party is concerned, we believe it is absolutely essential that any attempt to distort, rig or rort our electoral system in this country must be resisted at all costs. We will resist this fundamental change that is proposed by the government.

Let me say to the government that we consider that any mechanism to formulate the republic is of vital importance to all Australians. We say that this sort of change to the voting system—a voluntary postal ballot—diminishes the seriousness of the task that the Constitutional Convention has before it. After all, this is the convention, as the government says, that provides the framework of a move to a republic. If the Constitutional Convention is seen as some sort of gabfest where delegates are elected in the same way as you elect Logie winners—that is, by a voluntary postal vote system—the convention will not have the standing or the integrity in the eyes of the Australian public that it should have.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy‐six Logie winners.
—There are 76 Logie winners in here.
—There are some I wouldn't give a Logie to.

—You want to have a look at who does win Logies these days. Maybe it would please John Howard if the convention did not have the standing or integrity that we believe it should have. But I make the point that I am of the view that Mr Howard will use any mechanism he can to place obstacles on the path to a republic.

BREAK.PARA: I believe the government has to face up to the fact that compulsory voting has been a hallmark of our electoral system since 1924. It ensures a high and therefore representative turnout in our elections. It makes sure that everybody in this country has a stake in the result.

As I said in my speech on the second reading on this bill, in Australia voting is considered an obligation of citizenship, just like paying taxes or abiding by the law. It is these obligations of citizenship that promote social and political cohesion in this country.

In the Labor Party we have always believed that voting in this country is a communal act by all Australians. It is an affirmation of the commitment of Australians to democratic and public processes. Compulsory voting at attendance ballots is the hallmark of our democratic electoral system. We have always said that a move to voluntary voting means that political parties will concentrate their efforts on mobilising the vote on election day as opposed to ideas, policies and programs for government.

We are also acutely aware—and it is very important from Labor's perspective—that voluntary voting inevitably leads to targeting campaigns to those people who are most likely to turn out to vote. It is the more disadvantaged in the community who tend not to vote in voluntary systems, and it is precisely those people that the Labor Party believes government has a special responsibility and obligation to. We just cannot accept that the government's proposition that the election of delegates to this Constitutional convention should be used as some sort of experiment to destroy in excess of 70 years of democratic tradition in this country.

Senator Minchin talks about opinion polls. I read on the wire that there is one published tomorrow, Senator Minchin, a Morgan poll in the Bulletin. It says that, of people who vote for your party, coalition supporters, 68 per cent support compulsory voting. It also says that 70 per cent of Labor voters support compulsory voting. That is perhaps something you might care to take on board, but I believe there is strong community support for compulsory voting. As you have been keen to quote opinion polling in the debate, that is one that we just read about today that is being published tomorrow.

I think the arguments that you present in relation to the difference in cost between a voluntary postal ballot and a compulsory attendance ballot represent highly inflated figures. On your own figures, the difference is $13 million. Labor has consistently said that the real difference is in fact a lot less. We believe that it is significantly less than $13 million, but we say that this is important enough, if it is up to $13 million, to find that money in the Federation Fund, because at the end of the day that is what the Federation Fund ought to be about.

But we say that fundamentally you cannot put a dollar figure on democracy; you cannot actually cost out the democratic process like that; you cannot compromise on democracy. We also say that you ought not be able to change the best electoral system in the world, that is, the Australian ballot. It is tried and true. It is, in our view, the best electoral system in the world, and we cannot accept the government's attempts to change it through this mechanism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats also believe that the Senate should insist on the amendments before us. The first thing I would say to the government is that they still have a very clear option. The government can still take the compromise option of having their convention with a normal compulsory attendance vote. That is the normal way in which Australians turn up on an election day and vote at polling booths.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that would be very sensible compromise for this government to adopt. I think it is very immature to say, `It is our way or nothing.' The Democrats would like to see a convention, but we do not want to see one that is undermined by the processes. Unfortunately, I think that is the risk we run.

Just to deal with some points of refutation: firstly, Senator Minchin spoke at length about the 25 per cent, the quarter, of his fellow citizens who are undecided and how terrible it was to ask them to decide on voting for a convention. I think he makes the mistake of translating 25 per cent undecided on the matter of a republic. I think he should ask himself how many of those 25 per cent would have a view on `Do we want an Australian head of state?' They may not be decided on the form a republic should take, they may have some reservations about the structure that might follow such a plebiscite, but I do not think it is right to say that 25 per cent undecided means that they do not have a view on the fundamental question.

Secondly, the Democrats would argue that the compulsory vote has within it the elements of a plebiscite. It is the same as in a general election. People still ultimately have to make a choice. And we read in the papers in the last week of every campaign the high undecided figure. But on election day our system asks them to focus and make their choice. And they do.

I have heard Senator Minchin in a few interviews now talk about the way in which the Senate—usually he says Labor but perhaps he is saying the Senate now—wants to gaol all these people who do not want to vote. Senator Murray has given me the figures from the 1993 election. The number of Australians who refused to pay their fine for failing to vote and went to gaol is 43.

Senator Minchin, I think, conjured up images of two to three million Australians roaming around the country that this government would have to hunt down and send to gaol for failure to vote. What happens nor mally is that the Australian Electoral Commission sends them a `please explain' letter, and most of them have an explanation. It is no big deal. This is a pretty desperate kind of scare tactic, which I do not think is finding resonance out there in the community.

I have heard the argument about other countries so many times. We do not have to have a cultural cringe which says, `Maybe we have got something wrong for our country because everybody else does it differently.' We have confidence in the system which is a product of our history, our politics, our culture and which works for us. That is the important thing, not what America does, with low voter turnouts. Why should it be a problem if we have a system similar to that in one other country with respect to compulsion and similar to that in one other country with respect to the type of voting for the Senate? Why should that be a problem? If it works for us, it works and that is what is important. And our citizens understand it. So I do not think that is a very persuasive argument at all. I do not think Australians have rushed to embrace that argument when it comes to privatisation either. We do not think that, lemming‐like, we leap off the cliff, just because other countries do it.

I think the most compelling argument of all is that we should have a convention that we all own, that we have all cast a vote for, which therefore has legitimacy and authority for its deliberations, whatever they may be. That gives it the authority to go forward to the next step, whatever that may be. Those things are important: ownership, legitimacy, authority, to decide on the fundamental question on the only occasion on which this government is giving us that opportunity.

I am afraid the Democrats just do not trust the longer term agenda of undermining compulsory voting in this country. You can say it all you like, Senator Minchin, but I am afraid the agenda was exposed in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, and I think the timing was helpful. I think the Senate should insist on these amendments. I just say again that the government does have another option. It can have its convention. I hope it does have its conven tion. It can have a convention where the delegates are elected in a normal, compulsory attendance vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Faulkner indicated, the opposition does maintain its concerns with the bill. Of course, we hope that other senators do as well. During this debate a raft of legitimate concerns have been raised and traversed here. They are starting to be understood by the electorate. But I think it is unfortunate that the government not only has not taken the chance to agree with them but also has not taken the opportunity to even consider them.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the government that I think you are misreading the electorate. We are talking here of an issue—the republic—which has got 70 per cent support in the electorate. Roughly 70 per cent of the electorate support a compulsory vote. I have to say to you, Senator Minchin, that many are starting to think that you are trying to pull a real dodgy manoeuvre here. My experience today on the Australia Talks Back program for one hour between 12 and one o'clock, when at least 30 people called the program, was that only one person supported the government's position. All the others were critical and suspicious of what you are trying to pull off here. Seventy per cent of the public supports a republic Australia and 70 per cent of your members, in fact, support compulsory voting.

We have been presented with the government's most recent position today. They are threatening a double dissolution on this issue; they want to reintroduce it in three months time. You do not really expect us to believe that John Howard is going to go to a double dissolution as a proponent of the republic, do you? I say to you, Senator Minchin, that you are throwing around the double dissolution threat these days like confetti at a wedding. It is losing credibility. To pretend that this particular issue is one that might trigger it is something that I think you would be embarrassed to pursue.

You have got fundamental flaws with your proposition. We have seen tonight, for instance, in an act of desperation, that the cost of the alternative has been jumped up from $49 million to $53 million, $54 million, $55 million. We had to drag you back from $53½ million the first time, when you bowled in the figures of a Senate election and a House of Representatives election together in an attempt to mislead the public. The real bottom line difference is no more than $3 million or $4 million or $5 million, and you know it. What you are trying to do is conceal it. People could say, `Why is the government doing this?' One really only has to look at the composition of the government delegation to the convention to see that you are talking about possibly two out of 16 who are not monarchists. About 80 per cent of your delegation will support and do support monarchy Australia. That is why you are trying to dissemble and manoeuvre your way out of facing the people on this.

Our benchmark is the one that you set before the election, the one that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) set, and that is to involve all the people in all parts of the process—the beginning, the middle and the end. You have betrayed that commitment. There are 10 fundamental questions that you need to ask. They have been bowled up and you have not even started to consider them. Why a voluntary vote when 70 per cent of the public believes in a compulsory vote, when 68 per cent of your party believes in a compulsory vote? Less than one in five Australians want a voluntary vote.

Why are you trying to pull this on? Why a voluntary vote when we are talking about an issue as fundamental as the constitution? What we are talking about here is defining the terms of the plebiscite, something as critical as that. Something which will also flow from this convention will be whether we have a referendum or a plebiscite—another critical step in the process. Why do you not concede that, on the best available evidence, some seven million people will not vote. Thirty‐five to 40 per cent public participation is in excess of the average in voluntary voting elections, postal voting elections, in Australia.

Are you not concerned about the fact that at least 2½ million people or three million people will have difficulty in voting? Why are you not concerned about those who have changed addresses, those 2½ million families from non-English speaking backgrounds, those hundreds of thousands who have trouble voting and need assistance because of their lack of literacy skills, disability or age? Why do you try to confuse everyone with a new system of voting when you know the size of the ballot paper will be the same whatever system you use?

Why are you not concerned—and this is something that all Australians have been concerned about in terms of ballots for parliament—about the secrecy of the ballot? Why are you not concerned about the security of the ballot? You are not even putting an extra penny into ensuring that, when the ballot slips are posted out and delivered, they are protected. Not one extra dollar will go towards security for the delivery of the postal ballots. Your suggestion that you use a birthday to protect security is open to rorts and you know it. You continue to fudge the figures. The more desperate you get the bigger they get.

Why are you in a state of self‐denial over the practicalities? As I said last time we debated this legislation, people will have to fold, refold, unfold and fold again to get the ballot paper into the size envelope supplied. We will embark upon a system of stuffing envelopes which really will take us into a national game of origami.

Why do you continue to exclude the public from basic information? Last Friday was the day on which you were expecting those who were appointed to reply to you and to tell you whether they would participate in the convention. Why will you not tell us now who has accepted those nominations? Why are we not entitled to know? Why are we not entitled to know publicly and widely that for the first time in 25 years the President of the ACTU has not been invited to a national summit of importance? We know that all the appointments are of a political nature. You admitted very clearly and loudly last week that no public servant was involved in the process. All people were appointed by politicians.

The fact of the matter is that there are more problems with your proposal now than there were in the past. I do not think your standover behaviour and thuggery is working in the electorate. You know, for instance, that, even if 100 per cent of those who voted on your terms voted republic, then only 35 to 40 per cent of Australians would be seen to supporting a republic. You would dismiss it then as an insufficient consensus.

It is unfortunate that you floated either no convention or a fully appointed convention as the alternatives. Do you know what is common to both those options? They are both undemocratic. They both deny participation of the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are autocratic.

—They are very autocratic. On the weekend, the Prime Minister very clearly said in London—and think about this—`If there is a consensus then we will have a referendum, and if there is no consensus then we will go to the plebiscite.' The challenge is to you, Senator Minchin, and the government to consider what the Prime Minister said. It is clear that under your formula—and Mr Tony Abbott has already let the cat out of the bag about this—you have designed a proposal which will ensure that there is no consensus. It entrenches division and confusion. You know that and that is why you have bowled it up.

SPEECH.PARA: If you cannot reach consensus, then why do you not look at going directly to the proposal that you would go to if consensus is not reached at the convention, and that is the plebiscite. It would be a lot easier and you know that full well. It would save a bit of money as well. If your proposition is that if you cannot reach consensus through a convention then you go to a plebiscite, why not go to a plebiscite straight away? Unfortunately, I think your threats in recent days reveal your real agenda and that is you are not really serious about pursuing the Australian republic.

In closing, I put you, Senator Minchin, and the government on notice that the opposition will not let the issue die. You may pull the plug on the convention, but not on support for a republic. That has grown in recent years and it continues to grow. We on this side of the parliament will continue to explore and develop processes that both consider and implement the issue. We will continue to explore such processes and options until the Australian people have their say. We believe it should be before the next election. If you do not bite the bullet before then, we will make sure that it is an issue at the next election. As we are celebrating—

TALK.START.PARA: —You tried that at the last election and it failed.

—Senator Minchin said that we tried that at the last election and that failed. There were a number of other issues involved there, Senator Minchin. You confused the electorate at the election with your proposal, which was in a sense for all of us, as you put it. In the event that you take an undemocratic response to this, the opposition will develop options and keep on putting them to the people until the people actually participate in a democratic process.
—Senator Bolkus, your comments that Senator Minchin was involved in thuggery verge on being unparliamentary. In future I will rule them out of order.
—I didn't take it seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I have discovered through this process, Senator Minchin, that you have a sense of humour, which is always a valued commodity. You provoked my sense of humour when you spoke about the three million Australians that are going to be hunted down. I can imagine future Halloweens with Minchin masks and people being absolutely terrified that the one that got the three million is going to get you too. It goes a little far.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to add too much to what has been said and I am aware that this is a debate which we have had, and had well. I want to say a number of things which I think are critical to evaluate in this debate. The first is that the most important plank of the government's policy is that it said it wanted a constitutional convention. Not everybody agreed that that was the right way to go. There were large numbers of people who wanted a plebiscite first or instead and for the process to follow. However, the Senate and the parliament have agreed with the government's policy of a constitutional convention, so you get one out of one. That is what you want; that is what you have got.

The government also said that they wanted to appoint half the delegates and have half elected. Not many of us agreed with that either. Many of us wanted a fully elected convention. However, the Senate and the parliament have agreed to let you have your way. So you now have two out of two. You said that you wanted a ballot at which Australians could express their views. Well, you have got that too. So that is three out of three. The only missing component in your wish list was your voluntary voting wish as opposed to the Australian way—the best democratic practice of compulsory voting. I think you are being somewhat petulant, quite frankly, to be complaining in the way you are when you get three out of four.

Then you put up the proposition to the Senate and to the public at large: `But this is an impossible vote to manage.' It does not go down very well because we have been managing elections in this way for 80 years. That is quite a long time. But we specifically asked at the hearings for the AEC to tell us whether could they manage a compulsory attendance vote and the answer was yes. They understood all the problems. The answer from them was that they can do the job. The AEC, the outfit that has been managing all our elections very successfully, the outfit which confirmed your own election to government, say that they can do the job.

Then we have the argument: `But our system is kind of unique. We are the only people doing it.' In our parliamentary committee processes there is deceit and the deceit is that committee reports are produced and they do not say in the wording: `The majority of the committee said . . . ' or `The majority of the committee came to the view . . . ' They say, `The committee said . . . ' Sometimes if committees are filled up with people from particular factions there can even be the deceit that a minority is pursuing a particular view.

My view is that the deceit with the electoral matters report is that the recommendation for voluntary voting has majority support. It does not, not in the House of Representatives and not in the Senate. The deceit is also that very few countries pursue compulsory voting. If you look at my minority report there is a list of 21 countries which pursue a variant of compulsory voting, not exactly as we have it but a variant of it. That is 21 countries. You can say, `That is not so many, not many big countries there.' Very many of those countries are far bigger in population than we are.

There are about 200 countries, I understand, in the world. You can say that that is only 10 per cent, but only half of those countries are democracies. So 20 per cent of democracies are moving towards Australian best practice of compulsory voting. The list is growing—more and more people are attracted by it. The problem is that the elite never like to let go, so it is a long, long process.

You are supporting the progress towards voluntary voting because it will deliver your party a benefit. It is as cold and strategic and political as that. However, let us have a look at some of your arguments. You claim that these kinds of votes go on all the time. You say, `Local government do it and they do it successfully. Why can't we do it nationally on the same basis?' I happen to know of local government elections that have an eight per cent turnout.

TALK.START.PARA: —The big ones!

—Those are the big ones. What guarantee have you got that your style of election will not result in a local government style turnout? Some validity, some legitimacy, you are going to get for your convention as a result of that! That may suit the agenda of those who want to leave the system as it is, but it does not suit those who want to see an expression of the full Australian will. We know that on that day they will choose as they choose at an election. Those who say that they are undecided now will choose and they will choose either a republican or a monarchist candidate. When they choose you will know, all of us will know, that is the way Australia is moving. Once that day comes the die will be cast. That is it. You cannot resist it.

BREAK.PARA: I often think of the Prime Minister as John Canute, trying to hold back the waves of republicanism. He might succeed for a couple of years, but you have no chance. You are going to be rolled. Whatever way you try to manipulate this process you are going to be rolled over by those waves.

Let us go back to the arguments for compulsory voting. It is the Australian way. It is well known and understood. The AEC say that they can manage it. It does not invalidate your desire for a convention which is half appointed and half elected, exactly as you have designed it. The AEC maintain that they can manage it successfully. It will deliver a plebiscite indication as a result of people who vote either republican or monarchist. It is for those reasons, amongst others that have been expressed, that I and my party will continue to vote as we did previously and to resist your intention to reject the Senate amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is faced with somewhat of a dilemma—whether to insist upon the amendments or not to insist upon the amendments. The motion that is before us is not to insist upon the amendments. It matters not, as was explained by the chair previously, whether the motion is to insist or not to insist. The vote that is ultimately taken will not materially change that particular decision.

SPEECH.PARA: I might indicate now to the committee that nothing that has been said in this particular debate, nor in the period from the previous debate, has influenced me to change my vote. I know that these matters are difficult and are such that there can be genuinely held differences of opinion about them. For example, were we not to insist upon the amendments, what would occur then? It seems that there are quite a number of people who believe that that would mean that there would be, for the first time in the federal system as we know it, a vote which was not a compulsory attendance secret ballot.

Of course, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, has stated, this is not a federal election; it is an election for some of the delegates to the Constitutional Convention. I do not want to go over and rehash the arguments that I used on the previous occasion, which talked about the need for those elected delegates throughout Australia to be elected on the basis of equality of representations from the state. That argument was put forward by me but not taken up by anybody else.

On the last occasion, I expressed my disappointment that this particular measure put forward by the government and that aspect of it supported by the opposition, had put paid to the principle that had been adopted by the parliament on all previous occasions, as far as I know, when it came to the composition of constitutional conventions—that is to say, that there was an equality of representation from all the states. I do not want to belabour that point.

What we then come to is, if the government's proposal is accepted, it does go back to a situation whereby, for the first time, you do not have a compulsory attendance secret ballot. That would be a shame, because it would undermine a system of elections that has stood the test of time in Australia, is well understood by the Australian people and, I believe, well supported by the Australian people. It is something with which they are familiar, they are comfortable, and which they support.

Anything that would undermine that is fraught with danger. Indeed, the system of voluntary voting, as has been described in the government's original bill, would, in my view, lead to the sort of arm twisting that sometimes goes on in these sorts of polls not only in local government elections but also in some other elections for organisations that I know of. People go to people's homes and ask them whether they have voted and, if not, whether they could assist them with the voting, and perhaps they even go so far as taking the ballot and posting it for those people—rounding up in nursing homes and all the rest of it.

However, we do have to look at what might occur if the government's motion is defeated and the Senate insists upon its amendments. First of all, might I indicate one point for the committee. Senator Minchin mentioned—I may be mistaken here, and he can correct me if I am wrong—that there would be some difficulty in respect of a compulsory attendance secret ballot for persons who wished to vote under the line to be able to do so, whereas if the voting was to take place by way of optional postal balloting, there would be time for them to vote under the line and fill out all the squares. I took that to mean, difficulty in the time they might think is available to them. In fact, there is plenty of time, as they can stay in the polling booth for as long as they like, but I thought that that was the message and Senator Minchin can correct me if that is not what he is saying.

As I understand it, the Senate adopted opposition amendment No. 52 which enabled optional preferential voting under the line. As honourable senators would know, section 170 (1) of the Commonwealth Electoral Act does include a savings provision which enables a person who votes under the line to vote, in effect, for 90 per cent of the candidates with a maximum of three errors. That vote would still be counted as a formal vote.

I understand that in this particular election there probably would be a large number of candidates. As I understood the point of the proposal put forward by the opposition, it was on this particular occasion to have some sort of preferential voting. Therefore, as I understood it, that amendment would mean that a person need, in effect, only vote for one person if they were voting under the line.

I notice that that amendment has been disagreed to by the House of Representatives, and I am not sure where we are if we do not insist at least upon that particular amendment. If we were not to do so, I do not know whether it would place a serious burden on those who wish to vote under the line. At all events, I will vote so as to ensure that the Senate does insist upon the amendments we have made.

However, one of the things that does concern me is: where to now? What will the government do? It has been suggested to me by persons who are, indeed, of a republican bent: better some convention than no convention at all. Others who are also republicans and some who are persons who want to retain the status quo have indicated to me that, if there were to be a convention, the convention should have some credibility. They were quite convinced that, if there were not a compulsory attendance secret ballot, the convention itself would lack credibility.

That is a very strong argument and one that has to be taken into account both by persons who wish to retain the status quo and by those who wish to see Australia a republic. It is important that any constitutional convention have legitimacy. I suggest that the response to the government's proposal would be only about 30 per cent; that it would be only about 30 per cent of Australians who would vote in a ballot such as is proposed by the government. I also suggest that that would not give legitimacy to the Constitutional Convention. That would work against the interests of those who wish to have the status quo and those who wish to see Australia a republic.

But, of course, as I have mentioned before in a previous debate, the electorate is not divided only into those who wish to see the status quo remain and those who wish to see Australia a republic. There are provisional republicans—those who wish perhaps to retain the Queen as the head of state whilst she is about. There are others who have various views about how the constitution should go.

One thing does concern me about the government's proposal: it is inevitably going to throw up those people from the fringes who have their own agendas to pursue, including agendas which would disturb and undermine revered parts of our constitution. Generally speaking, apart from a few, I think there is agreement around this parliament. In general, the type of agreement I understand most members of parliament have is that there should ultimately be proposals that the status quo be retained or the minimalist public republic position should be the one to be accepted. I do not believe that, amongst members of this chamber or members of the House of Representatives, there are very many members or senators who have another view.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—I acknowledge the comment by Senator Collins. I do not believe that there is an intention to radically alter the constitution. However, if the government now says, `Well, no convention, unless under our terms,' my worry is that considerable concern will be caused in the community. The community wants to see this issue advanced. Even many of those who wish to retain the status quo want at least to see the matter settled one way or the other. The alternative is to have an uneasy status quo in this country leading up to the year 2000, where we do not know whether we are Arthur or Martha. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem here is that the government does not have any give. This is not the government's constitutional convention; it is not the government's process towards a republic. It belongs to the people of Australia and it belongs to the whole of the parliament. If we were to get a resolution here rather than having constitutional constipation, we would have give and take. The government would take maybe a little of the salts for clearing the system and brightening up the mind—refreshing the liver, if you like—by looking at some of the amendments brought forward by other components of this parliament and making sure that we moved on towards the inevitable public involvement in the process of Australia moving towards the inevitable republic. But I think we are getting bogged down here because the government does not have any give.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset the Greens believe that the whole of the convention—and we are prepared to give on the fact that there be a convention—ought to be elected by the people. But we could not find support on that anywhere. We also believe that, at the same time as the election of all persons representing Australians at this convention, there should be a simple yes/no plebiscite on whether people want a republic or not. That would involve every Australian at the outset in putting forward her or his view on the fundamental question which is at stake here, instead of delegating it to the indirect decision of the people for whom they might vote or leaving it to the outcome of the convention.

During the earlier debate I gave the cogent reasons as to why we ought to be following that path. It is sheer logic that a convention get a direction from the people as to whether or not they want a republic. Opinion polls show they would get that direction and then the convention could get on with the business of determining what sort of republic and how we get there, rather than bogging down into the slog between monarchists and republicans which will not differ too much from the position we find ourselves in here in the Senate tonight—people entrenched, people unable to give, no result coming out of that. Maybe we should have the people involved in breaking this impasse that is occurring here tonight—if only we were more technically equipped for the quick vote.

The government has to get off its high horse, not take unto itself the opinion that it and it alone is the arbiter of how this process will work. Indeed, it will work towards the outcome it wants because those two things are inseparable. If the government is determined it will not have any give on the process, how can there be much faith that it will have a laissez-faire approach to the outcome, either as expressed by the convention or by a consequent plebiscite or referendum of the people of Australia.

So right from the start this process is getting into difficulties because there is not any give from the government. We ought to be able to discuss the various components and make a breakthrough here, but I am afraid that the government is entrenched on abandoning the traditional compulsory voting component that Australians are used to. Quite conversely, it is determined to break with tradition and have a postal voting system rather than attendance at polling booths. It is resolute in not allowing a further panel on what is going to be a long voting paper for candidates which would allow people to say yes or no on the republic and, moreover, it is determined that it is not going to give an inch on its right to appoint half the delegates rather than allocate that right to Australians.

The outcome of this will be a lot of huffing and puffing over winter before there is another attempt at resolution and a delay in the Constitutional Convention until the new year. My point of view is that, if this impasse continues in the Senate, the government should take a good look at itself and its entrenched position and think about whether it is really a matter of saving dollars and cents. It should ask itself whether those arguments are really enough to cover the fact that it is hidebound about this, that it does not want to entertain other people's ideas, that it does not see this as a conjoint effort of the parliament representing the people rather than a sectional decision made by the government of the day.

I think it needs to consider really how best to hand the solution back to the people in whom I suspect newer members of the parliament have greater faith than do those who have been here for a longer time. If it does come down to a plebiscite, so be it. That may be the swiftest and quickest way to get the whole ball rolling again—a simple plebiscite that says to people: do you or do you not want a republic? In my view, the whole exercise of a convention is trammelled at the outset by not taking that advice from the people.

I cannot understand why no other party in the Senate is backing that option. It is such a fundamental one: ask the people at the outset what they want. You are going to have a multimillion dollar vote, so let them tick another box. Excuses about it costing million of dollars more, which the government uses to counter such an option, just do not stick. In the long run, taking such an option will save a heck of a lot of money. I believe that it will save the convention itself—it will save it from bogging down in an entrenched slog between monarchists and republicans, with a few people wavering in the middle, with no resolution.

Remember that the government uses the word `consensus' here; it wants a consensus coming out of that constitutional convention. Really, it is going to be a very short‐of‐the‐mark consensus if the lowest common denominator has to be reached between entrenched republicans and entrenched monarchists. That is what it will be.

I say again, I cannot understand why there is no support outside the Greens in this place for a plebiscite at the outset, or at least with this vote, so Australians can break that impasse which we can all see coming down the line. Give them the vote at the outset; trust in the people. That is what this should be. If the other components of this Senate were more willing to do that we would be a long way down the line towards breaking the impasse we find ourselves in tonight.

The impasse is going to have to be viewed with a fresh set of eyes by the government over the winter break. All of us, indeed, need to look at whether there is room for movement on this matter. All of us are going to suffer in the eyes of the people we represent if we cannot even get to first base in moving towards the republic, or at least towards the review of who should be head of state, which all Australians have talked about, thought about and become involved in in the last few years.

I do not see in this return from the House of Representatives any sign of give or take at all. All I do see is the government saying, `Take it or leave it.' Is that an injunction to the convention? Are you saying to delegates to this convention, `Take it or leave it; tell the other side to take it or leave it'? It is not a good way to go. It is going to take a review in cabinet to help break this impasse. All of us here need to be committed, however, to give and take, to make sure that this process does not go beyond the winter break and that we come out of that with a resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply offer the government, the opposition and other parties my support for a consideration of how best to process this matter after the decision has been made by the Senate tonight. Could I indicate to Senator Minchin my apology that I had misunderstood the situation. We had adopted opposition amendment No. 52 which went to ensuring that there was not an undue burden placed upon those who wished to vote beneath the line. The Senate adopted that measure and the House of Representatives has rejected that. But I point out to the committee that, of course, that would mean government section 103(6) would apply, which also goes to alleviating the burden of those who wish to vote under the line.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator MINCHIN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not prolong this debate by making any more than a few closing comments. I do remind the Senate that the government was elected overwhelmingly last year with a policy that was clearly not in favour of a republic. We went out there quite openly saying that it was not our policy to turn Australia into a republic; we thought the current system worked very well and was not in need of change. A number of speakers who spoke in this debate in favour of compulsion said, `If it works for us, why should we change it?' That is exactly the argument we put to the Australian people and they endorsed us.

SPEECH.PARA: We also said, however, that we would be willing to have a debate on this matter through the forum of a convention to which half the delegates are elected. That was the policy. It was not to have a plebiscite. We did not say we would have an appointed convention. We could have gone to the election saying that. It would have then been legitimate for us to have an appointed convention. We did not; we said that we would like to have a convention at which half the delegates are elected.

Coming into government we have thought long and hard about how to put that into effect. We think the method we have proposed is most reasonable and sensible. But we now have a situation where the Senate is saying to the government that we cannot implement our policy unless it is exactly on the terms dictated to us by the Senate, which we do not believe are practicable, fair or reasonable.

Figures have been quoted about `undecided' and `those in favour' of a republic. I want to make a point about what that all means for any compulsory vote. Newspoll, which is owned and conducted by News Ltd, which is, as we all know, very much in favour of the republic, ran its survey—it has been running for some time—in February this year. It asked, `Are you in favour or against Australia becoming a republic?' It found that 47 per cent were in favour of a republic, down from the 50 per cent in June 1995, 28 per cent were against and 25 per cent were uncommitted. Those are the figures that I have been relying on. Most of us in politics regard Newspoll as at least as reliable and accurate as any other polling organisation and, of course, it is one that in this case is in favour of this change.

The figures revealed that there is not a majority in favour of this change. But they also showed that 25 per cent are genuinely uncommitted about this question. We have therefore based our estimates of the effect of what the Senate insists we do in relation to this issue on those sorts of figures. We do not believe that the Senate has made a legitimate case for this election of delegates to a 10‐day convention to be conducted on the basis proposed by the Senate.

Much of the debate has been about the question of whether or not federal elections should be compulsory. That is utterly irrelevant to this question of what sort of electoral system do we use to elect delegates to the convention.

No doubt the Labor Party and this parliament dealt with the question of ATSIC elections on their merits when that matter was debated. I was not here. But you have put in place a system whereby ATSIC elections are voluntary. Where was the great rhetoric about how vital and essential compulsory voting was in that case? Senator Harradine said that, if you only get a 30 per cent turnout, it makes the convention utterly illegitimate. My understanding is that ATSIC elections get a turnout of 30 per cent. Are you saying to us that ATSIC is utterly illegitimate? If that is your position, so be it, but we have not stated that.

I find it most remarkable that you are insisting on compulsion in this case when that has not been the case in the past. It is remarkable and an interesting fact that the only precedent we have for an election of delegates to a convention of this kind was in the 1890s when it was voluntary. And it was voluntary right through until 1924, when the parliament decided that people had to be forced to vote. I put it to you that it is unduly authoritarian and unacceptable to the Liberal Party and the coalition government to force people to participate in this particular proposal.

For a whole variety of reasons, I think that the Senate has failed to convince the government that its proposed method of election of delegates is sensible, reasonable or rational. I therefore repeat that we ask the committee not to insist on its amendments.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Minchin's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner adjournment I was speaking about the fact that, after some very extended negotiations with the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), the Democrats working with the industry were able to get a number of significant improvements—not only improvements but in fact wins—for people who were disadvantaged. I am pleased to be able to put on the record what those wins were.

SPEECH.PARA: One is the commitment of the minister to an independent review of the residential classification scale instrument after three months of operation. This is very important because the figures which are coming in from the various nursing homes and hostels give a very uneven picture about how the instrument will work. Some of those people are saying that they will improve significantly in terms of the funding. The majority are saying that, in fact, they will be worse off.

It is impossible, without having the instrument tested in practice rather than in theory, to really establish what the effect will be. I think it is very important that the minister has said that she will review this after three months—not to delay it for two years but to virtually immediately take note of the effect. She will put a proposition to the cabinet if it shows up that there is significant disadvantage. I think that is important.

The second commitment is that there will be a wider independent review of the whole act at the end of the two years and then annual reporting to parliament. It is very important that this be an independent review. The minister accepted that. The industry pressed that very hard. The Democrats did have an amendment along those lines, which we will not press because of the commitment of the government on that.

The next commitment given by the minister is a very important one. That was an increase in the concessional resident supplement, guaranteeing a flat $7 per concessional resi dent for facilities with nought to 40 per cent concessional residents and a flat $12 per day per resident for those facilities with 41 per cent to 100 per cent concessional residents. This really means that these Democrat steered negotiations have delivered an extra $40 million per annum into the residential aged care sector. The Democrats also gained an agreement from the minister on the establishment of a complaints mechanism in each state which will deal with all aspects of residential care.

I am quite sure that some will criticise us for our decision to support this legislation today. We are willing to cop that criticism, but we believe that, when politics is stripped back, the basic agreement reached by the Democrats, the churches and the minister is not only practical but a positive step forward in dealing with the increasing pressure on both capital and recurrent expenditure for this important sector of a caring society.

We have eliminated the risk that was contained in the minister's original proposal of a two‐tier system developing where facilities for the rich would become significantly better than those for the less well off. I simply want to place on the record some extracts from what the major churches said today.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would you get a two‐tiered system, John?

—We will have the debate later. I am quite happy to go into that very extensively, Senator Murphy, because I believe you need an answer to that question. It is a very good one. The Chairman of Anglicare Australia, Bishop Curnow, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your time and energies over the last week or so, especially in negotiation over a better deal for the aged care reform. We appreciate the difficulty of protecting low income people in the current economic environment and would like to recognise your work in this regard.
Aged Care Australia still has reservations about the legislation but the organisation says:

ACA is prepared to support the legislation in the belief that the government will honour its commitments and will continue to work with the organisation to achieve a better system of residential aged care for older Australians.
Here is a comment from a media release by the Executive Director of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, Mr Sullivan:

"ACHCA wishes to express their gratitude to all members of the federal parliament in their reception to the association's concerns and suggestions. In particular, the support and help offered by the Australian Democrats over the negotiation period considerably advanced our cause," Mr Sullivan said.
The Uniting Church said:
. . . We have appreciated in particular the assistance of the Democrats in the negotiation of this more equitable reform package.
And from Anglicare itself:

The Catholic, Uniting and Anglican Churches together have negotiated for an extra $45 million into aged care, to be used to increase the payment for concessional residents from $5 per day to $7 for facilities under 40% of concessional residents, and $12 per day for facilities with more than 40% of concessional residents.

I would like to say that there is still a long way to go. I do not think we have solved all the problems in any sense, but I do believe that with this minister, and hopefully with the government, there is an openness to continue the discussions and to continue to work on these reforms, and I believe that will ensure a future for our parents, our grandparents and possibly for some of us in years to come.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibbs, Sen Brenda

TALK.START.PARA: —In reading the Aged Care Bill, it would appear that nursing homes have disappeared and vanished from the face of this earth. George Orwell would be proud of this bill. It should be called the Aged Care Bill of 1984, not 1997. It is extremely difficult to find the words `nursing care' anywhere in this bill, and I have still to find any reference to `nursing homes' or indeed `nurses'. This seems strange indeed when Australians have always used the words `nursing home' to describe residential facilities that cater for aged people who require a great deal of nursing care by trained nurses. But in the government's Orwellian version of aged care, nurses, nursing care and nursing homes are virtually ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: To save $400 million, this government will allow nursing homes, now to be called `residential facilities', to be run by managers with no nursing experience. No longer do nursing homes have to employ a qualified director of nursing who will ensure that professional standards are met. In reading this bill, I repeatedly read references to residential care as if every resident of these nursing homes was merely going there as an alternative place to live when, in reality, they go there because they need high‐quality nursing care. If they did not need this sort of qualified nursing care, they would go to a retirement village or would continue to lead their independent lives.

Under this legislation, there will be dramatically increased costs for gaining admission to a nursing home and dramatically decreased guarantees of the level of care that residents will receive. The previous system was transparent and allowed everyone to have some certainty about the staffing levels and the skill of staff in nursing homes. The new system will encourage proprietors to maximise their profits by deskilling their work force and subsequently downgrading the level of care to residents.

BREAK.PARA: The removal of the audit requirements for the care aggregate module funds means there will no longer be the checks and balances to ensure safe nursing levels or personal care levels. The collapsing of the CAM‐SAM and OCRE funds into one payment, based on resident dependency, will mean there will be no requirements to employ staff for these facilities according to resident dependency. It appears to be a reckless act by a government that has been captured by the private nursing home owners lobby.

The bill is very sparse on details about the residential subsidy classification instrument and arrangements for training of staff. Senators are entitled to have more detailed information on the implementation details, as is the nursing home industry. The quality of care section of this bill is extremely non‐specific about what this quality means and certainly does not specify that qualified nursing staff have to be employed. The closest reference states that providers must maintain an adequate number of appropriately skilled staff to ensure the care needs of care recipients are met.
