The term `appropriately skilled staff' could mean anything. If there are no qualified nursing staff, and especially if there are no directors of nursing, who is going to ensure that the taxpayers' money that the government allocates to these nursing homes is properly spent on nursing care?

The minister is going around claiming that accreditation will take care of everything. But accreditation, at least until the year 2000, only involves the buildings, not the personal care. The nurses union has brought to my attention that the removal of the audit requirements on prospectively funded long service leave for which funds have already been allocated will create a positive incentive for proprietors to make redundant any nurses who have worked for them for between five and 10 years. This is particularly disturbing because people who go into nursing homes require a level of care only nursing staff can provide. This could be because of illness, disease, incapacity or disability. In this bill there is a deliberate budget driven omission which fails to appreciate the health risk to residents in reducing or removing nurses.

We have heard much about the market forces that will come into play to ensure the level of nursing care will be just wonderful, but this is a fallacy—there are no market forces. The government has set a minimum level of fees but not a maximum, and will strictly limit and licence the number of nursing home beds it will fund. This means that those with few or no assets will have trouble accessing the limited number of beds because they will not give nursing home owners the same level of financial return. In other words, there is no market; just a system that will do little for those who need nursing home care and are not financially attractive to proprietors. There is no guarantee in this legislation that rural and remote areas will receive adequate nursing home beds. So‐called market forces will not address that.

Earlier this year I heard the details of an elderly man in Emerald who had to be moved hundreds of kilometres away from the rest of his family because there was an inadequate number of nursing home beds in the town. The tragedy of this particular incident was that the man, isolated from his family, died a few weeks later.

Aged care should never regress to the situation before 1984, as highlighted in the Giles report. This report highlighted a range of complaints against nursing homes. In fact, some of the photographs of neglected patients with bed sores you could put your fist into were horrifying. The horror stories continue.

Up‐front fees or accommodation bonds will cost residents entering a nursing home between $26,000 and $100,000 or more, depending on whether you believe the government or industry leaders. Over five years, nursing home proprietors will be able to keep $13,000 of that up‐front free. The pretext, put forward by the coalition government for introducing these fees, is that it will allow nursing homes to upgrade their facilities. This is largely based on the Gregory report, which found many nursing homes wanting. If this is really the case, then why is there nothing in the Aged Care Bill to compel nursing homes to use the money for that purpose?

So there we have it: the elderly will be forced to sell their homes and pay most of their money to the nursing homes. If the nursing home accepts them, there is nothing to make the home use that money for upgrades and, even if they do, most of the elderly who pay this fee will not even see the improvements if they eventually do take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—They will be dead. There is nothing to stop the $13,000, plus interest, because it will be invested, becoming part of an increased profit line. That is an incredibly irresponsible stand for any government to take, and it makes a nonsense out of this government's constant claims about caring for all Australians. Many homes will still find it very difficult to upgrade their facilities. These, of course, are the homes run by the church groups, which always take higher proportions of the financially disadvantaged—the disadvantaged that the Howard government plays plenty of lip‐service to, but does very little to assist.

BREAK.PARA: The report looked at the situation of hostels because they already have entry fees which were supposed to be targeted at upgrading facilities. But, according to the Gregory report, 21 per cent of hostels that are more than 15 years old have not been refurbished, and 16 per cent of hostels, mostly older stock, are currently required by a government authority to undertake capital upgrading. The report went on to say that these older hostels are more likely to contain higher proportions of financially disadvantaged people, possibly reflecting lower standards and a more institutional design. The report also said that there are two overlapping sets of hostels that are a cause for concern. Firstly, those hostels built in 1979 or earlier which have not been refurbished—approximately 11 per cent of hostels or 8,000 places—do not appear to be able to attract sufficient entry contribution paying residents to accumulate funds for a rebuild.

Secondly, hostels required to have high proportions of financially disadvantaged people are unable to access funds from residents and seem less able to access funds from a parent organisation or from the community. Also, hostels with low proportions of financially disadvantaged people receive nearly three times as much in non-operating income than do hostels with high proportions of financially disadvantaged people. With some nursing homes attracting three times the non-operating income of others, the potential to create two levels of nursing home care—the luxury model and the pauper's model—is high indeed.

The government and the Democrats have apparently come to an agreement about a sliding scale for the level of concessional resident subsidy. An increase over the pathetic amount of $5 that was originally offered by the government of $7 per resident in homes with up to 40 per cent concessional residents and $12 for each and every resident in homes with between 41 per cent and 100 per cent concessional residents is welcomed.

But correspondence that I have received from church groups indicates that the minimum amount they could cope with was $12 for every resident. This government has consistently declared that the elderly will be given a choice, that no-one will be forced to sell their home, but the realities are far different, and no-one has believed the government on this particular point.

The legislation sets a minimum that nursing home residents must be left with, which is $22,500. But there is no maximum amount. The better homes will be the most attractive, and they in turn will find those aged people with bigger assets more attractive.

In an effort to limit their residents to those with plenty of cash contributions, the fees could increase considerably. Without a maximum fee, it will not be long before the entry fee for most will become the total of all assets minus the $22,500. Nursing homes at the lower end of the spectrum will be left with residents who have little or no money to contribute towards entry fees.

The poor and the vulnerable will be left floundering. Homes that do not come up to the government's standard now and cannot attract finance for upgrading will either collapse or be left with no government support at all. Without subsidies, even the poor would have trouble staying in such homes. If a nursing home has to choose between a financially disadvantaged person and a fee paying person, I think it is pretty obvious which choice they will make. If they have to make a choice between someone with a home worth $90,000 and one with a home worth $250,000, they will obviously be attracted to the person with the better assets.

Australia, thanks to the Howard government, will end up with two types of nursing homes: one for the haves and one for the have-nots—in other words, a luxury model and a pauper's model. Equity will simply go out the window.

The government is also arguing that this is simply a natural progression from the aged hostel model. However, when people enter a hostel, it is of their own choice; they know what they are getting into and have plenty of time to decide whether or not they believe this is a good option for them. People enter a nursing home in a time of crisis. Sixty per cent of admissions are from acute hospitals after serious illness such as stroke. In other words, there is usually no choice in whether or not a person will go into a nursing home.

In terms of the Aged Care Income Testing Bill, I would like to know why this government is in such a hurry to set up procedures for income testing the elderly, while at the same time it has done very little to put in place arrangements for protecting the money that is paid into these homes as entry fees.

What, for instance, is to stop a nursing home going broke and effectively taking with it all of the residents' entry fees? Where are the trust funds or detailed prudential arrangements to protect these fees? How will the residents of such failed homes be able to pay to move into another nursing home? Where are this government's auditing procedures that will monitor the quality of care and the quality of the homes in general? Will it be industry based or self‐regulation? Is that how this government is going to protect the money of the elderly?

Quality health should be equally available to all Australians on the basis of need. No government should be abdicating its responsi bilities to its aged community in this way. The old and vulnerable have already lost access to the Commonwealth dental program, pay more for pharmaceuticals, pay more for home and community care programs, and are going to lose access to the government hearing service. This income testing bill and its associated nursing home fees merely add to the incredible burden that this government is throwing back at aged and vulnerable Australians.

There are more immediate concerns, however. Will the fees be increased in future and eat away even more of the disposable income of the aged? Will the nursing homes be allowed to keep more of the entry fees in future?

There is certainly pressure from the aged hostels lobby to increase the amount they can retain. The Gregory report noted that the hostels could keep $12,000 of an entry fee over five years. It stated:

Industry groups have argued that there is a need to increase the amount hostels can retain from entry contributions by lifting current restrictions. The entry contribution retention limits are set to ensure residents can obtain reasonable refunds upon departure and the amount retained is tied to length of stay.
The report goes on to talk about the positive aspects of lifting the current restrictions:

Increasing income from entry contribution amounts would enable hostels with entry contribution paying residents to pay off their capital debt sooner, provide extra income to set aside for depreciation costs, and generally boost viability. One industry suggestion is that the retention limit should be set at 5% every six months for 5 years regardless of the size of the contribution.
I believe this legislation will start a move which will work to the disadvantage of many of our most vulnerable senior citizens. I urge all senators to vote against it.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to see that so many people have come into the house to hear what I have to say in relation to the Aged Care Bill. It is interesting to see that this government has taken its usual approach and has rushed in to deal with the problem in a way that is entirely inappropriate. I believe that there is general agreement on a cross‐party basis that there is a difficulty in the funding of aged care, but certainly this is not the solution that I would consider appropriate and certainly it is not the solution that the community at large sees as the remedy to this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem of the funding of aged care has been a difficult and vexed issue for some time. Very soon after being elected to government in 1983, Labor chose to examine the situation, and a strategy was put into place in 1985 to deal with the problem. As a result, a major contribution in funding was made towards aged care, commencing at a figure of approximately $1.2 billion and going up to a figure of approximately $2.6 billion in the 1994-95 year, just before the election.

Despite this strategy, and because of the continuing explosion of those who are seen as the baby boomers coming to an age of dependency, which it is anticipated will peak some time in the next five to eight years, the funding provided by the then government has been seen to have been inadequate. The report done in 1994 indicated that there was a funding hole that had to be filled and it was required to bring a large number of nursing homes to up to an adequate level of funding. The interesting thing about the approach of this government is that you would have thought that they had done everything in their power to ensure sufficient funding and to ensure that those nursing homes were up to scratch, but nothing could be further from the truth. During the short period that this government have been in office they have taken every step possible to detract from the state of nursing homes and to reduce the funding available.

Last year, the total funds removed from aged care over four years was $577 million. Bearing in mind that in the last year before the election we put in about $2.6 billion, it is a rather major difference—approximately $2 billion. That $570 million came from $244 million in reducing outlays on capital commitments, $253 million in reducing subsidies paid to nursing homes for care, and $72 million in reducing funding to HACC, which meant that a lot of aged people who were intending to remain in their homes were having to pay user pays fees for the use of HACC. That meant that a strategy that was originally developed by the previous Labor government to ensure that people were able to remain in their homes and remain independent was taken away and greater proportions of people were being forced to go into nursing homes.

What is the bandaid solution to the capital funding crisis that now exists in the aged care sector, particularly in nursing homes? I would like to examine this Aged Care Bill and what it really does—I would have normally said for aged people, but in this case I will say to aged people. Anyone who has the misfortune to have to enter a nursing home under this bill, if it is successful, will be much worse off than they were previously.

I suppose that on the face of it these accommodation bonds are not too extreme in that they allow the removal of a maximum of $2,600 each year for a period of five years. But there is one additional factor. Nursing homes are also entitled to retain the interest which is earned on nursing home bonds or accommodation bonds—what we in the Labor Party call entry fees. Really, that is where it all turns and that is where it really becomes in the interests of nursing homes at large, at least those who act on a for profit basis, to take as high an accommodation bond or as high an entry fee as they possibly can. Obviously, the higher the entry fee they take from their residents, the higher level of interest that will be earned and the more profitable their nursing home for the aged will be.

When this issue was first starting to be debated in this house there was a suggestion that the figure that was put forward by the Labor Party, that was extrapolated from the hostel industry—a figure of $26,000—was dishonest and excessive and that, really, the fees that would have to be paid would be nowhere near that amount. With such strident propositions being put in the Senate by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) representing the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), we had some doubt that the figure of $26,000 was excessive.

BREAK.PARA: The sad thing is that it was not excessive. Evidence taken by the Community Affairs Committee at its inquiry indicated that $26,000 is very much at the low end of the spectrum and that fees of $30,000, $40,000—and, I have been advised, in some cases $110,000 and more—could be paid. A national survey of hostels indicated that the average bond is presently about $40,000. It has been put forward by the proprietors of nursing homes that they would see it as quite possible, depending on the quality of the nursing home, that bonds in excess of $110,000 could be payable. For the vast majority of people who are entering nursing homes this is a very large sum of money.

A lot of criticism about the size of the entry fee has been met by suggestions of flexibility. On the face of it, flexibility is always attractive. As is often the case with propositions about flexibility put by this government, the flexibility always goes against those in the arrangement who are weak and in favour of those who are strong. Very much in this case those residents who are entering nursing homes are in a weak position and those people who are running the nursing homes—and I tend to speak more about the for profit organisations—are in a strong position and certainly have the upper hand in negotiations.

The flexibility that is often put forward is that those people who do not want to sell their homes and may wish to pay by instalments can do so and that should be desirable for those residents and their families. The end result is that they not only pay an entry fee but also pay interest from the time the bond is due and payable until the time it is actually paid. That means that they are paying a much larger amount of money than they would otherwise pay.

The reality is that the only limitation that is placed on the size of the accommodation bond that has to be paid is the requirement that the resident, that aged, ill person who is so frail that they must have full‐time care, in that position of weakness must negotiate and the only restraint that is placed on these negotiations is that that ingoing resident retain a sum of $22,000 or 2.5 times their pension. Obviously, it is a larger amount for couples. Personally, I do not see that this sort of restriction is appropriate protection for people in those circumstances. There is great fear in the community that there will be a situation where the full extent of every potential resident's assets are taken and placed in the coffers of the nursing homes.

There is something even more insidious and which concerns me even more greatly. The system is set up so that there is, particularly for those for profit nursing homes, a general attraction, a profit, in having the class of residents who can pay an accommodation bond, particularly a large one, as against those who are not able to pay an accommodation bond. To some extent the minister has tried to calm our concerns and has suggested that the payment of a subsidy for those people who are financially disadvantaged may, to some extent, solve this problem.

The initial sum that was offered was $5 per day. That is quite a paltry amount. I remember when this sum was first suggested to Senator Newman. She rejected with some annoyance and anger our suggestion that the daily sum was that low. As the debate has developed and time has passed, it has become very clear to everyone that this is the sum that the government intends to provide to nursing homes to subsidise them for having the good grace to take on these people who are financially disadvantaged.

I know there have been extensive negotiations and some last minute wheeling and dealing. I am certain that senators such as Senator Woodley have tried to play a very positive role in this whole scheme. I do not believe that the negotiations that have taken place and the compromises that have been reached go any way towards putting those financially disadvantaged people in the same position as those who are able to pay a substantial accommodation bond.

I have had some fairly long discussions with persons from nursing homes, particularly those from the non-profit sector, who are very keen to ensure that they can continue to provide the services that they have to date to those who are financially disadvantaged. They put to me very strongly the view that the minimum subsidy that would have to be paid for a financially disadvantaged person would be somewhere in the range of $12 to $14 per day. Only if this sort of sum were paid would the nursing homes be in a situation where there would be no financial advantage for them to prefer an accommodation fee paying resident over a financially disadvantaged person who cannot afford to pay that entry fee.

Certainly the $7 subsidy, and the higher subsidy of $12 for a small group of residents when there is a higher percentage of disadvantaged residents, would be insufficient to remedy the situation. I have some sympathy for Senator Woodley. As I said before, I have faith that he is attempting to genuinely solve the problem, but it is my view that by accepting the compromise that has been put by this government he is not acting in the interests of charitable nursing homes and he is certainly not acting in the interests of those elderly people who have had difficulties in their lives, have not been able to save and do not have the funds available to them to pay this accommodation bond.

In the time I have available to me I would just like to reflect on some of the correspondence and the community concern that has been expressed to me. I know it is commonly said that there is great community concern. I suppose the value of that statement has been eroded by the number of times it has been used. But I have to say that it is true in this particular case. I have had more correspondence on this particular issue than I have probably had in the entire time I have been in the Senate.

I would like to refer to an article that was printed in the Central Coast Sun, that is around Gosford—an area where there is a large proportion of retired and elderly. There is also a large proportion of people who are retired but are really just dependent on the pension. A lot of us may not at this stage think about what it would be like to be retired on such a limited income, but I think it would be a pretty tough lifestyle. I certainly would not want to be in that position, and become frail and ill and struggling to find a nursing home that was prepared to take me because I did not have the funds to provide an accommodation bond. The article states:

Nurses working in aged care facilities on the Central Coast fear a return of the poor staffing and neglect horror stories of the 1970s and 80s in some homes with the introduction of the Aged Care Bill 1997.
More than 2000 aged care facility staff, residents and their families on the Central Coast recently signed a petition calling for amendments to the Bill.
The petition—22,000 signatures were collected NSW‐wide . . .

It goes on to talk about some of the nursing homes on the Central Coast. I will not read it all. I have also received a large number of items of correspondence, more from around New South Wales. I suppose I have to confess these were written before the change from $5 to $7. I certainly do not believe that that small change will remedy the problems. I have a letter from Bowden Brae Retirement Village in Normanhurst on the corner of Pennant Hills Road. This is just in the northern suburbs of Sydney in a reasonably affluent area. The letter says:
Our estimate of the reduction in Government subsidy will be in the region of $200,000 per annum.

I note that this is a not for profit group that does cater for those who are not very well off in the community. I have a huge stack of letters and I will not attempt to go through all of them. These are just a few samples to try to give the government an idea of how strongly people feel and how upset they really are about this whole issue. This next letter from the Lourdes Nursing Home says:

Using the available information to date, to the best of our ability we estimate that Lourdes Nursing Home will be $482,544.60 annually worse off under the new operational funding arrangements for aged care proposed by the Aged Care Bill 1997 which you will be debating this week.
A letter from the Central Coast Community Care Association states:

The Central Coast Community Care Association is a non profit, charitable organisation providing hostel accommodation for frail financially disadvantaged (concessional) residents only of the Central Coast of NSW. The estimates on an annual basis comparing the old rates with the new funding levels highlights an expected shortfall of $30,500. I attach a work sheet for your information.

I will not go on any further, but I just brought a few samples with me and I have a whole stack more in my room and also in my electorate office. I would hazard a guess that probably every member of both the Senate and the House of Representatives would have received letters and had contact in much the same vein because this bill does not resolve the problem that exists.

We concede that for essentially demographic reasons a difficulty has developed with the capital funding of aged care establishment. But to develop a system which acts to the detriment of those who are elderly and financially disadvantaged I do not believe is a solution to the problem. Certainly the proposition or the compromise which has been agreed with the Democrats of increasing the subsidy from $5 to $7, and $12 in some circumstances, will not resolve the problem. We will end up in a situation where those who can afford it will have a higher level of care in, essentially, hotel accommodation with those who cannot afford it either being left in substandard nursing homes or being unable to access nursing home care at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Aged Care Bill and associated legislation. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, said on achieving office last year that he wanted to provide Australians with a comfortable and relaxed society, and this has already been addressed by Senator Forshaw in his contribution. Mr Howard promised that the most vulnerable in the community would not be hurt. He said, `We will protect the vulnerable and the needy.' It seems obvious that he was not including our aged population in that warm and fuzzy promise.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill and its companion bills are an attack on the rights of elderly Australians to comprehensive, affordable health and community care. This discriminatory and ill-prepared bill will punish Australia's most vulnerable, older people, and will consign them to a two‐tiered system of health care that will condemn them without money or assets to a second rate level of care in older and increasingly run‐down accommodation.

In government, Labor's aged care reform strategy had major social justice objectives—access, equity and participation. Compare that strategy with those of the Howard administration which has as its driving tenet the user pays. That means you get into quality nursing home care if you have the money, and the money will determine the type of nursing home bed you get.

Where is the equity and fairness in this dollar-driven policy? Labor's policies were responsible for developing aged care based on needs rather than economic capacity to pay. Mr Howard and his Minister for Family Services, Mrs Moylan, profess compassion for the elderly community yet would abandon them to commercially driven market forces where proper care comes a distant second to profitability.

My colleague in the other place Jenny Macklin rightly asserts that the introduction of daily fees will ultimately lead to the creation of a two‐tiered system of nursing home care. In many cases, the elderly citizens of this country who are lucky enough to own a house are in the position of it being their only realisable asset. To place this group of our community in the invidious situation of having to oversee the sale of their home when they are too infirm to cope with all the attendant responsibilities this entails is irresponsible in the extreme.

Mr Howard and Mrs Moylan should visit elderly citizens' organisations and they will find out how deeply these people are concerned about what this government has done to them and how it is deserting them. Mr Howard is to be condemned for abandoning his promise to look after these vulnerable and needy people. The minister, Mrs Moylan, deserves the same condemnation for scaring the life out of ordinary decent people, people who have every right by any standard to affordable and equitable aged care facilities.

The Labor Party supports measures which lead to upgrading nursing care. It has always supported such measures. Indeed, during our 13 years in government, we instigated contin ual positive reforms and upgrade of care for elderly Australians. Let us take a minute or two to look at Labor's record in this area.

Contrary to the misrepresentations and half‐truths we have heard from Mrs Moylan and others on this matter, Labor in government undertook comprehensive reforms to aged care during its term in office. Australia's welfare 1993: services and assistance is a detailed report about Australia's health and welfare systems undertaken by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare, a body that is independent of government and political parties. That report described the major restructuring of aged care services that started in 1985. It makes the point:
It was not until the mid 1980s that a substantial overhaul of the aged care system—the Aged Care Reform Strategy—was implemented. Changes since that time have been considerable.
Labor's strategy also introduced standards of monitoring in 1987. Australia's welfare 1993 comments:

The results of a 4 year evaluation of the Standards Monitoring Program in nursing homes . . . included international comparisons, and places the Australian program at the forefront of aged care regulatory practices.

The irresponsible and strident rot being peddled by the Minister for Family Services and the Prime Minister needs to be countered. The fact of the matter is that Australia under Labor had an excellent standard of aged care; it was a world leader in the levels of care provided. This view was shared by delegates to the Alzheimers International Conference held in Scotland in 1994, just to give one example.

In adopting a more holistic approach to aged care, Labor provided security and piece of mind for older Australians requiring aged care. This government, in 12 short months, has managed to strip older Australians of their right to a dignified and equitable system of care. The passage of this government's bill will see a return to an incremental approach to aged care, with the addition of the user‐pays principle and a significant cut of $500 million in government support for aged care.

The Australian Labor Party rightly opposes these bills, because we view them as a totally inappropriate way of going about this task—a view shared, I might add, by health care professionals and proprietors. Older Australians are being placed under unnecessary and health threatening stress because of this government's uncaring and, quite frankly, frightening disregard for their wellbeing. I urge all senators to vote against the legislation.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lundy, Sen Kate

TALK.START.PARA: —To date throughout the public debate, the government has provided us with insubstantial and elusive responses to our questions relating to the Aged Care Bill. It has also made a mockery of community consultation, which has been redefined by the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) as `I'll talk and you listen'.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister has been dragging out the Gregory report as justification for a bill that the government knows to be a dangerous and cruel experiment on a section of the population that I was raised to believe you respected and cared for. Professor Gregory completely rejected—as does the ALP—the notion of a market model being used in aged care. That is because he understood this is about caring for older Australians, not making up rules based on one's ability to pay.

The Howard government has continued to claim that this bill will ensure accessible and equitable access to care for older Australians. If this is the case, why are there 23 sets of principles, or disallowable instruments, in the legislation? Also, why do these instruments include statements such as clause 1(b), which reads:
. . . to promote an appropriate quality of care and accommodation for the recipients of aged care services . . .

as opposed to `a higher quality of care'? We believe that this principle must demonstrate a commitment to higher quality care that encompasses best practice and accreditation. The ALP believes it is vital that the government include instruments that focus on the backbone of nursing homes—and that, of course, is their staff.

If the government wanted older Australians to feel as relaxed and comfortable as those on the government benches feel, it would have included in its legislation principles on service users' rights and high quality care. If this government adhered to the rhetoric it has been using about the system that the Labor government created and refined, it would have no problem in setting benchmarks for the care and dignity of Australians in residential care. But the government does not, and this unfortunately says so much.

This bill is ill-conceived and aimed at the lowest mark. I have to say that, on examination of the bill, it does not even look as if it will reach that low mark. The system that the Labor Party implemented and refined was one that was aimed at coping with an ageing population. The Australian Labor Party has maintained that nursing homes should be equally available to all Australians as, without such equity, divisions in systems of care will inevitably arise.

The chasm that exists between Labor's commitment to older people in Australia and that of this government is the fact that the Aged Care Bill is designed to respond to market forces. Labor's plan put people first. But what is intended under this bill is that the care and accommodation of the older generation will be determined by principles of economic rationalism instead of principles of basic rights to live with dignity.

Under this bill, to have had the highest standard of accredited care, to have had a Commonwealth body that regulates on your behalf and a system that allows you to concentrate on your own happiness and health and that of family and friends, instead of having to contemplate the relationship between your financial status and the care you will receive, will become prefaced by the adage `in the good old days'.

If this government had adhered to the Gregory report, they would not have contributed only a mere $10 million for capital needs for special circumstances. The facilities that often require upgrades are Commonwealth assisted, because they tend to cater for a greater proportion of older people who cannot afford to enter into the user‐pays system. Tragically, they may have no money, no home, no family support or no care networks—and sometimes all of the above. Consequently, these people will now have no choice in their place of care.

The minister would have to have her head in the sand not to see the effects of these circumstances on many residential care facilities. As the Labor Party has continuously stressed, this is an issue of care, not just accommodation. The Howard government's response to people on low incomes has been dangerously naive in this regard. The government have said that they will fund 27 per cent of places around Australia, and that that 27 per cent will be reserved for people who cannot pay the entry fee.

Given that the government has agreed, under pressure, that a couple will not have to dispose of their home as a means of paying for entry if only one person is going into a nursing home, combined with the number of pension recipients who cannot afford the fees, I am gravely concerned that the 27 per cent of places will not cover everyone who has a right to a government assisted reserved place in the next 10 to 20 years. With respect to the sale of the home becoming a reality for many requiring a place in a nursing home, the minister knows full well that around 90 per cent of people who go into nursing homes have been living alone.

The government has resorted to a typical response when trying to launch new policy changes by accusing the Labor Party of scaremongering. We have heard it many times in this chamber from the minister. The reality is that many older people cannot enter the user‐pays system. The fact that the government has set the subsidy for concessional residents at $5 per bed per day is nothing short of outrageous. The minister has been consistently advised by people in the sector who know what the real costs of the system are, and they have said that $12 per day is the minimum amount that is necessary.

The Labor Party has worked hard to prevent the establishment of classes of care. We will not allow a situation to arise where organisations are forced to pick between a $5 a day person or someone who can afford more. Since this debate started, we have been inundated with faxes from nursing homes around Australia. What administrators, managers and directors are saying to us is that $5 a day is a joke for concessional residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not $5; it is $7.

—I have had faxes from people in Gulgong, Woy Woy, Dubbo and Deniliquin—just to name a few places—who are in a state of shock about this bill. We are supporting their call for a realistic costing of capital subsidy for concessional residents. These faxes from rural and remote areas have provided evidence again that bills such as this work on the premise that there is one set of rules for those with money and another set for those who are disadvantaged by things such as where they live.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP believes that people in rural areas should not be punished for their geographical location. In debating this bill, we will seek to assure all older Australians that appropriate mechanisms will be put in place to monitor the number of concessional residents accessing places based on their need, not their socioeconomic status or address.

It is the government's job to assure the people in the aged care sector that they will not be lost in the search for the bottom line. We would like the government to explain to the many nursing home residents and staff how they can provide quality care when they will be worse off by up to $200,000 per annum, as is claimed by one group.

Many nursing home directors, due to their commitment to the disadvantaged, have provided for a higher proportion of subsidised places. For these directors, this bill sounds like their worst nightmare. These people will be forced to turn away those in need to maintain economic viability. I think this is cruel and unfair to those in management, because they are being punished for caring.

People in my own community have expressed their bitter disappointment that there is no recognition and, indeed, under this bill, no capability for those who are not in it for a profit. For some in this sector, their life in aged care is genuinely driven by altruism rather than directors' fees. The human factor is extinct in this bill.

Viable mechanisms for accountability are also missing. There are so many unanswered questions about the prudential arrangements and the details of the residential subsidy classification instruments that nursing homes really are in disbelief about the planned implementation of this bill.

According to people in the aged care sector and the community service sectors who are responsible for analysing this bill and disseminating information, there has not been enough information and there are very few signs of cooperative dialogue from the government. For those in the sector, attempts to understand all the parts of this very bill we are debating has produced, according to one person, a `deafening silence' from the government. People in my community here in Canberra have said to me that this much touted change of the aged sector has stalled and that it is in serious need of a major rethink.

Across‐the‐board, people are asking us to ensure that users of aged care facilities and workers in that industry will not suffer any more under this government. This is why we are seeking to ensure that this bill is amended. People in my community are very angry, frustrated and disappointed with a government which, for many, has betrayed them.

I think the government sentiment has been summarised by the member for Hindmarsh when she described this legislation as `revolutionary'. To cut almost $½ billion from the sector that cares for older people is so revolutionary it is in fact barbaric and extreme.

I would like all those who have made attempts to defend this bill to envisage the society they are trying to create. While you are at it, you can think about what your contribution to the international year for older persons will be in 1999. The Howard government should hang its head in shame. In two years we will be celebrating the lives, experiences, contributions and achievements that older people have made to this country and indeed the world. But under this aged care bill the celebration will be marred by the disappointment that older Australians will have in this government, and their ongoing frustration in dealing with a system that is inadequate and ineffective in servicing their needs.

To have squandered the opportunity to continue the reform that the Labor Party started and instead to choose to attack the funding base and dismantle the structure designed to provide equitable support and protection to those in need is a disgrace, as is this bill. It is fairly typical of a number of initiatives of this government that they have targeted aged care. I draw a parallel with the cuts to child care. In mentioning those two sectors together, I note that it was indeed the Treasurer (Mr Costello) who drew the nation's attention to the fact that these were two of the highest growth areas of government expenditure. Isn't it interesting that the government has chosen the two highest growth areas to totally cut down and dismantle instead of applying an effective strategy that acknowledges that growth and the need for growth in both of those sectors.

The fact that they have cut both those sectors, with all the implications, demonstrates that we do not have a government that governs in the interests of people. We have a government that governs in the interest of the budget bottom line, and that will be to the detriment of us all in the short, medium and long term.
(Quorum formed)
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 10.30 p.m. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment this evening on the fact that while there have been positive inroads into increasing the number of women in parliaments around the world, it is glaringly obvious that the pace of reform in reducing the gender gap in political life needs to accelerate. Inter‐parliamentary Union, or IPU, studies of women in the parliaments of the world in 1991, 1993, 1995 and 1997 plainly demonstrate the under‐representation of women.

SPEECH.PARA: In its 1991 study the IPU surveyed the lower or single chamber of the national parliament of each country in the study. At 30 June 1991, women made up only 11 per cent of the world's national parliaments. By 30 June 1993 this figure had dropped to 10.1 per cent and rose again in 1997, so that women now represent about 12 per cent of parliamentarians in the lower or single chamber in parliaments around the world.

These are concerning figures for a number of reasons. Firstly, they are dangerously low. Whereas women represent close to 51 per cent of the population, they only represent, on average, about one in eight members of lower houses of parliament, according to IPU study figures. Secondly, in a six‐year period from 1991 to 1997, when numerous elections have taken place globally, there is no definite trend which indicates a marked increase in the percentage of women parliamentarians. In effect, the figures represent a plateau effect as opposed to an increasing exponential line.

Numerous commentators have claimed that the `critical mass' percentage required for women to significantly affect policies and procedures is about 33 per cent. The United Nations regards 30 per cent of women in parliament to be the benchmark for meaningful participation in a country's parliament.

Moreover, there are important reasons why the disparity in representation should be overcome. Firstly, there are issues of democracy and egalitarianism. Ideally, a group comprising 50 per cent of the population should have a comparative role in the decision making process of government. It is inequitable to exclude half of the population from the decision making process.

Secondly, a parliament which does not have a healthy representation of women cannot claim to legitimately represent the population. Thirdly, without making sweeping generalisations, it is fair to say that women are able to bring different perspectives to the decision making process, particularly in the development of social policy.Women parliamentarians are also able to ensure that major government decisions are not made without consideration being given to the impact of those policies on women generally. Fourthly, it is both productive and efficient to involve women in the parliamentary process.

So how does Australia fare? Given that Australia was one of the earliest countries in which women gained the right to vote and to stand for federal parliament, progress has been relatively slow. Only 23 out of 148 members of the House of Representatives are women, which is a mere 15.54 per cent. Fortunately, the Senate, due to the method of voting being proportional representation, has double this ratio, with 32.89 per cent of the chamber being women.

In 1995 the United Nations ranked Australia 26th in the world in terms of women's representation in the nations' parliaments, based on 1994 data from 114 countries. Australia ranks sixth in the world amongst 130 countries based on 1992 data in a measure which the United Nations calls the gender‐ related development index. This is an average measure of the extent to which a country has been able to provide equally for both its male and female populations in terms of access to the basic human capabilities of a long and healthy life, education, knowledge and a good standard of living.

Australia is among the top few countries in terms of international comparisons in closing the gender gap. But the relevant issue here is: how can progress towards reducing the gender gap in society generally be translated and duplicated in the political arena? At the moment, there is a total of 21.4 per cent of women in the Australian federal parliament, which falls short of international targets of between 30 and 33 per cent.

The Australian experience suggests, however, that the quota system is not the path to follow in terms of improving representation. Quotas are means to engineer outcomes without overt regard to merit or talent. Neither the experience of the British Labour Party nor the Australian Labor Party has been particularly successful with employing quotas to achieve structural transformation to enable greater female participation.

Affirmative action policies within the British Labour Party, however, have been gradually adopted and have proved successful. The British Labour Party introduced a quota system in 1994 whereby 50 per cent of targeted seats would have all women candidate short lists. This policy, however, was disallowed in 1995 as a result of a challenge under the United Kingdom Sex Discrimination Act.

Irrespective of the end to the quota system which was initiated in 1994, gains were made by British women following the recent general elections. Six hundred and fifty‐nine seats were contested at the recent British election—158 by women. In 1992, 138 candidates were women—representing a rise of only three percentage points since 1992. However, the percentage of women who stood and won has increased by a substantial 37 points. In 1992, most of the women candidates were selected for unwinnable seats, in direct contrast to the 1997 election. Following the 1997 election, 18 per cent of the British parliament, 120 members, is comprised of female parliamentarians, which compares to only 9.2 per cent or 60 members in 1992.

These gains reflect the result of political parties—the British Labour Party in particu lar—making conscious and concerted decisions to increase the proportion of female representation. Similarly, the Australian Labor Party adopted a quota for preselections whereby women would constitute 35 per cent of the party by 2002. Implementation of this decision has apparently met with resistance from the Queensland and New South Wales branches. The quota system did not ensure that women were more likely to be preselected for safe seats. In her article published in the Sydney Papers, Eva Cox said:
I don't think the Labor Party's quotas have worked at all. It's fairly sad that the Labor Party, after making a lot of fuss, actually was beaten by the Liberal Party on numbers.

The following is a recent measure of the failure of the system: of 15 ALP members, including two women, who retired at or since the March 1996 election, in only one case—Jenny Macklin, the member for Jagajaga—was a women preselected to replace a retiring member. This represents 6.6 per cent—well short of the 35 per cent target.

In 1994 the coalition established the National Liberal Women's Forum to attract, train and lobby for women candidates. The women's forum offers guidance, mentor programs, support, training schemes and information kits. The result for the coalition following the 1996 federal election was not an overnight phenomenon but rather something that was part of a longer term plan to improve the status of women within the party and, ultimately, within the Australian political landscape.

There are 28 coalition women in the federal parliament at present out of a total of 48. Forty per cent of all women in the Senate are members of the coalition. The most stark figures are in relation to the House of Representatives. In that other place, 18 out of the 23 women are members of the coalition parties. This represents an overwhelming majority of 78.26 per cent.

The challenge, naturally, will be to maintain and increase the proportion of female parliamentarians. The Australian experience and that of many other democracies globally gives credence to the notion that quotas have not delivered the desired outcome and can, in fact, hinder—not improve—the status of women in the parliamentary process. It is vital for political parties to establish and implement internal party networks and structures which give women sufficient opportunities to develop the necessary skills and determination to put forward their candidature and succeed in winnable and safe positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to say a few words about the `for all of us' government and to focus on its success in the area of unemployment. I suppose it would like to claim some success in employment, but of course it is really unemployment.

BREAK.PARA: When the coalition won government last year, they said that the most fundamental issue they had to address was the budget deficit and that was so critical to achieving better outcomes in terms of investment that would ultimately lead to the creation of jobs. They embarked upon that campaign, which was really a campaign of slash and burn. It did not seem to have too much focus on creating jobs—in fact, I think it has had exactly the opposite effect.

The government cut almost all of the funding for the labour market programs that we had in place under Working Nation and, in effect, replaced them with nothing, save for one or two ad hoc programs such as the green corps and, more recently, work for the dole. The government did make some of these announcements prior to the election and had a policy about changing industrial relations legislation. That was a fundamentally important thing to do to create jobs, to remove the burden on business in terms of what they saw were very strict industrial relations laws and to free up the labour market. We have not seen too much evidence that that has created too many jobs either.

Then the focus went on interest rates. It is good that we have seen interest rates come down in this country. But I have to say that, despite the government wanting to claim all of the credit for this, much of it was due to the processes and programs that the former Labor government put in place in addressing inflation. The very reason we have got low interest rates is that we have low inflation. Yes, I would acknowledge that some credit must go to the government in terms of it addressing the fiscal aspects of government costs, but, in essence, the main reduction in interest rates occurred because of the previous government's management of the economy.

Even though we have got low interest rates and we have heard many claims about how housing affordability has come down—and it has—we are not seeing in any way, shape or form people prepared to buy. We have got the lowest interest rates that we have had for many years. The trouble is that people's principal concern—about their jobs—is not being addressed.

The government has taken steps to contract out and privatise many government services and many thousands of jobs have been lost. I think I saw the leader of the ACT government saying that, whilst there is a potential for 2,000 jobs to be lost in Newcastle, within the ACT some 4,000 jobs will go in the next two years and the ACT has already lost 4,000 jobs in the previous 12 months. You cannot keep taking out of an economy, no matter where it is, that number of jobs and expect people to maintain confidence.

If you look around the country at all of the former Public Service jobs that provided services to the community that have been lost, and then take account of all of the cuts that this government has made to various programs in education, health and child care in particular, you will see that people do not have the confidence any more. This government needs to instil some confidence back into the people about security of employment, let alone create employment—because it is not doing that either. It is not growing the economy. It has no capacity to grow the economy at a rate that will take account of people leaving school looking for jobs, let alone create jobs for those who are currently unemployed.

In terms of the `for all of us' claim, the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has stated on many occasions that his government would create jobs and would get unemployment down. I think the government had the target of getting unemployment down in their first 12 months to 8.25 per cent. It is well above that and going up. There is no real possibility of it coming down in the very near future—in fact, a number of people are actually stating that the unemployment rate is likely to go above nine per cent. I believe that will probably be the case if you take account of the things that are happening.

People do not have the confidence. Whilst there has been an increase in building activity—and the increase is coming off a very low base—we will not see the increases that have occurred in the past, simply because, as I said, people do not have the confidence that they will be able to maintain their job. Of course, major industries are still downsizing. They are still taking out the slack that they have in many of their industries in terms of employment.It is a matter of waiting until those things settle and until the government is able to provide some initiative and some drive in terms of industry development.

We must deal with the bounty issue. In my state, the very important shipbuilding industry was under threat—and is still under threat, I might say—because this government did not have the foresight and the decency to actually acknowledge that we do need to provide some assistance to our industries, particularly when they are competing in the export market against countries that have got major subsidy programs in place to assist their own industries.

It is just not acceptable. If the punters had to judge this government on the measure of its success in employment, it would fail miserably. In fact, many surveys show that people are judging them and that they are saying that the coalition leaders fail miserably on the basis of creating jobs for Australians; that they simply do not have any ideas; that they do not have any initiative; that they do not have any strategy for industry development in this country. I think the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, once put it that the government will be judged on its employment record. If that is the case, those opposite will be judged out of office.

In closing, because I know Senator Tierney wants to say something, I will just add that, of course, the government's latest saviour for the creation of jobs is a GST. The government wants to introduce a GST. That is now the latest thing that will create the jobs—how, I do not know. When we look around the world, we do not see too many jobs being created in the countries that actually have a GST. If the coalition, which claims to be for all of us and to be helping low‐income earners, gets to introduce a GST, low‐income earners will be the ones to suffer most and will have less confidence about the future.

I suggest that, when the Prime Minister comes back from his cricketing jaunt, he ought to sit down with his Treasurer (Mr Costello) and maybe include the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Reith, and have a little round‐table discussion and first work out what sort of GST they plan to have, if they are going to have one, and at least try to take account of the battlers of this country that they have so long purported to represent. However, the coalition really do not represent them and, until such time as they can come to grips with that, I am sure that the Australian electorate will judge them very badly.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Women South Australia: Youth Training Scheme

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to acknowledge the comments of Senator Coonan in the debate earlier this evening regarding women and their representation in parliaments around the world and just put on record how proud I am to belong to a party that has achieved more than 50 per cent representation of women in parliaments, not only in the federal parliament but in our various state parliaments where we are represented.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly commend the Liberal women on their work in getting increased representation. However, I am very concerned about the fact that many of those women who won seats in the last federal election are quite marginalised. That is, they are in marginal seats and tend to be lower down on upper house tickets. I only hope that that is a challenge that the Liberal Party will embrace come the next election to ensure that the women that they have assisted in gaining office will maintain their seats.

Also I am proud to belong to the state that was the first in the entire world to given women not only the right to stand for parliament but also the right to vote, and that was South Australia back in 1894. I just wish that we were meeting our IPU targets a little more quickly. In fact, I wish the IPU targets for women's representation in parliaments were around 50 and 60 per cent and then perhaps that would be a little more democratic.

BREAK.PARA: South Australia is the area that I wish to discuss tonight, in particular the youth training scheme that operates in South Australia but is now to be discontinued. It is one of the most successful employment initiatives offered to young people in my state and it has had a proven record of success. In fact, the scheme was a joint arrangement between the South Australian state government and the Commonwealth to give young people real access to jobs.

I am sad to say that in my state the number of 15‐ to 19‐year‐olds looking for full‐time work is now over 37 per cent—in fact 37.1 per cent according to the latest statistics. This compares with an unemployment rate of 9.8 per cent for those people aged 20 or more looking for full‐time work in South Australia. As you will be aware, these figures do not take into account the underemployed and other hidden unemployment figures. These figures mean that 8,400 young people in South Australia are without work but want a full‐time job.

These figures are disastrous and should serve as a neon sign to governments both at state and federal level that something is wrong and that the future for many young Australians is particularly bleak. Of course, it is particularly bleak when we are looking at some of the schemes that have been put forward by governments on a state and federal level in order to solve the problem of underemployment and unemployment. We have the Green Corps, which Senator Murphy mentioned earlier, but that is only 3,500 places over the next three years compared with a potential 75,000 over three to four years that have been lost through LEAP and REAP programs.

We have got increased disincentives, financial and psychological, to participate and enter education at every level. At a primary level and secondary level, we are seeing this shift from public education to private education—that is, a user‐pays principle. On a higher education level, we are seeing increased fees and charges up front and full‐cost fees. We are seeing the abolition of labour market program training places—around 120,000 places will be lost over the next three to four years. Recent changes include the work for the dole scheme, so there is a message to young people that somehow it is their fault that they cannot find work and that perhaps they should try a little harder, but, if they cannot find work, we will compel them to work for their meagre social security benefits, with no guarantee, not even a promise, of a job at the end of that process.

Only this week we have seen proposals regarding a common youth allowance, which suggests that, unless you are sick or you are homeless, if you are 16 or 17 and unemployed you will not get unemployment benefits. So many decisions have been taken by decision makers at a range of levels that make the future somewhat bleak for younger Australians.

As for the youth training scheme, it featured award wages, accredited training for 12 months and a high percentage of ongoing job placements in both the public and the private sectors. It was an Australian best practice model of real job training and creation. The training aimed to give young people the skills that the private and the public sector say young people need but which, of course, they are not necessarily given in school. These skills include basic job survival training, telephone manners, business protocols, et cetera, and exposure to workplaces as diverse as information technology offices, laboratories, hospitality, warehousing et cetera. All the trainees are expected to be computer literate. I think that is a necessity in today's age. The emphasis was to make these young people ready to work in either sector but, in particular, ready to work in the private sector.

Since December 1993, the youth training scheme has engaged a total of 3,500 young people as trainees. In the 1996‐97 financial year, a total of 1,200 young people were placed, and the Commonwealth matched a state government commitment of $10.2 million with a further $13.3 million, including some funds from ANTA, the Australian National Training Authority. The funding was provided as an experiment in getting young people to work—and it was a highly successful one at that.

This program did work. Of the original 2,000 trainees, more than 70 per cent found employment. This mean that the current high youth unemployment rate of 37 per cent would be reduced by about a quarter if the scheme were to continue with those kinds of placement rates. The only question left is: why has the government failed to take up this positive experience and taken advantage of a tried and tested scheme and idea? Surely this is what we must be doing if we are to solve not only the unemployment crisis among young Australians but also the under‐employment crisis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran, Sen Julian

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter that is important to the National Party. It is a matter that has been brought to the party's attention by two of the party's notables: former Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the Party, Doug Anthony, and former member for Gippsland, Peter Nixon. I might add that both are respected political operators with a record of long and worthy service to the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter relates to Old Parliament House. The complaint is that, if Old Parliament House has been established as a political museum, then why does the old National Party party room not form part of the history of Old Parliament House? After all, the room stood for 62 years as our home base—that is, for 62 years of our 76‐year history. It is worthy of note that ours is the second oldest party in existence. We have served in more governments than any other party, yet we have been cut out of the history of the nation's first Parliament House. Many present day members served in Old Parliament House.

I have been delegated by my party to pursue the matter, so I went down to Old Parliament House to see this desecration. I attached myself to a public tour of the house and, when it passed the old National Party—nee Country Party—party room, the guide glibly said in passing, `Over there is a gallery of famous people.' The guide kept walking and took the tour with him. Our history and our room has been reduced to a gallery `over there'.

All the old signs that once identified the room are gone. But, worse than this, when I peeled off the tour and entered the so‐called gallery, though I must say I had been warned what to expect, nevertheless the shock was still great. Hanging up on the walls of the grand old party's inner sanctum was a real rogues gallery: Gough Whitlam, Neville Wran, Bob Hawke, Lionel Murphy, Philip Adams, Don Chipp and Edna Everage! This can be verified by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) and others who have since been down to the room to see for themselves that it is not just some vision. The party believes that this gallery of rogues should be removed and the room restored to its original state. It is true some of the original furniture has been transferred to our current party room, but we may be willing to return the furniture to restore the old room's authenticity.

Having been on a guided tour, I can surely guarantee that re‐establishing the party room will add a great deal of spice to what are presently somewhat dull tours and add to the numbers coming through the turnstiles. I am sure that, when the public come on these tours, they are looking for authenticity and even some political intrigue which a revamped National Party party room would surely give.

I ask the minister to review the economics and practicalities of our request and re‐establish the room and the building to their original historical integrity on behalf of old and new members of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran, there are some in that rogues gallery who might not want their photos to be in the National Party room either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to describe an event that will be taking place in Darwin this weekend. The same event last year had 32,000 people visit it, and over the three days that it was held it generated business conservatively valued at approximately $15 million.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual Northern Territory Expo is an outstanding success story that demonstrates the continuing and growing links with the South-East Asian region that the people and the government of the Northern Territory are rapidly cultivating. The expo is also an important forum and opportunity for the Territory to aggressively market and make itself an essential economic partner to Asia. The key focus is to develop trade, business and investment links between the Northern Territory and South‐East Asia.

From its beginning 22 years ago as a local trade fair, the Northern Territory Expo has expanded to become the largest fair of its kind in Australia. At the 1995 expo there were 170 exhibits and 28,000 visitors. Last year the number of exhibits had almost doubled to 316, with visitor numbers, as I said earlier, up to 32,000.

This phenomenal growth reflects the importance that the Northern Territory government and business community place on this opportunity to reach new markets and showcase their products and services within both Australia and to their northern neighbours. The 1997 Northern Territory Expo is expected to be the biggest and best ever, with 35,000 visitors anticipated and the number of exhibitors exceeding last year's record number, with that number increasing to 320.

The success of Northern Territory Expo is a tribute to the vision and confidence of the Northern Territory government and the Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry took control of the expo in 1990 and formed NT Expo Pty Ltd in 1996, a wholly owned subsidiary of the chamber, to manage and organise the event each year. The event has progressed substantially since the chamber began managing it, and its growth is highlighted by the substantial increase in the number of stallholders and visitors, as described earlier. This also indicates the support that the business community and the wider Darwin community have given to the event.

The expo's manager, Elizabeth Hutchinson, who experienced a baptism of fire when she took over the organisation of the 1996 event a mere 10 weeks before the launch, has stressed the importance of community involvement in the event and the growing sense of pride and ownership felt by the people of Darwin towards the expo.

It is no coincidence that the success of the expo in recent years coincides with the stewardship of the chamber and the significant support they receive from the Northern Territory government, particularly the Hon. Eric Poole, the minister, and his Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry. Carole Frost, General Manager of the Northern Territory Chamber of Commerce and Industry, describes the expo as the jewel in the crown of the chamber. And I believe that the chamber's 1,000 members in the Territory would agreewholeheartedly with her.

The national significance placed on the Northern Territory Expo is best illustrated by the fact that this year's event will be the venue for a meeting of the state and territory trade ministers and that it will also receive a number of political and trade dignitaries from Asia.

The Federal Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, will again attend the expo, his second since opening the 1996 expo. This year the minister will be presenting the award for the best international exhibit. Mr Fischer's presence at the expo indicates the importance the federal government attaches to the event and the opportunities it offers for expanding trade and markets to the Asian region. Mr Fischer has previously commented:
The strong support that Expo continues to attract is another demonstration of the Northern Territory's `can do' approach to business and trade.
He believes:
It is the Territory's go ahead attitude which has underpinned its strong economic growth.

This is a ringing endorsement of the actions and policies of the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party government with regard to trade and the efforts made to facilitate increased access to Asian markets by Territory business.

The Northern Territory government has worked extremely hard to develop and foster trade and business links with its Northern neighbours. The Northern Territory government's Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry provides support to business and industry in the Territory to encourage development. The department works with business, industry and government to achieve many objectives, including: the development of business and international trade; the provision of a network of relationships for clients; the identification of trends and emerging technologies; and the transfer of skills and technology.

The rapid growth in trade between the Northern Territory and particularly the members of the Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines group—or what is called generally the East ASEAN Growth Area—can in large part be attributed to the Department of Asian Relations, Trade and Industry in the Territory and the successful strategies they have implemented.

The latest annual growth figures for trade between the Northern Territory and the East ASEAN Growth Area, as published in Territory Business, demonstrate the extent of growth in trade and the effectiveness of strategies being pursued by the department. Trade with the Philippines has increased by 15 per cent, with Brunei by 40 per cent, with Indonesia by 58 per cent, and trade with Malaysia is up by an incredible 90 per cent.

Apart from the activities of the Northern Territory department and the success of the Northern Territory Expo in increasing trade with countries in the Asian region, another organisation having a significant effect on trade is the International Business Council. The International Business Council has organised a conference which is one of the four major business and industry conferences and seminars held in the week leading up to the expo that more than l,000 interstate and international delegates attending expo will participate in.

BREAK.PARA: An interesting facet of the International Business Conference is that participants will be matched on a region by region basis. Each participating state, region or province will host their own seminar and participants will be matched at these seminars.

Other conferences and seminars being held include the Australian Dairy Corporation's, the annual Dairy Classics Night, the Offshore Supply and Service Seminar and the European Commission's `Australia-Europe-Asia: a guide to business opportunities.' The European Union is also featured in the International Pavilion, and they obviously see the NT Expo as an ideal opportunity to enhance their trade with Asia through Australia. This is something of a coup for the expo, as the European Union has a consumer base of 370 million and is now the world's largest trading block.

The recognition of the growing importance of Australia and the Northern Territory in this trade to the region has come about through the implementation of long‐term planning and strategies of the Northern Territory and the issues they have undertaken to stimulate trade, investment and other business. They have participated in memorandums of understanding with various countries and provinces in the region. We are well aware that these include: Indonesia in 1992, China in 1993, the Philippines and Brunei Darussalam in 1995, and Bali and Labuan in 1996. These memorandums of understanding are yet another example of the Territory's desire to pursue stronger and more beneficial relationships with our closest neighbours.

It is not only expo and the Northern Territory government wishing to achieve these changes. The Northern Territory University is making a strong push into Asia. A number of courses have focused on South-East Asian trade, culture and language, and the university is also actively recruiting students from Asia. There are also a number of reciprocal academic and research projects in Indonesia and other countries of our near neighbours. These portents of what expo is all about and long‐term planning underpin and guarantee the special link between the Northern Territory and Asia.

Expo is an initiative of the Northern Territory government, and its Chief Minister, the Hon. Shayne Stone, opened the expo earlier today. The expo will no doubt be an outstanding success, with many businesses and trade deals resulting. The expo, though, is not all business.

An added incentive to attend Northern Territory Expo is that there is the opportunity to make extensive and useful business contacts from both overseas and interstate. Participants can also enjoy an active round of social engagements and sporting activities in the absolutely perfect weather of Darwin's dry season.

There is an 18‐hole single stableford golf tournament which is to be held at the Darwin Golf Club's international championship course. That is an extremely popular event with visiting Asian business people. There is the gala event, the Northern Territory Expo dinner. This event gives the chance to continue networking on a more informal manner; it is to be held at the MGM Grand Casino. For those who are more musically inclined, there will be two concerts held during the week, a special preview of the International Guitar Festival and the Northern Territory Expo concert featuring several of Australia's finest entertainers.

When culture and trade combine, an important synergy develops, and the citizens of the Northern Territory are clearly confident leaders of Australia's important thrust and links with Asia. (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services: Grants and Programs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 10 April 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What programs and or grants administered by the Minister's portfolio provide assistance to people living in the following federal electorates: (a) the Northern Territory; (b) Kalgoorlie; (c) Leichhardt; (d) Herbert; (e) Kennedy; and (f) Capricornia.

(2) (a) What was the level of funding provided through the programs or grants in (1) to each electorate for the 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years; and (b) what level of funding was budgeted for in each electorate for each program or grant for the 1996‐97 financial year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the follow ing answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Health and Family Services has produced Electorate Profiles which provide an overview of the Department's service delivery activity, for which information is available, in each of the federal electorates. The full set of May 1996 Electorate Profiles, including the federal electorates of: (a) the Northern Territory; (b) Kalgoorlie; (c) Leichhardt; (d) Herbert; (e) Kennedy; and (f) Capricornia, is available in the Parliamentary Library.

(2) (a) The level of funding provided through the Department's programs and grants in each of the federal electorates for the 1994‐95 and 1995‐96 financial years is included in the respective Electorate Profiles. Expenditure for 1995‐96 is only to May 1996, the date at which the Profiles were produced. The Electorate Profiles are in the process of being updated and should be available in June 1997.

(b) The portfolio does not budget expenditure by federal electorate and is therefore unable to provide data on the level of funding budgeted for each of the electorates for the 1996‐97 financial year.
